Best part is the Fragata Sarmiento. Not much going on at Puerto Madero, so go when the Fragata Sarmiento is open to climb aboard. Fun for kids and adults to explore both decks.
Lively spot for eating and strolling. The modern, rising neighborhood attracts tourists and locals alike. Good for lunch at a waterside cafe and like everyone else is doing, a stroll.

Such a beautiful place!!!. We ate at a couple of the restaurants there. Estilo Campo was fantastic - great steak. The walk along the waterway was remarker with the views on both sides. There were a couple of open air bars there also that looked amazing.

One of my favorite spots in Buenos Aires, day or night. Reminds me a bit of the docklands in London where I live. Great place to walk around in the sunshine, or after dark. Lots of different places to eat, and equally suitable for a romantic walk or a family lunch.
Nice Area. Definitely check this place out. This is the newest part and richest part of Buenos Aires. Great place to jog/walk, eat, take pictures, exercise, etc.

worth some time. This is a renewed port area with a nice walkway that runs along a number of docking areas separated by swing bridges. It is the newest part of BA with many high rise buildings and very expensive restaurants. One of the highlights of the area is the Puente de la Mujer ("Women's Bridge"). It is a rotating bridge midway along Puerto Madero. It is an interesting design and popular for picture taking.
Lovely place. Puerto Madero is a great place to take a stroll... Many nice restaurants and some old ships to take a look at. Would recommend the restaurant Siga La Vaca

Smart upmarket area. This is the location of some of the city’s most expensive real estate – walkways flank the Rio de la Plata with some interesting bridges. There are shops and restaurants lining the walkways. This is a great place for a run in Buenos Aires, where you don’t have to dodge the traffic.
Really nice restaurant area. Very nice views and restaurants area in puerto madero, blocks are long so take tennis shoes, and light clothes.

Nice view and food. There are a lot of restaurants there where you can go and eat a delicious meat, inclding a nice desert and a nice view at the ships, also is one of most expensive parts in baires so take care with your pocket.

Great place to walk. Every time i come to Buenos Aires i make it a point to come here. It's a great place to walk before and after a big meal. Lot's of good restaurant to choose from. Bring cash since quite of few places do not take cash.
Great place!. It is a fabulous recycled old pot facility. There are a few fantastic restaurants. Easy to get around
Great walking good restaurants. We went for a walk and also for dining at the restaurant siga la vaca great view of the river and bridges variety of food and drinks around very local very nice

Variety of restaurants. Many restaurants all along the peer. Most of them are parrilla and a bit expensive. Expect $60 per person average.
You will also find fast food options McDonald's and Burger King.

Great walk around BA. Because it is a naval base, it is a great safe place to walk around by the water. There are restaurants and bars all along the water. It is also a great place to run if you need a nice space to work out.
Worth a visit!. I studied while abroad and have stayed there on trips since. Good for an afternoon to walk around. Its an entirely new area of the city, can feel a bit sterile, but fun to see!

Beautiful reclamation of the old port. Walked all through this area during my recent stay in BA. They have converted all the dock-lining buildings into shops and restos, as well as installing a university. Beautiful to walk, lots to shop and eat, and signs explaining all the significant sites. Thoroughly enjoyed it.

Good quality restaurants. Good quality restaurants and nice environment.
Pleasant walk along the waterside. Quite busy at the weekends which gives it a nice atmosphere. Feels safe walking around.
Worth a visit if you are in the city.
Pretty Walk. Enjoyed dinner at one of the restaurants and then a nice walk by the river. The sites are beautiful at night.
Nice Place to walk around. It's a nice place to walk around, but since it's touristy, it's pricey. So I what I recommend it's to walked around, take pictures, hang out, and go eat somewhere else.

OK but not really interesting. Numerous restaurants in this redeveloped wharf side complex offering Argentina's famed meats and fish. The food was good but not exceptional. Service in the one in which we dined was only average and made a little more difficult in that no on in the very large touristy restaurant spoke English.
River front. A renewed river front with modern amenities. Lots of restaurants and things to see. The sailing ship museum is a trip back to the past. Pricey compared to other areas.

Great new area in Buenos Aires. This area was an old port which was redeveloped about ten years ago. It is now full of hotels, apartments, shops and restaurants. Easy to get from here to all other parts of BA. HOHO has several stops in the area. Great place to walk. Lots of people around and very safe. We walked after dark and felt perfectly safe. Hilton in this area is a great place to stay if you want to be a it away from the hustle of the city.

Nice barrio. I was several times in Puerto Madero. Its a really safe area. I liked to walk alongside the water or in the big park. On sunny days its perfect to relax and read your book. On weekends it gets crowded. The shops and restaurants are expensive, so i propose to bring drinks with you.

Puerto Madero, Buenos Aires. Distant about 15 minutes walking from downtow and "microcentro" toward the "Rio de la Plata" Puerto Madero is located.Is a beatiful place where you can find a variety of Restaurants to have lunch or dinner aswell.Also, is a dockside Boardwalk, along you'll find the bridge "Puente de la Mujer" and also the museum ship "Fragata Sarmiento" open to visit.If you cross to the other side, I mean, going farther more towards the river, you'll be able to see the neighborhood "Puerto Madero" one of the newest in town, where modern buildings are still being raised.A curiosity, all streets have women names related to argentinian history.A must see if you travel to Buenos Aires.
Great spot for a stroll!. Beautiful, trendy part of the city. Grab a drink & stroll along the boardwalks on either side of the Puente de la Mujer bridge. Great spot to escape the crowds!

Worth a visit, but not the best waterside area I've visited. My view is slightly clouded by the fact that it was very cloudy on the day I visited! Even so I felt that this area still felt somewhat industrial and not really a tourist attraction if that is what it is trying to be. The Puente de la Mujer is impressive but I'm not sure if it's worth making a major detour to Puerto Madero just to see this, as I don't feel there's much else in the vicinity to see. Perhaps it's nicer on a sunny day to sit by the water's edge but I can't be sure.

Attractive warehouse development on the river. We had a pleasant stroll along the waterfront here. There are numerous restaurants and a couple of sailing boats which can be visited for a nominal cost. We had a light dinner here which was a bit disappointing but I think we just chose our establishment wrongly.
Nothing special. A badly organized development that already has signs of neglection. Not fun at all. For fun go to Palermo.
Nice water-side location. Dining by the canal is a very nice experience. Good central location for Buenos Aires. Must stop for time in BA.

A pleasant afternoon walk. We left our hotel about 4pm and walked down to the old port. We spent nearly an hour just meandering along the docks looking at the restaurant menus, watching the people go by and looking enviously at the yachts.There was somewhat of a bonus as that whole are was virtually vehicle free; "Mr" Obama was in town so the Centro" was almost closed down. Except for Police, Police Cars, Ambulances and American Spooks!! It did make walking so much more enjoyable. If you are there on a normal day be envious!!

Lots of places to eat. This area has been refurbished and the old warehouses are now offices, restaurants, and shops. There are many restaurants on the waterfront and one can have a beautiful view while eating their meal.
New area, looks like a great place to live. Modern and full of trendy restaurants, looks like a great place to live with family :) a bit on the expensive side, though...

MOST BEAUTIFUL AREA IN BA . You must come here when visiting BA. It's the high end of BA where you see beautiful shops, hotels and residences. The water view is amazing. Faena hotel is absolutely gorgeous.. We live in NYC and have stayed in the top hotels in the world. This may be top 5.
Good sightseeing and a lot of restaurants. totally tourist area but very good restaurants and nice waterfront shops and walking. They have revitalized this area several years ago and nice at night
Great place to have lunch or diner. This is one of my favorite place in Buenos Aires, It is full of restaurants with great terraces with view on the Rio Dique.

Beautiful area for walking. What a lovely area for strolling on a Sunday afternoon! We walked along the water on the city side watching boats come in, rowers paddle by, families out for an ice cream. I can't imaging this jewel in its former dilapidated form, it is such an asset to the city. Old formerly abandoned port warehouses are restored into shops and restaurants and the waterfront is a perfect place for a paseo.

Excellent area to dine and view. This is a nice area to stroll and visit. Lots of great restaurants and shops to visit.You will see people exercising on the equipment installed on the street and you have quick access to transport.
a nice neighborhood. located around the old port of Buenos Aires. High rise buildings for people with money. Nice architecture and many places for entertainment

Pleasant but Fragata ARA Sarrmiento best visit here.. Strolling here is fine- nice view of port and surroundings. Old port restored and has restaurants. My best time in the port was visiting Fragata ARA Sarmiento last year (see my report march 2015). Lots more to visit in BA than to spend too much time in this area.
Well! . Interesting historic background and the evolvement of the multi million dollar new developments around

Scorching hot, but plenty of places to relax. This modern part of Buenos Aires was one I took the chance to explore after coming out the Buquebus Terminal. Although the weather was over 35 degrees, it was very a lovely area to walk around with plenty of places to eat and drink. The highlight is, of course, the Puente de la Mujer Bridge, but the contrast with this and some of the older streets in the city makes it well worth an afternoon of your time.

Take a stroll. We stayed in the area and loved walking along the river front . But be warned...wear comfortable shoes add the cobblestones on the city side are uneven. The restaurants along the water offer a variety of food and they're are benches to sit and rest. Take water and avoid the heat of the day. Evenings are especially nice for a stroll and enjoy the lights reflecting off the water.

A Pleasant but Ordinary Place to Stroll. I am somewhat at a loss to understand the rave reviews some bestow on Puerto Madera. It has the charm of a well constructed office park. There is little to do or see. It's a nice place for a walk, but there are literally dozens of more interesting places for a stroll in Buenos Aires. If by chance someone in your party insists on visiting Puerto Madera, and you are unable to think of an excuse to decline, visit the Fortabat Museum instead of walking around the concrete port. The museum's collection is lovely and the space is beautiful. It's the personal collection of one of the wealthiest people in Argentina and is very much worth seeing.
Cool buzzing area. Lots of restaurants and bars, something for everyone. great for a sunset stroll along the river too.

Tourist spot where there are lots of restaurants near the River Plata. Lots of restaurants along the river--also a Tango place...too commercial and crowded for me. I prefer discovering local places in the city.
Spectacular. Worth the visit, 170 ha of revitilized harbour area. Good for strolls and walking, nice sidewalk cafes

Pleasant enough place if a bit Generic. Puerto Madero is a great new addition for the people of B.A. but as a visitor I didn't find it all that special with the typical global eating places (plus some local, admittedly which are supposed to be good). The best feature for me was the wonderful late 19th c. Naval training ship which is permanently moored there - wonderful! If you visit just around dusk you can appreciate the transition from daylight to a myriad of lights from the new high rise apartment buildings and the restored wharf buildings. Pleased I went there but would not necessarily rush back on any subsequent visits to the city.

Need to walk it. This is a walking experience, one of the most modern areas in Buenos Aires, full of restaurants, bars and hotels. Great place to workout if you feel caged in your hotel. Try to visit the Sarmiento frigate, or Uruguay corvette, docked at the canal. Also you can visit some art galleries like Faena.
Safiest place in town. Many of the best restaurants, but not all of them, are located in this constantly growing area. Close from downtown and several tourist attractions.

Lots of walking!. The views were good of the city and it was a nice walk around the water. However, we were approached by three different people trying to scam money or sell us items within an hour. It was a good place to visit for a short time, but not a place that we would necessarily go again.
Great resturants and lots to see. We love this place, it is very touristy but has excellent resturants and great places to walk, lots of ships and boats and easily accessed by walking or taxi,
Very nice area. Beautiful area of BA. Felt very safe walking around at night and took some beautiful shots of Puenta del Mujer before choosing a restaurant with a nice view of the water.

Skyscrapers crowding the port. In the past decade many high-rise buildings have gone up around Puerto Madero, somewhat changing the landscape. It is still full of great restaurants and worth a visit; the Calatrava pedestrian bridge merits a stroll! You can just walk over from the "microcentro" shopping area.

My favorite place for launching into Argentina, upon arrival in BA, time here allows one to brush up language skills!. I appreciate this little bridge from home to this spectacular country. Restaurants, tango, walking the circle from the Hilton to bar or restaurant brings you gliding into tomorrow's new travel adventure.

You can spend all day. One of the most beautiful places in Buenos Aires, pretty expensive though... Packed with restaurants, coffee shops and bars. Old brick port barracs refurbished and transformed in appartments and offices.
New modern neighberhood. exciting building complexes that used to be grain silos. Great to spend the day cycling, having drinks Ideal for the weekend.
The Old Port of Buenos Aires. On the way to Puerto Madero take time to photograph the famous bridge. The Port is full of great restaurants and great hotels.

Puerto Madero is Good for Daytime Stroll or Dinner at Night. Puerto Madero is a good spot for high end dining, a bit touristy, but the restaurants are popular. I personally think they are a bit over-priced and prefer to find smaller more authentic places in Recoleta or Palermo. It's a nice place for a walk on a sunny day - and b/c it's so huge, you can definitely get some exercise. We took in a ship museum - the Sarmiento - for 5 pesos which was fun, then continued to walk and had a drink at one of the nearby restaurants on the esplanade.

Very good. Went to eat on a couple of evenings. Nice to walk along the promenade by the river, although we felt we could be anywhere in Europe - ? Canary Wharf, England.Good atmosphere and choice of restaurants.

Clen, nice place to walk. This is a long walkway along the side of the water where there are a number of upscale restaurants (and a McDonalds). There are also two old boats you can go on and look at as they are now museums.Great place to go for a walk and we (as a couple) felt safe walking back from dinner along there at 10:30pm.

Upscale, Trendy Sanitized BA. Located on what is virtually all reclaimed land, this once derelict area has gotten a new lease on life. Once abandoned warehouses are now home to trendy cafes and restaurants. Luxury hi-rise buildings fill what were once empty lots. There is an interesting bridge spanning part of the port area that is in the form of a tango dancer which swings open. A nearby ecological preserve is worth a visit.
Expensive and a bit touristic, but so what?. Fun place to walk, to eat, to people watch. Lots of history. Some really fantastic restaurants. Every time in Buenos Aires, we go.

A very modern and nice place to walk, eat or drink!. Puerto Madero is the most modern place in Buenos Aires, you have to walk there and go across the Woman's bridge. There are a lot of nice restaurants and bars to eat and drink in Pto. Madero. It is cool at night or at the evening and it's a very touristic place!

the new place. Puerto Madero is the new ,fancy&expensive Bueno Aires.Nice place for a walk cause there is a nice aray of expensive terraces to enjoy a cocktail&lunch by the marina which also offers a visit on an old sail boat . Further in there is another area with nature by the water with lot's of birds,bicycles for hire&food trucs by the dozen with great views.A couple of hours is sufficient unless you decide to enjoy food&drinks.
Buenos Aires . Buenos Aires reminds me of Europe but in South America ❤️ easy to navigate and tones to see. Don't forget to bring your trainers

An area to spend the evening and dinner. This area is really good to spend the time with your friend and family in the evening and the for dinner. You can visit and see all site of buenos aires and after that finish it here. You can enjoy the time here with good food, good restaurant...
Everything you want to see or do. A very good place to spend the day or spend the night. It has several very good hotels, very good restaurants, easy access to the area around the Pink House.

Newest barrio in town. This barrio (city development) is the newest one in Buenos Aires, there are just a few old buildings and a monstrosity of silos still in place. Most are places build this century. Its tall condos are still half empty due to their highest rents in Latin America. Living here is very pleasant, no traffic jams, broad streets and the most safe place in Buenos Aires, where the local Navy police take care of business. On Sundays this turns into the Coney Island of the people, with families coming from all over to hang out in what Cubans call the Malecon (walkboard) bu the river. There are hundreds of vendors there to placate these hungry hordes.This section of town is not cheap in any way. Everything is more expensive here, save Farma City or Jumbo, which have prices like other stores.The restaurants at the entrance are expensive, no question about it. Some are very good, some not.This is not like Recoleta, where you can admire old buildings, walk a few blocks and find a nice cozy place to eat. This is like Aventura (Miami) in Argentina. Very new. If you do not stop here in your visit, you have not lost much.

Good food and nice walk. If you are looking for good food and nice atmosphere then Puerto Madero is for you. It's the newest neighborhood of Buenos Aires. Lots of high-rises, restaurants and bars along side the harbor. I would recommend going there for dinner. As anywhere else in Argentina its best to go around 9 p.m. That's when the locals go for dinner. You can relax with your Malbec, enjoy very good food specially barbeque, take a nice walk after dinner and experience the young lifestyle of the city. Adventures? Order Sweet bread (Mollejas) and blood Sausage (Morcillas). My absolute favorites! Enjoy your stay
Good food. Pricey.. Nice area with good food and wine though more expensive than many parts of town. Walking over the bridge at night is nice.

A harbor in the city center. OK, so you are on the water and want to see more water, this is a protected hatrbor with many great shops and restaurants all around. Just noce to walk about and enjoy the local flavor, mixed in with tourist stuff
great for a walk. Five former factories turned into so many restaurants. Its hard to choose. Definitely a great place to take a stroll on a nice day.

Lovely for a walk! Day & Night. gorgeous rehabilitated area of the city. It used to be a loading port (still is) but was in bad disrepair and practically abandoned for a long time. The government decided to revitalize the area by building high rise condos and bringing in dozens of restaurants and shops along a water front walk that surrounds the river area. Beautiful for a long walk after dinner, can also take river boats for water tours. Definitely adds a high end and picturesque air to the port area
Very nice walk. This is a very modern part of the city where you can eat very good food and have drinks next to the port.
Great place for a Wally and ..... If the weather is the right one it's an excellent opportunity to enjoy the new part of Buenos Aires. A lot of Restaurants, bars and shops for a good stroll

Just another redeveloped port. Lots of restaurants, but like many other port redevelopments we've visited, they're generally not all that special, and all appear to be overpriced. A pleasant place to get some exercise, but eat elsewhere.

Port recycled into restaurants and night life. Puerto Madero was the port that replaced the La Boca port but Buenos Aries outgrew it. The redevelopment came in with modern hgirises and condos. Then it added nightclubs and up scale restaruants Some historic boats are anchored along its wharves. Some restaurants specialize in Argentine buffest for lunch and dinner which are reasonable 170-200 pesos ( under $20US) for lunch and still reasonable for dinner with a view .Some tango shows also moved to Puerto madero.

Restaurant row & river walk. This is a great era to have a nice meal with a view of the river or grab an ice cream & go for a walk. I do not recommend the restaurant called Happenings. We did not get any service. After being seated and waiting 15 min. we finally left.
Not worth the effort. This really wasn't worth seeing. Although BsAs is a port city, you can't really see the ocean. Puerto Madero is a just a row of overpriced restaurants.

Puerto Madero. This seems to be where most of the hotels are located in particular cruise ship clients. You could be anywhere in the world it is dominated by shops and tourist paraphernalia and is not typical of Buenos Aires. If you want western shopping American fast food chains this is the place for you if you are a traveller rather than tourist there is no point in coming here.

Perfect way to enjoy fresh air. If your looking for a long leisurely walk with lovely scenery and plenty of bars , restaurants and shopping then this is a great day in Buenos Aires. You'll find trendy bars are a perfect place to chill and enjoy the sun. Photos attached

up to date port and environment. Nice place to visit, mostly clean and nice restaurants and shops. Puerto Madero Tango show was an amazing show. Lovely music, good food and vine in nice restaurant in Puerto Madero.
Now a modern place to see. This is agreat place to walk/drive around and visit. This place has been done up and is a very chic place to visit.
Has become overly touristy and somewhat run down. The restaurants here are really just for tourists now which is the same when the city has so many amazing options. Not worth a visit.
loveliest part of bs as. i love puerto madero so much. it must be the river. it calms me. everything is so clean and nice. highly recommended if you're in the city

Good restaurants in an open environment, lovely scenery. This is one of the bet spots in Buenos Aires for restaurants. It is one part of the old harbor transformed in a great boardwalk surrounded by several restaurants. One can also have a nice view of rio Tigre from either the boardwalk or one of the many restaurants.The neighbor hood itself is very modern and trendy with high store building at a walking distance.

Urban renewal success. This whole area was apparently run down and was reclaimed a few years ago. It's highly walkable for all ages. The river is lined with shops and restaurants. It seems a bit misleading to call it a " port". It's more like a river with no active port ...

A harbour exceptional. This is one of the best places in the city. Go there in the late afternoon and watch the sun goes down at the calatrava bridge. Great places to eat, though some of them are really expensive

Simply amazing. We go often to Buenos Aires and this is a must stop. Actually once during the day where you can have a great visit to the war ship museum and a nice walk at the port where you see the bridge and the water reflecting the sun. And once at night coz the view is completely different!The restaurants absolutely love them!!I dont eat much meat anymore, so the other restaurants like Sotovoce, Marcelo, Chila, La Parolaccia which are italian, seafood or mediterranean cuisines are really nice!!Excellent view and food and wines!!A great spot to jog as well if you live nearby.Love it!!

Beautiful Area. We didn't have much time in Buenos Aires, but I'm glad that we made it to Puerto Madero to visit. We walked around and took in the sites and we ate a wonderful lunch and drank wine. Definitely worth a stop!

Great place to spend some time!. I've stayed at the Hilton in Puerto Madero a couple of times and there was plenty to do around there to fill my evenings after work. There are several upscale restaurants, some light shopping, and beautiful scenery that is great for making all your friends back home jealous. One restaurant I'd highly recommend is Cabana las Lilas right on the waterway. I made the mistake of eating there by myself and with all the extras they bring you before you order I was stuffed by the end! It's definitely a place for a small group. Beautiful area and a cheap taxi ride away from most of Buenos Aires.

Great Restaurants, Lovely Scenery. There are some great restaurants on this promenade. Some interesting historic ships you can tour. A very beautiful and modern bridge. I recommend it for any type of traveler. This was one of my favorite parts of Buenos Aires due to it's cleanliness and lack of congestion.

Expensive . It's the most expensive neighborhood of the city, surrounded by beautiful buildings and all the trendy shops. You can get a really nice picture in the port or in the "punte de las mujeres".

Good for food choice. We spent an afternoon wandering around the recently revamped complex of warehouses that have been turned into shops and restaurants. There is a great choice of food types and prices on this complex but it's a rather soulless place and very tourist. We were recommended it for lunch and indeed we did find a great restaurant to have lunch but at a price. Worth a look but if you can manage to look and then move on to as find a more local place to eat probably better.
Nice neighbourhood. Puerto Madero is a picturesque neighbourhood, near the old port. The old warehouses are converted to trendy restaurants and appartements on the upper floor.
Worth a visit. When you are in Buenos Aries ,the old port area is interesting .Lots of resturants to choose from if you wish to eat .Full of tourists so do be careful as pick pockets are plentiful .

A lovely Sunday afternoon!. We were thirsty so we wandered over to the river to see what we could find to drink and discovered a festival-like atmosphere on a lovely summer Sunday afternoon. The training ships on the river are beautiful to look at and, although we didn't partake of the tour, we loved having them as a backdrop to our time on the river. The tango dancers also added an Argentinian flair to what might feel like any waterfront development. All in all, we were glad we went.
Beautiful for walk. Beautiful place for afternoon/evening walk. With the sunset it is amazing. Unfortunatelly, most of the restaurants are expensive there

Good area. We stayed in the Puerto madero area for a total of 3 nites. We felt safe in walking around and our hotel was near the dock area and Womens bridge. Lots of restaurants along the docki area but not much shopping.
Interesting at night. Some nice lighting around the old docks make the cranes look striking against the night sky. Restaurants were busy but not full , prices did not seem that high.

Would be better at night. We walked around here on a drizzly day and aside from a nice view of the Ladies' Bridge and a schooner, there wasn't much going on. One restaurant after another, lacking in charm, is what it seems to offer. I think it would be more picturesque at night when lights are reflecting off the water, and more vibrant at night with more people eating at the restaurants.

Penguins, Sea Lions and Elephant Seals. The city is not very interesting. Take one of the trips out of town to visit the Magellanic Penguin rookeries and beaches where sea lions disport themselves elephant seals sleep. You can get close to the penguins but not the sea lions, which is probably just as well.

Nice for walking. Nice neighborhood for an evening walk to see the people jogging, skating and to have a drink while watching the sunset. There are not many nice shops and some areas feel a bit run down. we like the Catrava bridge and the sailing ship which is moored in the canal. Have dinner at Osaka Puerto Madero.
Relaxing atmosphere . This place is very secure and has many good restaurants along the boardwalk. The puente de las mujeres and the garden are beautiful.
Chic place . Nice place with the best of Buenos Aires. The view is amazing, worth to take a walk through the place. Full of posh and expensive restaurants.

Lovely pleasant environment. Lovely for a stroll, drink and dinner. Worth a visit, particularly on a warm sunny evening. Great place to go for a stroll followed by a drink and dinner. Safe and easy to get to.
Women's Bridge crossing Puerto Madero. The bridge designed by Santiago Calatrava was outstanding, he won the Architect of the year award, certainly a must to walk over!

Generic Upscale Shopping/Restaurants. Upscale Shopping/Restaurants make this trendy upscale port area mixed use development area very popular as such areas are the world over. Close your eyes and you'd be hard pressed to know what City you were in when you opened them. Unless you're into the trendy clubs this is an expensive, crowded area to avoid. It has no character whatsoever IMHO.

Vibey, modern district with plenty to offer!!. Modern, upbeat, preserved architecture, supplemented with a wide array of cafes, bars and restaurants, provides an interim escape from the hassle bustle and monumental sights and sounds of the city. One can relax over a quite and authentic meal (if you choose), or simply chill with a beverage of your choice, after a leisurely walk around Puerto Madero. Close proximity to the CBD and other main attractions.

Take Your Pick of Restaurants. An enormous number of restaurants and cafes to choose from, offering mainly good quality but overpriced food. Keep in mind that this is a tourist area. A nice place to eat on the terraces on a warm evening,
Nothing Great. Good redevelopment of this once rundown area however definite tourist trap with the restaurants. High price..lower quality compared to other places in the city.

Good place for a walk with many restaurants. Puerto Madero is a good place for a walk followed by lunch or dinner in one of the many restaurants. Nice scenery with old Sailing ships and old port equipment like cranes.
Beuatiful place. Nice place to walk around and visit the big boat museum there. We really had a good time. Great restaurants around as well.
Best part of town for. Clean new and lots of good places to eat. One of the nicest bridges in the world. Go and enjoyBA can we a little dirty in parts. Avoid La Boca

Nice area full of over priced eateries. The remains of what would have been a bustling port. Now just a pleasant area with lots of expensive cafes, hotels and a couple of old ships. An experience that can be missed without regret.

Great place to spend time. The whole Puerto is big and you can find many places to stay. Many restaurants, cheap and expensive, nice views and good point to see ships and to go to parc. Also, there are Little sport places where you can work a bit!

Great Afternoon or Evening place. Great selection of restaurants and trendy bars. A lot of big name establishments here like TGI Friday's but a lot of Argentinian places to eat, The port and Recoleta were my favourite areas for eating in the city. The best I went to at Puerto Madero was Cabana Las Lilas, but you would need to reserve. Great scenery and place to walk around and take in some fresh air. Very loively on Saturday and Sunday afternoon's and a good atmosphere if there is a big football game on.

Restaurants. First night we arrived, we ate at Central Market. A casual restaurant in the Puerto Madero. Food was delicious -- fresh fish and uniquely prepared vegetables. We returned a few nights later to a higher end restaurant in the vicinity --- Sotto Voce. Can't say enough about the service -- high quality-- the food - and the wine from Argentina -- Chardonnay by Kaufman.And considering, we are used to NYC prices --- this was 50% less! Very affordable city.
Wonderful. this area is as fine as you will find anywhere. Safe, easy to get around, and plenty of restaurants to choose from. Waling dietance to to downtown Buenos Aires.

Visit this place at night. Visited this place twice while we stayed in Buenos Aires. Once during the daytime and once at night. The daytime views are good, nothing overwhelming but once you are there after sundown the place just lights up. The reflections on the water are mesmerising and there were hordes of people with cameras. But be very careful, as Buenos Aires is a city known for crimes. Keep your cameras and money in a safe place and don't flash those jewelleries. When you come back walk straight back and look determined.
Fire works at new years eve. If you are in Buenos Aires at the eve of new year then don't miss out the opportunity to visit Puerto Madero. During new year you can see a lot of fireworks here

Reluctant to visit but convinced by evidence. As reclamation of abandoned old industrial settings go, one would be justified not to expect too much in BsAs, well considering how so many other places in the world have had a head start. But I do have to say that they did a fantastic work. The place is an ideal balance between old and new with enough flair to make one forget that this is, after all, a country with great discrepancies andeconomic problems.If Madero was (in)famous for designing a port that had to be abandoned, the architects that planned the renovation should be given the chance to have the area named after them. That would be aestethic justice.

Nice walk around the Marina. We have now been here twice, once rain, and today sunny. Lots of places to eat but so tourist. After a lot of walking, after waiting a bit later we choose Happening. A great choice and we really enjoyed for our last night after 3 weeks in Argentina.
Very nice area, lots of shops and food. I was briefly in this area but next trip I plan to stay nearby. There were quite a few shops and lots of restaurants.
Walk through- lunch. Great lunch spot and stroll along the shore. Accessible by tourist yellow bus. You can jump off bus and jump back on. Many restaurants along wharf.
Cool but not a lot to do except eat. A waterfront. Cool reclaimed land. Pretty, but also kind of boring if you arrive early for dinner. We had to burn waiting for restaurants to open at 8 PM.

Safe area with shops and restaurants. This is one of the last areas of BA that the police have identified as "green" for crime. It is a safe area to walk at night and there are many great restaurants and some shops along the water front. Great views at night of the ships and the bridge and there are many people walking or eating on the outdoor patios. This is very close to the Hilton hotel. Great place for dinner reservations.

Quiet beautifull place to see and enjoy!. Such a nice place just walking aroud and enjoying the view! On one side of the port you can walk and enjoy the many good restaurants and on the other side enjoy the nice boutIques and beautifull buildings! There are a few boat museums you can also visit while strolling along! I recommend this area!

Outdoors in the city. Amazing and safe neighborhood to visit. Great restaurants and parks, very good place to do sports such as rollerblading, bicycle riding or jogging. The Reserva Ecologica is another amazing place to visit and only steps away

Interesting concept, but a little boring for kids. Perfect for a quiet business lunch at one of the good restaurants or a night out, but not a very fun place for taking the kids. There is not much else to do other than contemplate the architecture and view and you need to walk a lot to get from one end to the other. Very safe and pleasant for couples looking for a good place to wine and dine. It´s not really a tourist attraction unless you need a place to walk and relax.
Excellent Neighborhood. lots of restaurants and a casino. Great views. Safe during the day and at night too. I recommend Gourmet Porteno.

Excellent Steak and Interesting Sculptures. This area has several excellent steak houses to choose from, simply pick any along the boardwalk area and enjoy. There are art pieces all over the area that are worth exploring more in depth. Additionally there are old shipping cranes throughout that provide an interesting break to the roof-lines. Lovers of old ships and yachts will enjoy walking along the marina.

An amazing example of good government intervention . More than the modernity of the place, the sensation of progress, the environment of safety and joy, Puerto Madero is an example of the capacity and potential of Argentinean people. My sincere desire is that the future governments may continue the improvements in the area and spread this for the entire city.

Nothing really interesting to see, just terrible overpriced bars and restaurants. Puerto Madero is a Cliché of Buenos Aires, it's a business area so don't expect to see anything exciting. Unless you are a luxury traveller avoid the shops, restaurants and bars, as they are far too expensive and the food is regular to normal,

up & coming neighbourhood. buenos aires is such a surprising city... and the area of Puerto Madero stands out in contrast to the city's European architecturewell worth a visit and a long stroll along the refurbished old dockland
The newest area to visit Buenos Aires. Beatiful to make a walking tour, specially by night. Very nice and safe. Excellent restaurants also, but a little bit expensive.

You must know ut !. Nice and quite neightborhood near downtown of Buenos Aires.
You will find well known restaurants and do not forget to visit the Fortabat Museum located at 100 Olga Cosettini

Puerto Madero - a modern slice of history. In the historic port of Buenos Aires you will find Puerto Madero. Looking out over historic sailing ships while simultaneously passing a large selection of cafes and restaurants. I expected that this place would be a tourist trap, but I was pleasantly surprised. We were able to enjoy our walk without being hassled by touts, and the area felt safe from pickpockets.We found Puerto Madero to be a relaxing place far away from the bustle of central BA. Not to be missed.

Beautiful at night. We walked from one side of the river to the other on a beautiful January evening. We ate beef dinners at one of the wonderful restaurants along the walk and walked across the famous "woman's bridge". The atmosphere is exciting and the area beautiful and romantic.

Beautiful area, well worth a look. We walked from Cordoba up to the Sarmiento and then back to the Women's Bridge, across the bridge. Then back to Cordoba. The refurbishment of this area is great. There are lots of cafes and restaurants along the way and the prices varied from above average to expensive.
Upcoming Neighborhood. We had a lot of fun walking around this modern neighborhood. There was a great vibe and lots of trendy restaurants and bars
Stylish Area - must see. Lovely area and a place to walk about and take in the ambience of the area. A modern contrast to the historically rich buildings in BA
Great place to visit at night . Great place to have a night walk, with some pleasant views and a lot of nice restaurants and bars all around the place.
Great for a mooch around. Puerto Madero reminded me of canary wharf with sun. A lovely modern area to spend a few hours with great food options. Take a hat as the sun beats down.

Miss it out if you are short of time!. We went there for the famous street food along the ecological park but decided against trying any of the stuff on offer. It is modern and has many mid range to high priced restuarnts. Unless you want to try out the restaurants you will miss nothing by not visiting the port.
Not the best city waterfront I have visited.. Call it a good beginning. A board walk with trendy restaurants built into old ware houses, but not much else.

a gentrified area but not much more. This area, along the water, is a gentrified port area. Lots of old warehouses are now offices and shops and restaurants. Worth a stroll if in the area but I would not go out of my way to visit again.

Safe place to walk and dine. The area has many restaurants and some shopping. I used the port area to commute between the office and hotel. The dining can be higher priced and the shopping I saw was limited. I liked seeing the cranes and older boats in the harbor.This area has lots of security and is very safe. There is usually a nice breeze keeping it cooler that in denser parts of Buenos Aires.
Very interesting!. Nice restaurants, good food, in a refurbished site. It is worh a visit for the nice restaurants, which offer great food at great value.

You need to go and walk. The area is very nice.. This is one of the things you need to do when you are in Buenos Aires. Go and walk around Puerto Madero, the Women Bridge (Puente de las Mujeres) and eat a good steak in some of the places that are around there.

Nice for a stroll. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here if your time is limited. Having said that, if you have some spare time for a short stroll it is interesting to see how they have converted a former dock area into the most modern part of Buenos Aires.

Great modern part of BA. We stayed a night in this part of Buenos Aires after a South America cruise. It's a very comfortable part of town close to many attractions. Safe to walk around..Lots of restaurants & wine stores. Catamarans to the Tigre Delta are right there!!!

Cool Mix of Modern and Classic. Many reviews have mentioned the high prices at the restaurants in the Puerto Madero area. I would agree that this isn't an area to find economic eats. But, this is the sort of place that you go if you want to experience the cool ambiance of an old, restored port facility reborn as upscale dining and great people-watching. We happened to go twice. Once, we went in the late afternoon before the dinner crowd showed up. We went back early on a Sunday morning to jog. There were a few other joggers as well as some people who obviously hadn't been home from the night before. In the end, if you are visiting BA, go to Puerto Madero. You might just decide that the views and the ambiance are worth the few extra pesos that you'll have to shell out.
Liked it. Poorto madero is like another country inside Buenps Aires. Enjoyed my life and time here, relaxed ans safe atmosphere. I`d recommend it to anyone..
Definite must see. Beautiful place for a walk after a delicious meal in one of the many great restaurants and pubs available there.

A must in Buenos Ayres. Puerto Madero is a city in its modernity, a very pleasant place to walk by, to sit and see people and life passing before you, while you may hava a lunch, a dinner or even a snack drinking a local beer or a glass of wine. It is architeture, art, history, mixed in a cocktail of goog taste.

Lovely neighborhood in Buenos Aires. This is a newer, more business oriented neighborhood of BA. Make sure you see the bridge (not that you could miss it) and take a stroll through the preserve. Lots of restaurants are available as well. The air is fresh and clean in Puerto Madero.
Beautiful area. Really nice port, which is definetly worth for a walk and to take photos. This place also have many restaurants.
Still developing and very much like other city port river front developments. Ok but mixed quality and also good bits and more lively bits interspersed with dead areas - for us a bit non descript

NEW BEAUTIFUL BARRIO. This is a modern part of Buenos Aires. It has modern buildings ,lots of cafes ,restaurants and bars.Very nice for a walk and a drink on a sunny day. It also host the "women bridge " by Calatrava ,inspired in Tango.
Don't miss it . It's worth it.

Nice for a Stroll. Clean safe riverfront with a good selection of cafes and restaurants on both sides - everything from American franchises to quaint local haunts. There are several ships that have been restored as mini-museums. They are cheap and interesting - try to visit at least one.
Nothing special. Everybody was excited about this place but it's nothing special and actually overpriced. Nice to have a walk but not too long.

Seems like a tourist trap and nothing overly special in my opinion. This is the old dock area of BA that has obviously been renovated with most of the old buildings destroyed and just a few of them restored. There are about 150 restaurants over the 4 dock areas so plenty of places to eat.....just most of them seen very overpriced, you are definitely paying for the area. This area attracts a lot of beggars and although in the day it seems quite safe I would definitely watch my belongings and not sure I would feel safe there in the evenings. The water is dirty, apart from a few old boats there isn't a lot to see. I was hoping for more of a European Harbour feel but it seems more like a load of converted warehouses and modern tower blocks. For me this is nothing special, if you are limited for time in BA I wouldn't make the effort to go over to this place unless you find yourself in the area.
Just like London Docklands. Pleasant enough to walk by the polluted water and eat in overpriced restaurants but it pretty average reclaimed docks and not with going out of you way to see

nice modern place. A bit expensive but really nice views. I found better restaurants since these were too highly priced and supposedly at night there is "more action" but it was too dark to walk there at night

Getting better all the time. This area used to be the old port and has been changed into a trendy restaurant area where many people hand out. You get all types of dining for all type of wallets. Many young locals meet with their friends and so it is a very lively area. Restaurants from very good steak to Italian all available. Also great to take some nice pictures in the evening

Nice place for a walk!. I liked the atmosphere of this place. It seems to be a more liberal part of town. There's plenty of bars where one can relax, have a beer, enjoy the view and just let time pass by. There you can see the bridge El Puente de la Mujer!

cool area. nice feels like an oasis of sophistication very european. nice hotels nice fancy restaurants
it's more for those with expensive taste.

Overpriced gentrified port area. The suburb of Puerto Madero was once the dirty port area of Buenos Aires. However in recent years it has been significantly gentrified and now contains an array of high end restaurants in addition to a large nature open nature area. I visited with my partner in December 2015. It reminded me a lot of the docklands area in Liverpool. To be honest the only thing I found exceptional about it was the price of our very average lunch. I don't think it's a 'must visit' for anyone in buenos aires.

Nothing special. Don't understand why this place is a separate point of interest here. Really nothing special there. Restaurants are expensive. I ate more tasty food in BA at less touristic places. The only interesting thing here - is just to walk along the embankment and bridges.
Restored port area. Interesting expansion of the city onto former freight terminal. Some great new architecture, nice restaurants, and pleasant walks.
Walk and Eat. You can walk away throught to Puerto madero and than you can very special meat in the Cabana Las Lias restourant..but you must know a little a bit expensive
Great walking area. Nice views and great bars and restaurants. Safe and very good for jogging and roller skating Amazing sunsets.

Trendy and nice. This zone of the city has some beautiful architecture, recuperated buildings from the time when it was a port, also don't miss on the park and natural reserve further east.This zone has some good restaurants (overpriced, but good), and in summer feels hotter than the rest of the city :(

Puerto Maduro and Entertaining . They did a great job with this port renovation project. I really enjoyed the music car on top of the restaurant, parading sounds in a rather democratic way. The menu are a little pricey comparing to other places in town, but the atmosphere in unbeatable. Just do not convert, enjoy it.

Nice for food and stroling!. We came here in the evening when it was cooler. The area is beautiful with a lot of nice restaurants and even the oppurtunity to go on a gondole if you're feeling romantic!
Nice walk in the evening. A clean and serene port. Went there in the evening. The restaurants on the side add a charm to this place in the eveining. Must watch for anyone going to BsAs
Perfect for an afternoon coffee. Beautiful and although not necessarily very typically Argentinian, it is nonetheless a great place for a run or afternoon wonder.

A classy quite area to stay there. We stayed in Hilton in this area . I liked this area alot. Quite,peacful,you can walk around very clean. Have a coffee or snack. And at night you can have dinner in one of alot of restaurants,classy ones as well. All places are on the porto maderoIt is also very close to park there where all people are relaxing or playing sports.I really loved the place and if i go there again will difintly wish to stay there again.
Food. There are many restaurants along the waterfront to choose vertically any type of food you prefer -- of course meat, seafood.Etc.
New Years!. I spend new years eve here and I have a great time. They have lots of fireworks and the place is beautiful. There's many restaurants and a lot of people. I definitely have a great time.

What to do Christmas Day!. Should you find yourself in Buenos Aires on Christmas Day, almost everything closes down. However, our concierge suggested we go luncheon to LA CABANA in Puerto Madero. We took a taxi from our hotel and spent a wonderful and memorable few hours at this elegant restaurant. It was a bit pricey, but really worth it ! The restaurant was elegant and we sat on the verandah overlooking the canal.We ordered a wonderful vegetable soup, outstanding empanadas, a great salad, and delicious banana crepes for dessert. The service was impeccable - a Christmas day treat to remember!
Excellent choice of Restaurants . Spend time walking along this lovely new area. A nice escape from the bustle of the shopping streets. Fantastic range of quality restaurants to choose from.

Trendy cafés, but also the gate to the fantastic natural reserve. Puerto Madero has been cleaned up and set up for businesses and rich people, but it is also the way to enter one of the most wonderful places in town: the nature reserve on the river. It is free and it is the only way to get to see the Plate river.

A new modern city inside of BA!. Please go during the afternoon and visit the women bridge, it looks like a tango couple dancing. Also try to visit the natural reserve first during the sunset, so romantic and relaxed moment.

Nothing special. We would certainly not recommend this area when there are so many exciting things to do in Buenos Aries. You could certainly spend 10 days looking at the great attractions that are available and this unfortunately is not one of them

Excellent neighbourhood . This new neighbourhood in Buenos Aires is just perfect for a vibrant stay at Buenos Aires.The old dársenas and port are has been changed into a modern neighbourhood.There is at all times youngsters and public in general enjoying the area. Good for sports, skateboarding and roller-skating, it is not infrequent to see as well the family enjoying the mates and the view.Plenty of restaurants and eateries all over the place.Police presence is seen 24/7.There is nearby metro station ( walking distance) and buses are available as well.If you like shopping then you ll have to move to other areas as the main type of shops are restaurants.Very nice place to stay.

Lovely attractive area. Really enjoyed our visit to Puerto Madero. We ate at a small café and had empanadas. The day was beautiful and we were impressed with the new bridge and the sailing ship. There is also a wonderful art museum. Coleccion de Arte Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat. Definitely worth a visit. The café next door ,Croque Madame,has excellent coffee and desserts.

Good place for restaurants and a stroll. This old dock area has in recent years been restored and is now populated with restaurants on one side a blocks of expensive flats on the other. Some of the old cranes have been left in place to remind of its original purpose.

The place to stay and dine. Puerto Madero i( the harbour area ) s a very modern area of the city. Lots of quality hotels and restaurants. This is the area to stay. It even has its own police force giving it a very safe feel.Nearby ( walking distance ) is the Presidential Palace - affectionately known as the Pink Palace or Casa Rosada. The President only uses this building as an office; and resides elsewhere. The building itself looked in good repair, but the grounds on one side looked in a poor state - as shown in a photo here.The building has a balcony famous for Presidential speeches. In 1946 a working class hero President Peron - came to power, and made speeches here. He was accompanied by his wife Maria Eva Duarte. She was affectionately known a s Evita; and she became President after the death of her husband. Still today she is much loved and her pictures can be seen on the sides of buildings around the city.The balcony was also used in 1982 to announce war against the UK over the Falkland Islands. In front of the Palace is Plaza de Mayo ( May Square ). Argentina’s turbulent history records many events taking place here.  For example :- In the early 1980s - mothers protested to the military dictatorship about the disappearance of huge numbers of their children.  Many still unaccounted for today. In 2001 thousands of people gathered in the plaza & banged pots and pans to protest about the devaluation of their savings. The protests became violent and people were killed here. In 2012 - people gathered to protest about the suspicious death of their federal prosecutor, Alberto Nisman.Across the square is the Metropolitan Cathedral of the former Archbishop Jorge Mario Bergoglio, now better known as Pope Francis 1.  One of the most important religious buildings in Argentina. It has a sumptuous interior, and the high alter has amazing carvings & sculptures. There are lots of shrines and monuments throughout the building.Streets lead off the Plaza into the city centre, which is much like any city centre the world over - lots of shops and stores - with the obvious slant on Argentinian products and styles. Good for the shopaholics !Visit the cemetery to see the grave of Eva Peron - much loved and revered past President.. There is however, some dispute whether she is actually there, in the family Duarte tomb. Much of the cemetery has mausoleum’s to hold all family coffins & many can be viewed through the glass fronts of the buildings. Coffins in pristine condition - located on rack upon rack of the dead.Visit some poorer areas of the city - where people live in quite difficult conditions and eked out a living selling their wares. Many buildings in the area are brightly coloured.Argentina is famous for its “tango dancers”, and around the city are street entertainers, dressed to “tango”, and keen to have you pose with them for photos - which you were then charged for.  Another way to earn a peso and make a living.Take an organised day trip out into the country & visit an Estancia ( a farm ). Go horse riding on the Pampas with the Gauchos. An excellent & worthwhile trip - but it is a long day.

Restaurants galore. This historic area filled with old warehouses along the river port area has been converted to trendy restaurants and bars and living space. We ate dinner here one night and walked along the water enjoying seeing the local families out and about enjoying a nice evening. Worth a visit for lunch or dinner.

Fascinating area of old and new working well in harmony. Whether for a walk or an evening meal; a great place to people watch and sit outside near the water for a nice meal. Amazing modern architecture blended with late Victorian buildings that have been repurposed very effectively. Good presence by Federal Police. Watch for pick-picketers and avoid children soliciting. Do not walk back to your hotel from here -take a taxi -as its too near some shady areas i.e. Retiro station, bus exchange. The Colección Fortabat Art Museum is absolutely worth seeing -eclectic and world class.

Place Sophisticated and Nice. It is a beautiful place of historical value, it demonstrates how a deteriorated area can be very good use, has many good restaurants, has a sophisticated nightlife, has easy access and can be visited by day for a family outing.

Restaurants in Puerto Madero are overpriced, but the locale is very nice. Many people are advised to go to Puerto Madero for dinner. There is indeed an almost unending row of restaurants with very nice looking patio's and interiors. I looked at the menu's which pretty much are duplicates of each other. We had dinner here one night. It was okay food but now having been 3 days in BA and having been to other places in neighbourhoods, I can definitively say that Puerto Madera looks nice but that there are many more nicer places for much better value. Ask your hotel concierge and they will recommend places in your neighbourhood that will outshine the restaurants of Puerto Madera.

Well worth visiting. Well worth visiting this area of Buenos Aires particularly to visit the Ecological area. Recommend having an idea as to the layout of the ecological area as is very large and easy to get lost.

nice place to walk and eat. Very nice port day and night. We went during the day and it was sunny and hot. we walked on both side of the river and crossed the "Mujer Bridge" it is called the women bridge because it resembles the leg of a woman dancing the Tango, nice. You have to visit the "Frigata" an old war ship nicely kept (Ticket 50 cent).We also went at night for nice and supper in a very nice restaurant.

THIS IS ONE OF THE MAGICAL CORNERS OF THE CITY. During the day, but especisally at sunset and night, Puerto Madero, former decadent harbour area now richly gentrified, is an area of Bairesthat must be seen and lived. You'll never regret hours spent there, strolling, drinking, eating or simply sitting and watching.

Worth it if you are in the area. Not sure I would go out of my way just to visit the area but there are a lot of good restaurants (including Las Lilas and Osaka) as well as the Faena Hotel and the Woman's Bridge (Puente de la Mujer)

nothing special. We went here because we wanted to buy a ferry ticket to uruguay and so we had a walk around the pier. There are a lot of restaurants in this area but we didn't try any. Puente de la mujer is a famous spot but honestly I found nothing special in it. It's close to the plaza de mayo but i'd rather go to the plaza instead of this area...

Gastronomic area. This is the old port that has had a renaissance and is now a trendy area with offices, condos and a bunch of restaurants. Mostly Italian restaurants, some pricey others not so. We enjoyed Gato, reasonable prices, efficient service. The area is safe and a short walk from the Florida Street shopping area.

Meh.. Not a very well-maintained side of town, and overall not all that much to do. We regretted not spending our time elsewhere given all there is to see in the city. Unless you have a particular interest in this area I would probably skip it
Fun for New Years Eve. Had a great meal with a fun party atmosphere this past New Years Eve. There was a great fireworks display over the water and everyone had a great time.
Bland. This place is like any other bland upscale part of any city in the world. Nothing special here. Also everything is very expensive.
A must see part of BsAs. A very happening part of Buenos Aires! Tons of places to eat, right next to the river, and a lovely pedestrian bridge across the river! I place well worth a full day visit!

Great Sunset. Puerto Madero is gorgeous to visit at night. There are plenty of restaurants and terraces where you can watch people while enjoying tasty emapandas. Locals like to go jogging in the evening and there are benches where one can rest and admire the views.
Nice area of Buenos Aires. Portenos are very proud of this area. It is a nice place to visit but not a 'don't miss this' on your tour of Buenos Aires.

Charming neighborhood leads to great travel experience. A great way to explore environs of Buenos Aires is by Buquebus ferry which leaves from the ferry terminal at Puerto Maderos. For approximately $150 and an hour ride one-way across the Rio de la Plata, you can buy a round-trip ticket to Colonia del Sacramento, Uruguay and spend the day and get a cooling ride out on a great river on a hot day. Great views of Buenos Aires!

Best neighborhood to stay in. The Puerto Madero neighborhood is the cleanest neighborhood, very safe, is surrounded by water as its name would suggest, and has quite a number of excellent restaurants in all price ranges in easy walking distance. There is also a nature preserve nearby but for some reason it was always closed when I tried to go there, maybe I was there too early in the day.
interesting urban redevelopment. it's great to see the new development in the area and what facelift they've done to the area. Would visit and enjoy a walk there again
Charming. I love the place! The buildings, the restaurants, people from everywhere walking around it! Very charming, even with the high prices in Argentina

Great area with expensive restaurants. We really enjoyed walking around the port, with the calm waters, brick pathways and variety of restaurants that are in the area. Beware though, prices for food rival the best restaurants of NYC!

Cool spot. This is a really cool spot to take pictures. The bridge is gorgeous and Puerto madero is lined with restaurants. The people are friendly and it is a perfect site to see for couples and families.
Regeneration of an port area. Like many cities Buenos Aires is experiencing urban renewal. This historic port srea is being renewed and has new residential areas with open green space included.

Place to relax before your Cruise. We planned to arrive a day before we embarked on our cruise in order to relax from our lengthy trip from Vancouver BC. We enjoyed this area for the proximity to the cruise ship terminal as well as ease to walk to some nice restaurants. We especially enjoyed our meal this evening at Cabana Los Lilas,,,, great food and wonderful service!A 10-minute walk from our hotel - The Regal Pacific. Again another place we would recommend to stay,,, clean, comfortable and friendly,,,, found on Priceline

Must see in BA. Well, this is indeed a must see. Best time to go is late afternoon, so you can enjoy the day light view as well as the night lit ones. Walk, drink, eat and enjoy the promenade that many locals do on weekends.

New Year's Eve 2015 at Puerto Madero!. We spent the 2015 New Year's Eve at Puerto Madero. We somehow got a table for $2600 pesos! That was one of the cheapest places we could get into at Puerto Madero. The atmosphere in this place is great! Lot of couples and families, mostly tourists, enjoying a great evening.The fireworks were just great! And people danced on the street. There were free tango and samba lessons on the street at midnight which I really enjoyed!A great place to relax in the evenings in BA.

New Year's Eve 2015 at Puerto Madero!. We spent the 2015 New Year's Eve at Puerto Madero. We somehow got a table for $2600 pesos! That was one of the cheapest places we could get into at Puerto Madero. The atmosphere in this place is great! Lot of couples and families, mostly tourists, enjoying a great evening.The fireworks were just great! And people danced on the street. There were free tango and samba lessons on the street at midnight which I really enjoyed!A great place to relax in the evenings in BA.
Must See. We visited Puerto Madero in early November of 2015. A very interesting area with lots of nice architecture and nice places to eat. Very nice for strolling along.

Nice Place to dine and walk . I visited Puerto Madero in evening to dine at a nice Italian restaurant. Then in the morning I visited again to walk.There are many fancy restaurants here and a nice place to walk along the port.

Worth a visit. Puerto Madero is a large area. We walked along the promenade and just absorbed the area. Tall ships were docked and the area was busy. The area is known for new residential and commercial buildings and wide promenades with restaurants though most of them are fast food places.

A good example of city revitalization. You can see how a abandoned port was changed into walkway and high end condo/apartments and business area.There are also 2 sail boat as part of museum hosted by Arg navy.

NIce to drive through- but it lack character. Was on a driving tour and enjoyed the drive through this area lack the character of old BA. Nice old buildings that have been gentrified and wide avenues with nice high rises but the area lacks the vibrants gritty culture of BA. 30 minutes was plenty

Many Dining Options, Many Price Ranges. We ate in PM twice, both times satisfied with the experience. The best was on Christmas Day, when we were unsure what restaurants would be open everywhere else in the city. I would say we had the best dining experience of the entire trip that day. On both days, there were a lot of people walking around enjoying the friendly atmosphere.
Fancy neighborhood in Buenos Aires . I always go to Puerto Madero when I visit Buenos Aires mainly in summer. It has great restaurants and pubs with the best view in town.

A beautiful place to walking...and eating. Puerto Madero was rebuilding recently. It is a very nice place to walking in the afternoon and there are a lot of restaurants, parrila,The Ponte da Mulher is a amazing bridge.We ate at Rodízio, located there, and is a good restaurant, with parrila and seafood.

Night Life and More. The Puerto Madero area is teeming with night life, restaurants, and shops. It's also home to some of the most expensive real estate in the nation. A stroll along the river walk here is worth the time. You can't go wrong with spending time in this area.

European/Western Tourist Area. This a terrific little area that feels a bit like Europe or parts of the US - higher end restaurants, this is most assuredly NOT historic BA - but the very modern end of town. Definitely one of the more expensive areas. If you want to "go local" this might not be the place - though it is certainly close to many local attractions - a good starting point for destinations beyond.... This area feels VERY safe - and easy to wander about.

The standard place for all tourists to go to. This area was built to be a tourist trap and it has become one. It has all the right ingredients - waterfront, restaurants, security and all kinds of people attracted to all of the above.Basically if you're not sure where to go - this is your place. Keep in mind, that not all of BA is nice, safe and pretty, so following the mainstream maybe not a bad thing to do.
nice walk. nice walk and very sage you will see the famous bridge from there and a few restaurant $$$$ on each side
Great place to take a walk and choose a restaurant.. This area is good for talking a walk before dinner, there are many places for all budgets and food choices.
Quiet newer part of the city. This is a decent place for a nice long walk, jog or bike ride. It seems to be growing into a district to escape the pace of the rest of the city.
Great restaurant area, lovely to go for a walk along here. Lots of nice restaurants along the promenade, nice to walk around here. We felt safe walking around here.
Eat at SottoVocce. Great Italian restaurant situated in the Puerto Madero.Nice interesting walk along the water. Choice of at least fifty restaurants

The newest and cutest neighborhood. This relatively new neighborhood situated by the Rio de la Plata side, is known by it's very good restaurant classy walking raods, beautiful bridges and marina. It is a combination between the old and the modern. if you visit Buenos Aires it is a must.
The modern bit. Lively, modern and if you close your eyes almost shut and look northwards from the quay you could almost be in dock lands... But worth the time to visit
Decent . Decent spot. Not my favorite part of the trip. I enjoyed random streets better and found it less populated... Worth walking around tho.

Nice place to stroll along the river. Puerto Madero is basically a lot of restaurants and bars located along a canal. It's located about 5 mn walk from plaza de Mayo. There are a lot of good restaurants to choose from but they're a little bit Pricier than those in the city centre. The place is quite quiet during the week days but gets very lively in the evening. There are no public bathrooms!Not recommended on a rainy day - obviously.

Great place to walk around!. I spent a fair amount of a sunny day just walking around this area. Great private Art gallery (can't recall the name...sorry) at the far end and nice little restaurants all along the water way.

Lovely Relaxing area. The old dock area has now been completely redeveloped with eating establishments, etc lining to old area.Original Dock's and Warehouses were British Built and much of the hardware has logo's from Cardiff, and various other locations in UKNearby is the Constantera Reserve, which is good for walking around. The Lakes are a bit weed infested, which keeps getting cleaning up, but somehow the plastic bottles seem to get left. Pity.,
Plenty to see and do. Plenty of cafes, food outlets, weekend markets and a relaxed family atmosphere. Good for locals and visitors alike.
Great place! Great atmosphere!. What a great walking! Nice people just sitting, enjoying life, exercising, spending some great time! Very good restaurants, hard to pick one!!!

Great waterfront area. Like in many other cities, old dockyards are turned to great new living, office and dining facilities. I was there 20 years ago and there was almost nothing.Today, it's a beautiful, new built area with many high rises on the river/sea front. Nice and long promenades to walk, jog or cycle.Many cafes and restaurants around (on a pricier side).
A new part of town of the years 2000. It's a good place to go for a walk and to eat, but the architecture could be from any recently upgraded former harbour area such as Dublin or Hamburg.

Great walking and restaurant area.. The old historical shipping area of Buenos Aires. You can walk up and down both sides of the waterfront with old historic shipping cranes left as symbols of the past. There is also an amazing suspension bridge near the eastern end. Restaurants line both sides of the waterfront with all possibilities of restaurant cuisines and styles to fit every taste and pocket book.

Restaurants galore with fantastic views. There is a variety of restaurants for all tastes and pocketbooks as well as a promenade for strolling, admiring the contrast of views and during the day excess to museum/boats.
A nice walk but..... The port lacks atmosphere due to a lack of retailers, it is sad to see but that said it is still a lovely walk in the sun and there are some good eating options also
Pretty locks, marinas, and boats.. Nothing really notable, except the two classic ships that are now museums. A good amount of history on both ships, but all information is in spanish.
Must see and eat there. This side of the city has certainly an european touch.. you have access to boat rides or a boat exposition if you are lucky. I've eaten at different spots here, all are good!

Morning Stroll. We strolled down Puerto Madero before we go to the Pink house. It was a nice walk seeing two classic ships.
The stroll along puerto madero was a wake up walk where we came across quite some joggers, it was a sunny day and not too much people yet. So it was an enjoyable stroll.

Relaxing Place. This is a place to explore, use to be a major ware house shipping port, but since has been revamped in to flats, business, shopping, cafes and restaurants. There is tall ships to visit, lots of benches to sit and relax and check out the sites, and sip a cafe. this also close to the water front parks, casino, this is a spectacular at night, when the lights are on, a nice romantic place to visit with your significant other. a must visit when in Buenos Aires, we will definitely be going back here, when back in BA.
Very nice place. Very nice place, full of bars and restaurants. Nice to walk on the river banks. Do not miss it when you are in BA

At night it is spectacular . We concluded a private photography lesson at Puerto madero!!! The evening lights were amazing.a walk along the cobble stone board walk with buenos Aries across the water...spectacular!!!!

Great place to visit. This is a great place to walk around and visit great tall ships, and cross El Puente de la Mujer. Fantastic restaurants. Little bit expensive but the atmosphere is great and well worth it. Very safe to walk around.

A place to visit. If in Buenos Aires this is a place close to the shopping district worth spending a relaxed afternoon. Best time 5-7pm have a late lunch the go strolling.. This was an ugly port turned turisty. Lost of good restaurants but must look hard for the low prices... Great deal on a big piece of meat that you can share and do better with your $$$
Las Liljas. Out of anyone's fantasy this is an Argentinian barbecue very good steaksNice to sit outside by the harborBeef, beef, beef

Thirty years ago, there were only rats there!!!. La Boca was the first port of B.A. Where Puerto Madero is there was a very long pier but no real port. Ships had to unloaded by small boats. In the late 1880's Puerto Madero was partially inagurated. A complicated design, with four closed docks in line built on reclaimed land. At the beginning it worked well, but ships grew in size and the port became obsolete. When the third port of B.A. was inaugurated, Puerto Madero started to lose traffic and in the 1980's it was a cemetery for old ships. In the 90's the city of Buenos Aires and the real state developers teamed-up and a whole new neighborhood was created. It's residential, a business area, there's a yatch port, a museum ship, a beautiful pedestrian bridge, two embassies, a university, three hotels and many restaurants to chose from. People can walk 2.5 miles from from North to South and last but not least, all the way South there's a floating casino.The old warehouses were fully renovated, where we had silos and mills there are tall condominiums and...where on earth is the river? A mile away to the East.
Excellent restaurants and ambiance. This is a marvelous district to go and have a meal, drink a coffee, visit an art gallery or simply enjoy the sights.

Great walking. I walked through this area twice. If you go past the water you will find a lovely park and nice walking by the nature reserve. You can walk on the boardwalk outside of the reserve where there are food trucks. Or you can go into the reserve and hike the nature trails. Nice way to spend a day and not expensive.
Puerto Madero. After a day in of travel, we had a great meal at one of the many choices of restaurants in the Puerto Madero area. Lovely to walk around day or night.

Great restaurants - Perfect for an evening walk. This is where all the trendiest restaurants are located. Dinner is typically served much later here than in the State. Reservations are recommended. I highly suggest walking the bridges after dinner. Very romantic.

Vey nice. Nice place for a stroll although personally I don't think it should be number 2 as there are more beautiful parts of the city.They have done a great job thougg and there are lots of beautiful restaurants along the old docks.Certainly well worth a visit though
A nice place to visit. Puerto Madero has many types of restaurants, museums, boats, and other things to see and do. It is very convenient to p

Restaurants galore. A stroll to Puerto Madero reveals a very tasteful restoration of dockyards into a residential precinct lined with great eateries. Lots of variety and very pleasant to sit outside overlooking the docks.

great place for an evening stroll. Wide promenade that is perfect for an after (or before) dinner stroll. Or go on the weekends when the locals come out in droves. A lot of restaurants on one side, and tall towers on the other. Feels quite safe.
Very nice. A great place for a stroll, specially in the afternoon or night.You will find fine restaurants and stores while you walk by the channel.
Expensive and overrated. Shocked to see that a pizza was 325 pesos...really nothing to see here...! Feels very sterile and business like. id give it a miss.

Spend an evening here!. Get down from your vehicle and walk around the area. Cafes, restaurants, the old sailing naval ship, birds in the docks, gondola ride, young people dancing in groups to music, pubs...the whole lot
Walking Place. Really nice interesting place with a lot of restaurants and nice views, close to the river, visit the Women's Bridge.

Good for a walk, a coffee or a meal. I walked down Puerto Madero on a crisp afternoon for a coffee. The breeze is stronger here so bring a layer. It is like walking around a dock in multiple places in the US. There are places to eat, drink and while away the afternoon. Puerto Madero is built on landfill and the real-estate I have heard is the most expensive in the city. So this place might be considered "swank" by the locals but I wasn't terribly impressed.
Sarmiento Ship well worth the tour. We strolled along the Puerto Madero and enjoyed the tours ot the old ships. The Sarmiento was a highlight.

Each to their own...but not for me. Puerto Madero is where a friend of mine lives, and it says it all that it wasn't top of his list of places he recommended we visit.
