It is nice, and were I over here as an expat, I may well consider an apartment in this area, purely for comfort and familiarity. But that's not what I'm looking for on a holiday. So - if you are the kind who likes places that feel familiar, then head to this area pronto.
Pleasant enough.....but.... We had been told we had to visit Puerto Madero as it was very like London Docklands....I found it to be very dull, with restaurants overpriced and aimed at tourists!

A model of modernism and aesthetic sense. Great to go for a walk, to have a nice meal choosing between different restaurants while having a beautiful view over the modern architecture buildings, especially at sunset.
Lovely. Amazing place. A lot of restaurantes with a lot of variety. Espectacular views and buildings. Its the new part of the city
Modern BA. Not a particularly BA experience could have been anywhere in the modern world but some fantastic restaurants and great to walk about

Boring. Like the urban renewed docklands of Amsterdam, it's good for an hour tops. The restaurants are all hideously priced. Completely sterile environment, but I suppose better than decay. The place is DEAD after lunch.
Great area to walk and dine. This was a great area to walk and dine. Very clean and safe. Many restaurants to select from. Close to downtown BA but not as congested.

So what?. Boring urban renewal area along water (that's nice).
Restaurants are very overpriced. I looked at many menus.
So not Buenos Aires.
Walk along the water. Nice strolling place right in the city. Seeing the Puente del Mujere was worth the walk. Lots of restaurants.

Great place. Nice place to take a nice walk. It has nice restaurants that offer great food for you to have dinner or lunch. Great place for you to take your time and enjoy people walking by in a relaxing way. I recommend it

The new and modern BsAs. Nice area to walk around along the wharf, with many restaurants and shops. Its an area of new condos, office buildings and hotels, bars and night clubs.
Take a walk along the river and try one of the food stalls, order a choripan, local favorite.

The BA version of Canary Wharf. This is a must see for the Buenos Aires of the future. Fabulous skyscrapers and refurbished warehouses which have lots of cafes and restaurants to enjoy around the port area.
lovely area. Excellent for day or night walks...nice restaurants and bars around. The view of the river is nice. Restaurants located by the old boat-side are more classy!!!

Great area of town. This is the newest and trendy area of Buenos Aries. It's characterized by brand new high rise condos surrounding the 2nd port, which is now only used by local boaters. All of the local warehouses have been converted over the last 10 years into restaurants and shopping. It's a great stroll along both sides of the canal-like water area. Very pleasant place to visit - and to have nice meal. We were there late afternoon, but according to reports, all the restaurants stay open until 2am, so a good place for late night dinner. Like almost all of Buenos Aries, it "appears" to be extremely safe and comfortable.

Good place to stroll. A good place to spend a sunny day watching natives and tourists whatsoever to stroll, eat and drink. Impressive modern architecture with the skyscrapers and a gateway from the hustle and bustle of the city
Great place for a walk. Great place for a walk and go for a lunch or dinner. Lots of restaurants to choose from, Argentinian or Italian restaurants.
Ok. Nice waterfront area for a walk or stroll. Newish Area. Affluent. Trendy Restaurants. Good place for taking a breather between other tourist activities.
Amazing place!. Wonderful place to look and walk around and have a lunch or dinner. The place has amazing restaurants with great food :)

Creativee cluster and luxury district. Puerto Madero is new district in Buenos Aires full of luxury buildings with very high price apartments, factories renovated into the trendy lofts, full of business centres and so on. I did not give 5 points, because there was the abcence or even lack of galleries, theatre or music venues there. The worlds tendency is to establish creative cultural clusters in the urban industry zones.So don't miss that district in your tour.Sincerely Yours,Artur

Stroll along the port with your loved one. Great after dinner stroll or before if you choose with someone you love. Preferably at dusk or dark (which we prefer). Great to walk off a a meal before heading back to the Hotel. Great area as well with no graffiti or barred shops.

New, Clean and Nice. Puerto Madero is a much newer area of Buenos Aires and seems like a separate city unto itself. Unlike a lot of Buenos Aires it is clean and safe. Lots of good restaurants and shops and the walk along the waterfront packed with gourmet lunch wagons makes for a good midday break from sightseeing and other tourist activities.

Gastronomic Wonderland. If you're a foodie with the desire to walk and discover out of the way treasures, then this area is your gold mine. It could take you weeks to sample all the cafes, bars and restaurants in this district. Also the sights (buildings, monuments, parks and shops) can really stretch your budget. Great people watching along the docks on both sides. We felt very safe walking in this area. No peddlers or solicitors either.

The trendiest part of Buenos Aires. I have visited a few barrios on a short vacation to Buenos Aires and this part of the city is my favorite, by far. Clean, safe, trendy and offers an amazing selection of excellent restaurants and bars at different price ranges.
Nice stroll. On a sunny day or at night with the lights turned on, it is nice to stroll along the water. Restaurants are expensive there.
Like any American rehabilitated waterfront. This part of town reminds you of any rehabilitated waterfront in any American city. It's a nice area to walk, to jog, where to get a cup of coffee.
Peaceful area.... . Nice, and peaceful place to visit in Buenos Aires. You can find a museum boat here, or just sit and relax, having a beer...
Beautiful harbour with lots of restaurants. Beautiful harbour with lots of restaurants. Lots of people running, biking. The famous bridge and a nice place to have a glass of wine

The place to be: amazing transformation!. over 10 years of going to BsAs, it is amazing to see how this neighborhood was born and how it came along to become the best part of town, specially for business trips.Great hotels, best restaurants and walking access to the country's GDP (main firms, banks and govt).The transformation of abandoned warehouses to office and restaurants were a hit and inspirations for many dilapidated port areas around the globe. Mthis should be a model for Rio's ongoing revitalization projects.

Buquebus-Francisco. It was an awesome experience to go with the Francisco - a high speed ferry between BA and Montevideo-. The waiting place inside is nice and clean, the buffet is not expensive, air conditioning is well working. I loved it!;-)))

Nice place for a stroll. I got the sense that this relatively newly developed area is still finding its feet - it has a great design and the bridge itself is stunning. A lovely spot for an evening stroll and an ice cream. There are loads of restaurants lining either side of the water but if you plan on dining here be warned - according to my local friends the prices are much, much higher than you'd pay elsewhere in the city.
Very nice. A vrey nice place, recommendede for a visit at any time, lots of restaurants and Cafe's, great place for sports , jogging and running, very close to the "La Reserva".

Good place for some walks and talks. We reached here by subte, got till Retiro and then took a cab to the place that cost 35 pesos. Its a very good place especially if you own a DSLR camera. You can take wonderful photographs considering the sunset scenery and some skyscrapers. We missed the entry to the Ship museum because it operates between 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM. Overall its a worth visit if you have few hours to spare in your trip to Buenos Aires.

Worth A Visit But Not Special. This development is essentially a number of restaurants some of which are good. It has been there about twenty years and is looking a little tired but worth a visit if in BA
Lovely walk. Modern, contemporary flavor. Visit the Sarmiento fregata in the dock (Saturday is for free!); it pulls you back to the way a ship was run in the old times.
Beautiful area to walk and dine. Wonderful to see how they have fixed up this area of the city and well worth taking time to come down for a meal and a walk.
Great place to visit for a walk, have a drink or eat!. This is one of the newest and more beautiful settings around the water, is a must during day or night time when you visit Buenos Aires.

great please for a walks and eat-out!. this area is a great place to walk around, to have a food and just chill-out. offers a wide variety of different eateries, restaurants and also different sights. allocate some hours for visit and enjoy!

Delightful stroll along the river. This is not only a nice walk with lots of photo ops but it is a good stroll for foodies. Head to Puerto Madero if you're looking for a good up scale meal with a view.

Go with the tide. When in the mood for a nice walk, pick Puerto Madero - it will fascinate with its wonderful brick houses, with the greatness of Rio de la Plata, luxurious boats, and posh restaurants. Thinking of organizing a romantic dinner for two? Puerto Madero would definitely be the perfect location and you have where to pick your restaurant of choice. And you never know - you might meet Messi in the area :-)

Great Stroll Along Historic Waterfront. The Port is a dichotomy - old warehouses beautifully restored into mostly (too many??) top end restaurants backed by uber modern office buildings and apartments. There are numerous fabulous personal sailboats to envy and a couple of big old sailing ships (big!) that add to the quaintness of the experience. All in all worth a couple of hours strolling in a large circle around the docks (cross the bridges) and have a local beer or a copa de vino at one of the many outside cafes.

Babies Galore!. There is no better place to be between Sept-Dec if you want to see the most amazing sights of whales, sea lions and penguins tending to their new borns. We got unbelievably up close and personal with the amazing wild life and plan to go back. This is an amazing part of our planet.
Good place. Looks great, cool restaurants and close to la casa rosada so good place to start your day at. Mostly on sunny days.

BRING YOUR CAMERA AND WALKING SHOES. Puerto Madero is the right place for jogging and walking around. It is full of restaurants with different dining options. The must go places are: the Fortabat Museum, Puente de la Mujer, Freddo ice cream parlor, Sushi Club restaurant and the ecological reserve. If you are looking for the best Argentina beef, the right place to go is Cabana Las Lilas. The best time to go is the evening or night.

Nice place to walk with your friends or family. it's a nice place to spend a nice time in company or alone.I love to go for a drink in their coffee shops or small bars or go eat at the various and varied restaurant is in the area.

Excellent example of Port Redevelopment. Isolated from the noise of the rest of the city Puerto Madero contains magnificent new condominiums along with an amazing array of shops and restaurants, reused old factories turned into modern universities, hotels and business. I highly recommend a visit to this area, spend a day and even get to the real waterfront through some beautiful green space.

A nice escape from the city any time of day. I enjoy walking through PM to the nature reserve, and either sitting and reading or grabbing a snack at the Parillas near the water. PM might be a pricey neighborhood, but there are plenty of inexpensive options.

Great Restaurants. Puerto Madero has amazing seafood restaurants. Eating by the seaport is a very relaxing experience. And the best part is that after lunch you can just stroll around and enjoy the view.
Good place to walk . Less hustle and bustle than the main streets of the city. Worth a look but the restaurants looked a bit uninspiring. Lacks the character of some other areas.

All roads are leading to Puerto Madero.... Puerto Madero is the biggest concentration of great restaurants of all kinds in BsAs. Te renewed old port became one of the main city attraction, mainly for eating. Some of the best restaurants of BsAs are found in the area, for sure a safe place to spend the evening.

Perfect to meet friends. Perfect place to meet friends for a meal or a coffee
they did a nice work renewing the port area.
elegant place with several option in restaurants and cafeterias

Trendy area with lost of restaurants. The old port in Buenos Aires has been made into a nice pedestrian area with lots of restaurants and terraces. i enjoyed the atmosphere of the place. lots of people that jog , walk togheter or with the dogs. Loved it
On the water. Row of restaurants. You can take a walk on on the water and eat Argentinian excellent red meats.Try " luomo cut (beef tenderloin)
Nice area for a stroll. The port is an interesting area. There seems to be an attempt to revitalize it with numerous restaurants and sights in the area along the waterway.

Very nice place to stroll and eat. Puerto Madero has very nice restaurants to choose from. The place is also very nice to have a coffee or an ice cream. It is relatively expensive compared to one would pay at the center of town.

Puerto Madero continues to evolve. Puerto Madero has gotten a make over over the last few years. this is a great place for a long walk on sunny days. It's got a few shops, but above all it's got a lot of great restaurants. If you're looking for a nice place to have a meal and enjoy the view and after meal walk, Puerto Madero is the place to go!
I loved. Very romantic, awesome, beautiful, place loves every corner of Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires can not leave without visiting this place is very close to the city center
Beautiful moder Barrio. For everyone who came to Buenos aires and want to experience something different. After you see all historic area and need change go there. I love modern architecture

Quiet civilized modern neighborhood in BA. Walking distance from the hustle and bustle of old Buenos Aires, Puerto Madera is civilized with cafés, clean sidewalks shops, luxury hotels, fine dining among modern residential high rises.

Puerto Madero was very fun to visit, with lots of variety, park, vendors and views.. I would recommend the boardwalk and woman's bridge for photos. You can do a number of things: like visit the park, vendors, marina and enjoy the views.
Great pedestrian area! Fun at night!. We went to this area a few times during our trip--some in the day and some at night. It was a great, safe place to walk.
best part of the city. get some ice cream or coffee from starbucks, drive by skates or bike, pass the wonderful puente de la mujer, best place to spend sundays...
Awesome Place to Go. Puerto Madero is beautiful to walk around, filled with restaurnts and bars, it is full of options! Must go!

Interesting area to walk around. A newer area by BA standards,fun and interesting to walk around with bars and trendy places near the water, but more touristy and pricey then other parts of BA. If in the area, a nice place to stroll but not sure its a destination. There is a Hilton there and that actually would be a good location to see the city. since a close enough walk or taxi to most ares of the city for tourists.

A mix of old and new. The area has been revitalised with glass buildings, offices, some nice looking restaurants and bars. It was very busy with walkers, cyclists and even roller skaters. Some of the original cranes had been left on the dockside to look a bit arty. A new bridge, Puente de la Mujer, was pretty fancy and was supposed to resemble a couple dancing tango.
Impecable. Is worth it to spend the day. Great bars. Restaurantes and coffe shopsSafe place cleanDo not forget your camera and your sneakers

Dont get there too early. A mix of both trendy, noisy establishments, as well as some fine restaurants, focussed on Argentna's famous steak.Given their fondness for later evening meals, some of the locals refereed to themselves as Vampires. They don't like to feed until around 9 or 10 pm. This may explain the lack of people we saw around us and inside the establishments as wondered down the old red building side of Puerto Madero, across the bridge and then back down the other side.We saw many fine menus, but the lack of patrons put us off. If only we had known more about the local customs. Perhaps an afternoon nap may have held us in good stead for a late night meal.

Nice area. Beautiful area to walk around, relax and look out over the water, visit the old sailing ships, enjoy drinks, food or nightlife.
Safe in the evening.
Not the cheapest part of Buenos Aires though.
Puerto Madero. Take a refreshing walk along the docks, stop for a drink or lunch at one of the many riverside restaurants....a beautifully restored area and safe place to go.

Old and new, great to stroll along the water.. A sunny day helped but what a lovely spot to stroll. Dozens of places to eat, benches to sit on. Places for ice cream, some history as well as the new steel and glass corporate buildings on the other side of the bridge.

Nothing original. This is a rehabilitated dock area: old cranes, some ships, many, large brick buildings converted in fashionable, expensive international restaurants, small shops with tourists crap,.... it seems that all cities in the world have the same model. Not unpleasant, but with an air of "deja vu" and quite boring. Ok for a stroll though.
A pleasant place. A place with a lot of good restaurants, a wondeful view, built in an ancient harbour area. The buildings are restored but they keep original lines.

Puerto Madero. Puerto Madero is one of the most interesting places in Buenos Aires. You can eat in good (expensive) restaurants just in front of the Rio de la plata. You can go there just to walk and see the heart of Buenos Aires. You can take the BUQUEBUS to Uruguay in Puerto Madero.

Looks a bit neglected and has really expensive restaurants. It is probably nicer on a sunny day. We were there in 2009 and it was busier and more cared for. Now it feels a bit run down. However, we did go on a cloudy day so maybe there are more people there in the summer. The restaurants are unimpressive and very expensive. The views are nothing special. There is better use of waterfronts in other cities. We prefer to wander and eat in Palermo.

Very upscale restaurant district---don't miss it!. Puerto Madero used to be a run-down neglected part of town, a bunch of old customs warehouses and storage buildings that had not been used in many years. The a very entrepreneurial man bought the whole area for pennies on the dollar, tore down the old warehouses or greatly upgraded them, and leased the newly attractive space to expensive restaurants, including some of the finest in the city. These include Parolaccia, Katrine, and La Cabana de las Lilas. The ultra-luxurious Hotel Faena, the home of the famous Rojo Tango show, is also located in this area. All these restaurants offer a very nice view of the river, and many offer dining al fresco during the warm months. A VERY pleasant part of town.

great sightseeing and walking. lots of restaurants. Lots of restaurants and great sightseeing and walking. Plenty of bars and restaurants to choose from.and there are a couple of maritime museum ships that are very interesting. Admission is super cheap to the museums.

Nothing to see. Only worth going there as a pitstop or on the way to somewhere else. Restaurants are expensive and generic, and all you have to see is the dirty river with boats and building on the other side. We didn't go to the Natural Reserve though, maybe that could worth it.

Fun place to walk around - lots of shops and restaurants. Our group walked around Puerto Madero for an afternoon - stopped to have a drink and some snacks at a small stand in the middle. Worth taking a stroll through for sure.

Great modern area of the city - lots of places to eat. Modern development a short distance from the city centre. Loads of places to eat, a spectacular Santiago Calatrava footbridge and a visit to the sailing ship the Sarminento is very interesting (and ridiculously cheap at 5 pesos).
Trendy location for lunch & dinner. We went there for the second time. Plenty locations for lunch or dinner. Depending on your appetite, just puck the right restaurant!

A wonderful waterfront area to spend the afternoon and enjoy the many restaurants!. Nice to see that this once neglected barrio (docklands) has been converted to a nice hip and tready area with a variety of fabulous restaurants. Well worth spending an afternoon exploring the area and the Puente de la Mujer (Women's Bridge).

Spectacular urban renewal. This place is just lovely. great to wander and browse, lots of restaurants and wide walkways along the length of the old port basins. the old warehouses have been restored into top class and expensive apartments, added to with the building of very modern residential, retail and office blocks. it's airy, spacious, light-filled, fun, casual, elegant and feels very special. Do visit and wander at leisure, whether for an hour or half a day or stay at the hugely and huge Hilton. Brilliant urban regeneration, not just a renewal, but a place re-imagined and greatly enhanced.
Nice catwalk. Very nice to hang out in a sunny day, no matter the time of the year. Safety place and wih nice shops and restaurants (very good one: Faena Hotel and iCentral Market).
Nice restored port area. Restored port area of town, now full of restaurants. Active at night, with pubs and nice views. We visited the 1897 naval ship on permanent display.
Renovated waterfront. fancy dining, a popular spot for strolling lunch hour or evenings, take a rowing lesson! walking distance from downtown and the ecological reserve

Nice place for walks during the day and restaurants during the evenings. A very large selection of excellent restaurants for dinner. During the day is a nice place for walks along the water. Going south leads to the older section of the city.
Great views. This a trendy area. London docks alike. It is possible to find anything you are into. Cheap food, expensive. Prices are according to each place and the view is pretty cool.

Contrast to LaBoca. Puerto Madero is another port in Buenos Aires very different from LaBoca. When we were there during the day in October, it was really quite empty. We enjoyed seeing new buildings and the different bridges, especially the Woman's Bridge. The restaurants tended to be high end and more expensive than other areas in BA; we didn't try any of them because none of them had more than 2 or 3 tables in use, and we don't like to be in empty restaurants. It probably is a happening place at night, but we didn't happen to be there then. I would definitely go there when in BA if only to see the contrasts in architecture, etc.
Beautiful - but disappointing. Puerto Madero is the old Puerto de BsAs.A lot of expensive places to eat, but very nice and tasty! A good place for a walk or exercises.

Avoid it. Quite confused why locals kept telling us this was a must see in Buenos Aires. Very sterile and not at all what a tourist wants to see in Buenos Aires, a city filled with antique buildings, historic landmarks and culture.

Take a walk in Puerto Madero. I came here on my very last day in Buenos Aires and I would've regretted not visiting this lovely corner of this magical city.Definitely take a stroll around the port and sit in one of the cafes along side and enjoy people watching.

Just a row of expensive condominiums. Puerto Madero pretends to be the place where you MUST have your flat or apartment if you want to be included in Buenos Aires's upper class, but after a close look you'll realize that not even locals believe that, and prefere to live in boroughs like Recoleta or Palermo. This row of skycrapers with medium-to-expensive bars and restaurants on the first floors is a nice presentation picture and skyline of this huge city, but after a walk around the canal it just gets boring.

Not outstanding . The neighborhood is beautiful with some luxury hotel and good restaurant but nothing breathtaking. As a matter of fact prices don't reflect the usual quality of food of Buenos aires.
Lots of character. This area has a beautiful air about it and some very nice restaurants as well. It's a great place to spend at least an evening or two while youre in B.A.

Romantic walk in Buenos Aires!. Puerto madero is what it was the old port in buenos aires fully refurbished, beautified and restore to a glamorous look. It is consider the high class upper scale residential area in the, you may say, the "New Buenos Aires" full of outdoor cafes, bars and top quality restaurants. It is consider very safe to walk through here at night since it is well protected by the Argentine's Navy prefecture.
Beautiful . Walk in the end of the day gives us peace. Good energy. People use to go with friends, dogs, just for walk or see the view.

A must-see in Buenos Aires!. Great for a stroll along the port and to enjoy a fine dining experience at one of the very nice restaurants! We chose a seafood place, which was a nice break from all of the steak.

Weird, but very nice.. Its for sure the odd one out in the city, having been constructed last in buenos aires, this area or sky scrapers and fine dinning sure doesn't resemble the rest of the city. Great place to go during the day (and night) to eat and have a drink. (prepare the wallet though, not cheap).

Variety of eateries!. Lovely area with lots of restaurants on the river - varied prices and cuisines.
It was walkable back to our hotel (about 20 mins) and we also walked from the Flea Market (a sunday morning must!) to our lunch date

My Favorite place in BA. Puerto Madero is a wonderful boardwalk with lots of places to eat. They left all the old port machinery in place. There are old ships to explore for a minimal fee, the woman's bridge, the outdoor fitness area, PM Yacht club. This is also a short walk to Casa Rosa and the east end of Florida street. A great place to spend the afternoon and do lunch or dinner

Wonderful place, many bars and nightclubs. Prices are fare. Delicious restaurant and wines.. Wonderful place, many bars and nightclubs. Prices are fare. Delicious restaurant and wines. Great place to visit. Beautiful!

Wide selection of restaurants.. A really nice place by the side of quay.Uniquely designed for a value added tourism.If you are found of food and drinks, this place can leave you and your family mesmerized.Good location to take pictures.Best restaurant and sight seeing location within the city.This is quite lengthy ,so one should be bit selective on type of restaurant or food.TGIF !Cheers

Good when it is sunny. It could look dull for someone who expect to see magnificent views. Yet, views at night or sunny day could be nice. Walkig through the Puerto and having foods at a restaurant along the water looking at the view can be a nice way of spending an evening in BA.

Only in Europe. Only in Europe was possible to recycle an old harbor to make it a fashionable place with fancy restaurants and the most expensive apartments. The good taste is everywhere. The best location in the city, just in front of downtown Buenos Aires, but with the peace of a town. A must go place in a visit to this amazing City.

Built to be Trendy, but You can't Plan Trendy.... New and safe with expensive office and residential space, PM is fashioned to be the "gentrified" section of BA. But it is sterile. If you have ample time in BA, it is worth a walk (pleasant walk at that); or if you want a top quality eatery, some are there. But the whole thing is forced. The designers, however, did an excellent job preserving some of the old dock cranes and bridges.

New Buenos Aires. We visited three days ago and were very pleased with leasure stroll at the reaver walk. This place creates an image of modern and prosperous town of our times. There is a couple of museums to visit and good choice of cafe and restaurants although more expensive than in another parts of town.
me gusta puerto madero. estuve en puerta madero por una fiesta con mis amigos it was a great place to be at with my friends I felt safe and well taken care of
FOOD. It's a street facing the river with a lot of a restaurants, nothing special, for tourist, the prices I think are good and about the food: the one I went, it was a italian one it was nice.

Day out with friends and family. Went there with friends and family for a walk and to shop. A lot of the shops and vendors had some really nice things.
Looking for souvenirs which we couldn't find unfortunately.
Neat, interesting venue. The area is full of eating places and locals. On Sunday, the roller bladers were out in force. Photogenic, and vibey
Romantic Atmosphere. Clean, safe and very nice walk around area. Coo, fancy and popular restaurants, shops and hotels(hilton). Close to casa Rosada and easy to walk around!

the new cool area for living. Loads of tall , new glass condos, a river walk.... some mediocre restaurants on river walk.
Interesting to see..besides buildings not much stores or other.
Hotel Fiena worth going to especially the Tango show

Puerto Madero. Very modern, trendy, and posh. It's a great place to hit a nice restaurant or to catch a movie. If you visit Bs. As. you have to head that direction at least once.One decent restaurant at Puerto Madero is Siga la Vaca. It's a meat lover's fantasy. It's an all you can eat buffet, and you can walk right up to the barbecue and point out the meat you want. They eat late in Argentina, so if you show up before 9, you might be dining alone. If you show up after 10, there will be a wait--even on a week night.
excellent place to walk around. his is one of the safest place to walk around. Not only that there are many good restaurants that offer a variety of foods.
Dinner. Loads of restaurants all prices .walk by the river best time at night when the boats and cranes are lit up. Weekends very busy.
Good for a sunset walk on weekends. Great for a Sunday stroll at sunset, great views of the river and bridge. Very good for jogging and exercising outside. Restaurants are expensive here.

Puerto Madera - don't miss it!. This area is very modern with loads of restaurants, a long walk on either side if the dikes. There are 2 ship museums and it's a great place for people watching.The nature reserve is just behind the port area if you want a run or cycle.

Good way of walking around and spending some time. Excellent time spend there walking around.Nice view if you are a photographer.
You can find in the area lot of restaurants with Argentinian specific cuisine but also international ones.
Great area to stay. Close to the centre of town, but also quiet, with lots of restaurants and a huge park to walk/run/play in.

Do not stay in Puerto Madero. We stayed here this visit to Buenos Aires and regretted it the minute we arrived at the Hilton. It is modern, not at all the feel of the city, and difficult to get to by public transportation. Even the restaurants in the area were bad.

You did not go to Bs As if you did not paid a visit Puerto Madero.. You did not go to Buenos Aires if you did not visited this landmark. Puerto Madero is a great place for you to eat, shop, or just a walk around. It has an amazing view and it's a great place to take pictures. Definitely a must go.

Brunch anyone ?. Puerto Madero is not just an "attraction" ... it is a working port. There are very nice hotels and superb restaurants and the best place to have brunch on a Sunday is on Puerto Madero.
To go for a walk and maybe.... A couple of drinks, there are several restaurants and it is pretty secure, this area is especially very nice during the hot time.

Excellent to spend an afternoon . The first time we visited Puerto Madero was for dinner and it was during winter time so we couldn't really enjoy the whole of Puerto Madero. Thus second time we were there for lunch and after having lunch in one of the many restaurants there we walked throughout the Puerto, had ice cream and enjoy the weather. We spent there around 4 hours but could have been 6 easily, between the museums, coffee places, parks and restaurants Puerto Madero is the perfect place to spend a Saturday afternoon in Buenos Aires

Charming Esplanade. The old Buenos Aires docks have given way to a long esplanade where high end shops and nice restaurants abound. A perfect place yo have a coffee while you look out at the inner waterway, the marina or the bridge which is said to be stylistically shaped like a woman dancing the tango. This is a relaxed neighbourhood which is easy to walk around although seeing all of it would take some time. This is not an exciting place not does it have a lot of history. But it is great for a relaxing walk and a good meal.

A beautiful walk..... It was a bit cold..it is their winter until November, they told us. It was very crowded very lively, lots of photo ops, restaurants and shops and yes even McDonalds. Everyone was getting their ice cream cone. A ship to go aboard of and just enjoy the view....

Waterfront revitalization. I enjoyed the chance to see how the waterfront has been revitalized. There are lots of restaurants and one or two shops. I didn't have time to walk in the park but enjoyed the time I spent exploring the old docks. Puerto Madero makes a nice contrast to the rest of Buenos Aires.

Nothing special. Nice to see how the old area has been redone for families etc, but I wouldn't consider it an attraction worth going out of your way for. Looks like modern redevelopment in countless cities around the world. Nice for a pleasant stroll though if in the area.

Transformation done beautifully. Its incredible how this port area has been transformed into a great walking ans scenery, big buildings on one side and redecorated olds dicks into great restaurants and coffee shops, great place to walk around in a sunny day

Holiday . Puerto Madero is nice renovated area with brand new skyscrapers, nice cafes places etc. Nice area to spend half a day. We experienced good restaurants as well the ones which are not as good. Definitely worth to see it.

Very nice walk. Buenos Aires city council has done a great job in recovering this area. all is very nice and kept in excellent conditions, plenty of restaurant and bars to stop during your walk.The place seems safe at all hours and although we have been there in winter it is still nice to walk in the evening if the weather is good.

Nice place to visit. This is a nice place to go for a walk and get something to eat. There are a lot of upscale restaurants along the sidewalk, and the whole area is pretty. There are a lot of high-rent apartments in the area. At the north end of Puerto Madero is the place where the Buquebus ferry docks.

Newest neighborhood in Buenos Aires. It is extraordinary to see how an old port of Buenos Aires was redesign as a quite trending neighborhood. Excellent restaurants, nice people, great gardens, 5 stars hotels ( including the outstanding FAENA ! ). Puerto Madero is a MUST SEE when in BUE

The old customs wharehouse. The origin of puerto madero can be find in the old customs wharehouse of Buenos Aires port .This place was recycled in the 90s during the neoliberal government who sells to the private sector all of these public goods . These british warehouses were built in the begining of the twenty century and abandoned in the 70s.Today this fashion place is occupied by offices and restaurants. You as a tourist can find very good restaurants with accesible prices and also enjoy with the river view .
Good options for restaurants. Las Cabanas de Las Lilas is the best. Though, very expensive. Don't ever go to It Gatto pizzaria/restaurant, food is horrible.

If you spend a few days in B.A. this is a place to visit.. The newest neighbourhood in Buenos Aires, very close to the downtown area. If you're looking forward to eating great "parrillas" or International cuisine, this is an appropriate place while interesting view.On the other hand, and if you like jogging, cycling, or just enjoy a sunny day, there is an large natural reserve between the river and the city.Good Luck

Fun spot for food and walks. Great place, lots of restaurants located inside the old harbor side warehouses. Have a stroll before entering one of the many restaurants for lunch or dinner. A very trendy place which is also great for some people watching.

Awesome place to relax. Puerto Madero is one of the wealthiest areas in BA. Its very very nice, you not only have parks nearby, you also have restaurants, coffee shops and stores of different kinds, cinema, casino all over the area. You can walk, jog o run if you want alonside the river, or if you prefer you can sit down and read a book while you see the river in front of you. You will see a lot of people during the daytime so its a pretty safe area all the time, specially during the daytime.You have a lot of places to go and eat or have a coffee. There is also a casino, called "El casino flotante", and its a boat that is a casino. If you wanna go to a restaurant in Puerto Madero, you have a couple of good choices, but everything is way more expensive because of the area. So you can go to another restaurant and eat better and cheaper.You can go also to the cinema, drink mate sitting in a park bench or go to the casino. I think its a must for all the travellers that are coming for the first time to visit BA.

Great place to visit, you can't skip it. Around 15 to 20 blocks of a canal with boats, bridges, historic structures and building, great restaurants with a lot of options to choose from. Don't skip this visit at Buenos Aires!There are various hotels walking distance, a Hilton right at the zone, a Sheraton few blocks walking distance, a Park Tower hotel. You can plan your stay around this location and still see a lot more! Just do "near me" on trip advisor and you'll for sure enjoy your stay.
Excelent place to visit and eat. This place is the one that will should visit qhen go to Buenos Aires. There is excelent option to eat and have a good dinner and drink wine
Nice for walks and restaurants. I had dinner at an Italian restaurant and afterwards a nice walk in the dark. It felt quite safe due to police presence and the views are great.

nice place to go for a walk. the place is new, white and clean, very in contradition with the colored and messy Buenos Aires. it fits in the city though with its famous bridge and the restaurants, tango places and tall buildings.
Business away from city noise.... Working in the quarter, one can enjoy low noise environment. Some wind may occur due to proximity yo river.

Visited while importing a car.. We visited here often while importing our car. Again many of the building as run down and shabby.I hope you dont see it because your importing a car, its a horrible experience.

Beautiful area with excellent restaurants.. This area has been rebuilt and I could swear that I was in Dublin with the bridge dedicated to women, and the beautiful riverfront. The restaurants in this area are excellent!! Not a bad choice to be made, here!

Great landscape to walk during the day and night!. The city has done a great job on renewing the port area in the 90s and it is now a great landscape for travelers to enjoy while walking whether it is daytime or at night. You will find great restaurants, fine hotels and bars to spend time in groups or couples. From Puerto Madero you can access San Telmo or the city center after a 30min walk.
Nice but not spectalular. There are old port, new buildings and some wetland with birds nearby, but that was nothing special as I was told.

most magical view. Buenos Aires is beautiful and I feel that Puerto Madero on a suitable evening is the most magical place to be be in this beautiful city. On the evening we visited, the colours on the horizon were many and vivid and the womens bridge was absolutely captivating. There is ample room to walk and laze with great quality restaurants around. Every city needs a place like this...

Fantastic. This place is amazing you can find dozen and dozen of nice restaurants the wine are superb you have a lot of variety the people is nice not the kindest but is you pay you will be well serve, they need work how to treat foreign people I always feel they are trying to scams people that don't speak spanish
Walks and archtecture.. What a lovely place. Full of restaurants, bars, ice cream shops. Go for a walk, take pictures and enjoy the architecture of Puente de la Mujer. What a beautiful view.

Recovered Warehouse District, Great for Pedestrians. Such a wonderful area for walking around and really highlights the active community in Buenos Aires. This is an old warehouse district on the waterfront that has been recovered to showcase great architecture and is full of good restaurants and bars. I walked around here by myself to explore the area and felt perfectly safe. It is a bit touristy, but there were a few locals going on runs or roller blading. There are loft apartments in the area, which draws a crowd of young professionals.

Great walk after meetings or at lunch. Love Puerto, you can run before or after work, simply walk during lunch... Stop for a meal, ice cream, alfajores or Starbucks ( free-Wi-Fi.) The scenario is very dramatic, at the same time modern with old and new buildings, all lights and boats... Also GREAT for business/couples/family dinner. Variety of restaurants specialized in Argentinian bbq, seafood, Italian, Peruvian, Sushi... You name it. Reservation is a good idea, places can get pretty busy.

Everything pretty but no trash bins available. This is a very exclusive area of the city of Buenos Aires. Safe to walk, day or night (very important nowadays), well maintained, with modern buildings and restaurants, art attractions such as the Fortabat private collection or the newest cultural center Kirchner.Natural reserve is behind, I don't like it but you can visit to have an idea.Restaurants are expensive and touristy in general, so it is not the best neighborhood to eat, but some exceptions that I like are Happening for meat and La Rosa Náutica for fish and Peruvian, that are still expensive but worth it.I go to skate there and there is place for people to walk in a comfortable way, not crowded. I know that it is clean already, but I had to walk up to the avenue to throw a piece of paper, no trash bins on the way.You can easily get here by buses that stop on Alem Av., or subway line B last stop Alem, and if you have time, the Pink House and Mayo square are just blocks away. You can do both attractions in one afternoon.
Modern Buenos Aires. Nice and modern. A great place to walk and spend the evening. Grab some dinner, a drink or a gelato.

Modern port, nice restaurants. Definitely a place to see. Renovated port and a lot of sophisticated restaurants. It is very touristic therefore expensive, you can also see a lot of rich locals having their dinners there. In my opinion you could get more quality for those prices.

Relax and enjoy the atmosphere of Puerto Madero. It is always nice to sit for a beer and check on the people in Puerto Madero. I like to walk both sidewalks and enjoy the "happy hour" ... it can be crowded sometimes but it is always fun to watch how locals and foreigners behave.
Nice place for a walk.. This is a great place to take a walk. It's pretty and the air is fresh. There are many restaurants to choose from. Very safe area.
Go and see and eat. Go wander around, have some food, shop a little and enjoy the outdoors. It is very walker friendly unlike some other parts of the city.

excellent place to stay. We stayed at the HIlton and this place was wonderful. Excellent restaurants close by. The ferry station was within walking distance to go to Monte Video or Colonia. The tourist bus stop is also very closeby. But the bus is not very useful. All of a sudden they cancel the bus service. Excellent restaurants. Pretty much you can walk to some of the attractions.

Fancy commercial redevelopment of the old warehouse and port district: restaurants, cafes and apartments. Puerto Madero is the name for the redevelopment of a several mile long stretch of the old warehouse and port strip of Buenos Aires. The area has now been developed into a complex of fancy and quite expensive cafes, restaurants and apartment complexes. The area reminds me of similar developments in London (Canary Wharf) and Melbourne (Southbank). This is still a good area to walk and browse and its generally a very safe place.

A popular spot for the old port of Buenos Aires and where the Women's Bridge is located. This is a very popular tourist spot in Buenos Aires where you can see both the old and the new. Many modern architectures and high rises on one side and old brick buildings remodeled on the other. 2 floating museums Corvette Uruguay and Frigate Presidente Sarmiento stationed near the river banks, a small fee admission is required for each. The famous Women's Bridge is also in sight when you come to the waterfront. A promenade is available on both sides of the river banks. Catholic University of Argentina is also on the river banks.

Beautiful, safe, many restaurants. If you want a nice three mile stretch near the water, this is it. Many good restaurants and plenty of room for jogging and walking. Lots of security and patrolled and safe and by the sleek Hilton. We tried five restaurants in this area and loved all of them. Very pretty at night.

New And Growing In Buenos Aires. A renovated shipping yard, this part of town is Buenos Aires' new up and coming district. It's a great place to run or bike or even roller blade along the old docks and mooring points beside the retired shipping channels. The restaurants are varied and hotels are new and fresh in this beautiful old capital. The only drawback is that if you stay here you will need to take a cab to reach any location downtown.

A nostalgic view of Buenos Aires.. As a seaman I have a great interest on old ports, ships etc. puerto madero is the old port of Buenos Aires. Nowadays it is a great place to walk, to dinner, to have fun as the old warehouses have been transformed into bars, restaurants and cafes.

Jogging in Buenos Aires - 2. Puerto Madero, the Docks route. Last week I reported to you on a jogging trail in Recoleta / Palermo along the woods of Palermo “Bosques de Palermo”. I would like in this report to talk about Jogging in “Puerto Madero”. Puerto Madero is a new, elegant and very modern Barrio of Buenos Aires. There are several jogging options, I like two of them. One is relatively short while the other is long. I will review the short route in this note, the one I call the “docks route”. As I did in my earlier review, I will also mention the points of interest you will see along the route.If you are staying in Puerto Madero, you can join this route at any point suitable for you, as described below. If you are coming from somewhere else in town to jog in Puerto Madero, I would recommend you enter Puerto Madero via “Avenida Córdoba” which turns into “Avenida Cecilia Grierson” in Puerto Madero or via “Avenida Belgrano” which turns into “Avenida Azucena Villaflor” in Puerto Madero. These two entrances allow you to easily join the docks jogging route. You will need your map now to mark the route.This is just over 4 km route around the first three of Puerto Madero docks. One can start at any point, but let us assume you are coming via “Avenida Córdoba” so you start at its intersection with “Avenida Alicia Moreau de Justo”. Run south alongside the docks on “Juana Manuela Gorriti” street. You will see on your right the famous grill house “Sottovoce” and just before you come to the end of the first dock there is another good grill house “Cabaña Las Lilas”. Continue south along the second dock and about half way through it you will see the “Museo Fragata Sarmiento” which is worth visiting on another day. Along the second dock you will continue to see restaurants, but perhaps of a less caliber than the two I mentioned above. As you go from the second to the third dock, you will cross “Avenida Belgrano” which would be your starting point if you entered Puerto Madero via “Avenida Belgrano”. As you run along the third dock the “Catholic university of Buenos Aires” will be on your right. The third dock finishes at “Avenida Estados Unidos” or “Avenida Rosario Vera Peñaloza” in Puerto Madero and that is where you cross the docks and turn around running north on “Pierina Dealessi” street . On that side is the “Hotel Madero” which is very close to the intersection of “Avenida Rosario Vera Peñaloza” and “Pierina Dealessi” street. If you are staying at that hotel, you would start the route there. As you finish the third dock and cross “Avenida Azucena Villaflor”, look to the right and see the exclusive “Torres Le Parc” apartment building towers. If you are following the news, you will recognize it as the place where Prosecutor “Alberto Nisman” was found dead earlier this year. As you reach about half way through this dock, you will see the famous bridge “Puente de la Mujer” which has the shape of a lady’s figure. You would have seen the bridge on your way south, but the figure of the lady is better seen from this side. As you finish the second dock, you will see the Hilton Hotel, Buenos Aires on your right side. [This would be your starting point on this route if you are staying at the Hilton]. Continue north along the first dock and about half way through it, you will see on the left [in the canal] the Buenos Aires Yacht club. You will have just passed the Yacht club admin building on your right. There will also be many elegant cafés and small restaurants on your right. As you approach the end of the first dock you will notice on your right a huge futuristic and very elegant building. This is the museum “Colección de Arte Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat”, which should definitely be on your list of places to see in Buenos Aires, if you have not done so yet. [I have reported earlier on this museum]. This brings you to the end of this route. Please note that you will have to go a bit further north to reach “Avenida Cecilia Grierson” to cross back to the other side of the docks and exit Puerto Madero [at Avenida Córdoba] or continue to reach the “Avenida Belgrano” exit or to go back to the hotels.You could, if you wish to make the loop a little longer by continuing further south along the fourth dock. If you do, I would recommend that at the end of the fourth dock you turn back on the same side of the dock and then cross at the bottom of the third dock as in the original route. It is a bit difficult to cross to the other side of the docks at the end of the fourth dock. If you wish to run a longer route still, please see my next report that will follow in a few days. By the way, as Puerto Madero is quite new, you will notice that there are only few mature trees, and hence little shade, along this route. My advice therefore is to run as early as you can and to start the run, as described above, on the west side of the docks. You may also have noticed that the streets I mentioned are named after ladies. This is because all Puerto Madero streets are named after famous Argentine ladies. Enjoy your run!

Nicely revitalized walking area filled with restaurants. It is accessible by metro and a ncie place for a long stroll along the river. You can also enjoy the beauty of the Calatraba designed bridge. This is an area that was filled with warehouses and other port facilities but had been beautifully transformed into a modern waterfront residential and commercial area.

Safe and very nice.. Puerto Madero used to be the old port.It was renewed and today is one of the most expensive places in Buenos Aires, if not the most.It is a very nice area during the day and also at night. The only problem i find is that all restaurants in the area are pretty expensive.It is definetely a must but i suggest having dinner/lunch somewhere else if your budget is tight.You have many green spaces to seat at have a drink or a sandwich. Chilled and nice.
Beautiful modern buildings.. Saw while on the city bus tour. This area is full of recently constructed tall glass sky scrapers. It's the place to live these days, but you'll need a wad to do so.

The Neighbourhood to walk and dine. This is the port of Buenos Aires, the safest place if you want to have a walk and enjoy of the view of the river and the city.
There'r many options to dine around some of them with good quality, beware many of this restaurants are bad and expensive, is better to read reviews before making any reservation.
Contemporary dock. Great restaurants, nice dock with the iconic bridge as background. This is an emblem of he modern Buenos Aires, definetly a must if you visit this city.
A fresh air in BAS. A fresh air in BAS, the place is really nice, with a lot or restaurants with a great variety of prices.

Ok - dont got to Argenttina just for a Vacation. Buenos Aries for me as a whole was a little disappointing. I didn't get the feel of vibrant culture that I was expecting and Puerto Madero was no different. The area has everything it needs to bee very sleek but isn't.

Reminded me of Seaport / Design District in Boston. Really great spot to walk along with cool restaurants and nice buildings. I spent most of my life in Boston and it reminds me of the seaport / design district. You can just about walk to Caminito from here if you have time and are up for a longer stroll.
Average Port, Nice Dining Options. The port was unimpressive, but there were several nice dining options lining the waterway. We had nice steak and wine.

Beautiful area. Great place, lot's of restaurants. Nice bridge and surrounding areas.
Was there in the day but looked like would have been a good spot for the evening also.
Gourmet Food begins here....... For block after block, one is treated to a food carnival. Each restaurant vies with the another to appease appetites of all kinds and from all continents.

Nice Walk. I ended up at Puerto Madero while looking for the Buque Bus terminal. After missing my ferry I decided to walk around and it is a very nice walk. The buildings are obviously originals from time pat but have been beautifully updated without losing their authenticity. The "compass bridge' was a highlight for me and I enjoyed posing on it along a lot of people who felt the same. It has a very modern feel compared to the other parts of BA I visited so depending on what you like it may or may not appeal to you. The restaurants did seem very upscale and pricey so I would not necessarily eat here but for a walk along the water with nice views I would recommend Puerto Madero.

Regenerated port area. Interesting regenerated port area, much like in London, NYC.etc. Some good restaurants and other chains. Open space and water makes a welcome break from the congested dusty streets of BA. (I was here in winter)

Waterside broadwalk with nice parks and an abundance of cafes and restaurants. This is one of the new residential areas of Buenos Aires, and seems to cater to wealthier people who want to have the parks and views they could not get in Recoleta. It has many parks and on a nice day walking the boardwalk and watching the boats is a great way to spend and afternoon. The area is also lined with great restaurants and cafes and has a nice museum at the end. There are several excellent restaurants by the water that are close by the downtown area.

Must visit. Great wine and food for all, sat outside and watched the world go by as we wined and dined. It was close to a perfect moment. The food was outstanding. All fresh and tasty. Very well prepared. The wine list is robust. And good choices abound along the entire $ spectrum. Service was delightful. Helpful. They just let us sit and savor the expereince. And the cost was ridiculously reasonable ... given the exchange rate de jour.Wish I was not a continent away ... or I would be back in a flash.

Great Restaurants. Nice area located along former naval base in Buenos Aires. Great scenery and restaurants to visits. One of my fav Italian restaurants is located there...called Marcelo and it's definitely worth the visit. Highly secured area as well so you feel pretty safe perusing the area.

Buenos Aires' old Port and a new upscale neighborhood!. It is amazing to see, after a few years, how much the renovation efforts for the area of Buenos Aires' old port - the famous "Puerto Madero" - have changed and upscaled this whole neighborhood! At the same time, I must agree that the newly developed area looks much more like another town, almost disconnected of the Buenos Aires that we ever knew. The old warehouses are today occupied by restaurants, bars and hotels. Skyscrapers are seen here and there. Near it, at just a walking distance, a new museum housing the admirable "Colección de Arte Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat". Visit the museum and have lunch at one of the very many restaurants of Puerto Madero. But, and there is always a but, don't expect to find high gastronomy. Puerto Madero's restaurants are much more on the touristic side. Bon Appétit!
Modern part of town. Lovely place to go for a stroll and eye up the busy restaurants along the river. Easy to find somewhere busy and safe to walk around at night also.

Nice to walk around, but not for heels ;-). The old docks are great for walking around, and the area is fairly clean and has a distinct personality with the old warehouse buildings lining the streets and the occasional, colourful mechnical cranes painted yellow and orange. The planked bridge walkways and cobblestones immediately along the water are a bit challenging for heels, though!

Some Good Cuisine. This is a port like most, but there is also some decent cuisine to be enjoyed here. Look for the restaurant that looks like the doors belong on a horse stable. I can't remember the name, but the food was great.

Nice. An excellent place to go for a walking, have a break and have dinner. Really beautiful and with a nice ambiance. Id say that it could be more attractions as diferent types of restaurants and snack bars for the day and some entertainment staff and museums... but I really like this place and ill recommended it for sure

Keep calm and walk along the river!. It's calm and beautiful to walk around the river.You can go to many restaurants that exist in the margin of the river or you can just walk between the streets and bridges (like the "Woman Bridge", a simbol of Puerto Madero)!

So-so. Puerto Madero was not one of my highlights in Buenos. It's glitz, it's overpriced, many of the restaurants are overpriced, it's a be seen kind of place without soul. Still it's worth going to see what it is about and to try one or 2 places, maybe for drink or starter only, to get the feel. Instead of 3 stars I would have given 2.5 if that option was possible.
not at all buenos aires. Buenos Aires is an amazing city, but this neighborhood felt like another world and not at all authentic. I would skip it if you have limited time.
Nice and Beautiful. Very beautiful both during the day and at night. Reminds me of Battery Park in NYC. Bull dog bar/restaurant is pretty good.

Must visit in Buenos Aires. Here you can see where all the black money is spent in Argentina. It is a must visit for a foreigner coming to BA. You will see first hand the rich/poor difference in Argentina's society.

Nice area, but feels disconnected from city. My husband had a business trip to Buenos Aires, and he was staying in the Hilton in Puerto Madero. If we were traveling on our own, we would have been in a hostel or B&B. The Hilton was wonderful, but we would never pay that much on our own for a hotel. The Puerto Madero neighborhood is nice and much cleaner than the old city. There are many visible law enforcement officers since the Coast Guard also patrols this area, and I felt comfortable walking around at night. The area feels very disconnected from the rest of the city though. It's obvious that it's a business district, but the areas along the canal remained active well in to the evening hours. But we are also in the first week of winter holidays, or so I'm told. If you are looking for quaint traditional Latin America vibe, this isn't it. But it is safe and clean and within walking distance to the city center. I'd recommend a cab if you are going to San Telmo or Palermo though.

Very Tourist friendly area. Puerto Madero is great for visitors to BsAs. It has some of the best restaurants and views of the old bonding warehouse zone of old BsAs. Great ambiance and a nice introduction for new visitors

Great neighborhood in BA. This is a fun place to visit and a little bit of a "break" from the hustle and bustle of downtown BA. Great restaurants all over Puerto Madero and shopping is not far away. Great walking paths and plenty to see and do. Highly recommend as part of a BA holiday.
a must go in buenos aires.. a must go in buenos aires.its all renewed and modern. lots of restaurants. there is a lot to walk there.

Great adaptive reuse of buildings and port. This is a great neighborhood to walk around, people watch and grab a bite to eat. It is somewhat touristy, but the old port buildings are beautiful and the old industrial canal and bridges give it a great ambiance.
Nice view. And tons of options to grab something to eat! Nice place! Most restaurants offer a menu with lunch, drink and dessert around 100 - 130 pesos.
A bit of everything neighborhood.. Great many restaurants and plenty people watching. Upscale neighborhood with a little of everything next to the river.
Good walking location . Lively (especially considering it was winter) place. Loads of restaurants. Good spot to go for a walk and just investigate BA.

Nice and peaceful. Quiet and restaurants on both sides of the river. Some relatively expensive. We had made time to take a seat at Mostaza for coffee. Is quite relaxing and just let time flow by. Personally preferred evenings when the sun sets and is so pretty!

Hummmm.... The opposite of La Boca, Puerto Madero is one of the most rich neighborhood. Like this, there are public and private security all the time. So you can take a good walk around, until reach the Nature Reserve. There is a museum ship on the harbour with lots of things to see by a symbolic price. As a rich place, the restaurants are expensives too. By the way, if you have a guide, he/she can take you to very special places to taste regional food as empanadas for a special good price.
Must visit. So many places to see around, harbour bridge, great restaurantes, etc etc. Loved the ferry ride around harbour. Its cheap and fun. Must visit place in BA

I'm the exception. Let me clear about this review, is VERY subjective. Puerto Madero is one of the high end places in Buenos Aires, populated by celebrities and well off people. For ME is average because in a city known for its personality Puerto Madero is indistinct you could be anywhere in the world in a very nice boardwalk full of coffee shops and nice places to eat but not necessarily in Buenos Aires.
Beautiful scenery. It's a beautiful place to visit. It's filled with restaurants that actually stay open all day long. Try to go there when it's sunny...that's the best way to appreciate its beauty.

Excellent. Well design open floor lobby. Great services in general. Friendly staff. Convenient restaurant located at lobby with great food. Should try empanadas. "Finger leaking"Hotel linen top of the line properly finished clean fresh.Executive room has all amenities you may requireBeside (location-location-location) is located along the river with all kinds of restaurants available.Spa is also great as well as fitness center.I would consider this Hilton not only for traveling but also for vacation. "Is time to Tango"

Don't leave BA without visiting Puerto Madero. Puerto Madero is a very modern and hip barrio (neighborhood) of Buenos Aires (BA). Not a far walk from many touristy areas and important historical buildings as well. If you can stay here while in BA, you will enjoy your vacation as many must-see areas are within a walking distance or a quick cab drive.Even if you don't care for modern high rise buildings, you will like the great restaurants this area has to offer. We had our best meal in BA here at Cabana Villegas. If food and modern architecture is not your thing, I will let you in on what seems to be a little mentioned secret. At night, and probably only on weekends, groups of young and middle aged men and women gather and dance their socks off to music played by impromptu DJs in very casual water-side "dance clubs". I am talking open-air and open to the public dance gatherings on the ultra wide sidewalk. You can stand and watch or join the action. We saw two such groups on Friday night. It seems like some of them got there by bus. There are also several fast food trucks parked by the water. A big contrast to the fine dining you find just two blocks west. If you want to see and experience a more laid back area right next to million dollar apartments, this was, for sure, a very unique experience for us. To find them, keep on walking Eastwards until you reach the river's edge (not the man made rectangular water areas. I will try to attach a video I took of one of the dancing groups. When they played faster and more popular songs, there were at least a 100 people dancing. Fun and very different.
Very nice restaurants and neighborhood. Is very nice to go and have dinner in a fancy restaurant. I'll fully recommend going to this neighborhood.
Nice place to walk. Madero harbour gives a good opportunity to have a pleasant walk along the river and to visit very good restaurants. The zone is modern and has interesting views of the city.

New and Hip and on the water. I went to Puerto Madero when the sun was setting because I wanted to check out the place. Its the new rich hip area of Buenos Aires. I will say while walking along the boardwalk there were nice restaurants and music playing and looks like a good time. Take stroll along the boardwalk and across the bridge.
Gastronomic. Great place do have a lunch or Dinner or eat any things, Have many good restaurant, and bucolic view to river... Really enjoyable place do seat and have a drink....

A very pleasant stroll. This was a nice place to take an afternoon stroll - there was a 5K race going on, roller skaters, boats and bridges, and lots of restaurants for lunch and some fantastic coffee. What we didn't like is that it looked like it could have been "anywhere" - the US, Europe, Argentina. Nice but nondescript. Great place (picture-esque, safe, and wide open with the canal running through the middle) to stroll on a sunny day.

Walk and have lunch. Rebuilt old port area, very pedestrian friendly, many new, trendy restaurants and street food, too. Very nicely restored wetlands and marshes with walks of various lengths to view wildlife and be far removed from city life.
Amazing new look on an old area. Interesting re-furbished area that only a few years before looked so dodgy it wasn't even worth going briefly. Now it is modern and beautiful with parks and cafes.

MODERN AND FANCY. This is a very safe neighbourhood, full of tall buildings and hotels. It is very nice to visit by car and drag around. You will find some food stores and coffee shops. Sundays can be crowded, very crowded and during week days, intense traffic must be considered
You must to visit. This is a new neighborwood in the old pier of Buenos Aires.Beatiful views, restaurant, the ost safe zone in the cuty.

Modern area. It's a new neighborhood, walking distance from the main train station or subway. It is a very beautiful area, with nice little cafeterias and restaurants. Ideal for spending an afternoon walking or just sitting down for a coffee enjoying the view of the river and the new gondolas which are available to navigate. There is also an art museum which can be visited there, the Fortabat Museum.
New In Buenos Aires. It is the newest neiborhood in Buenos Aires, Its the best face of BUenos Aires, interesting place for have a lunc or dinner.

A interesting Place. I liked to visit this place beacuse there are many tourist atractions , this is visited by many tourost from different tourists , i went to Puerto Madero with my firneds to know this beautiful place .

Must see in Buenos Aires - and eat very good. Interesting experience to see how it is possible to renovate a decaying port area on a tourist gourmet center. Inspired by the model of Barcelona, Puerto Madero is a very good example of reconstruction and improvement of port old buildings that turned into beautiful restaurants.Although there are places to visit, the main attraction are the restaurants of all kinds, kitchen, taste and of course, prices.I consider the best gastronomic place of Bs.As.

Upscale and chic. Puerto Madero is the newest neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Right on the river, this is a neighborhood full of upscale restaurants, bistros and cafes that will have a bit higher price tag. It's also a lovely place to walk around and enjoy a less crowded, greener neighborhood. The large, white, modern bridge (Puente de la Mujer) is a must, but If you're visiting during the winter, you'll want to go here during the daytime, as it gets rather windy on the river at night. AbbySay Hueque Argentina Adventures

Not Buenos Aires. Really disliked Puerto Madero even though locals kept recommending the neighborhood to us. Felt like countless other similar redevelopment projects around the world and very overpriced and mediorcre restaurants.

I guess it is a must but do not expect much. Common wisdom will indicate that Puerto Madero (PM) is a must visit while in Buenos Aires (BA) and I agree but do not expect anything special. It was the old main port of BA and it is worth walking around the 4 sections that will take you about 2 hours and take a look a the old structures (buildings and cranes) and new condominiums specially since it is at walking distance from other major attraction such as Teatro Colon among others. Restaurants at PM in my opinion are many overpriced and are not necessarily the best value for money since you will be paying the tourist trap but there are some with nice views, just check the menu. I did have lunch twice at Peugeot Lounge Cafe close to the BuqueBus side of PM and I found the place to be simple and provide excellent food (we ate creeps, generous sandwiches, soups, desserts and had the Patagonia beer) at a very reasonable price with same nice terrace - view. Enjoy your visit.jr

I used to live in B, and go back about each 2 years toBuenos Aires,I will be going this October. Buenos Aires is a very beautiful city, you have wherever you go good food, good ways of going around,,like subways, colectivos(small busses),etc.etc. its a very vibrant city, it depends on the taste of the individual. I love the architecture of the old houses and palaces, the cultural part,like the Theater Colon, and so many others, just the little stores in the "barrios" neighborhoods are something to see.Restaurants in Puerto Madero are very nice, but kind of expensive(not w/US$), but you have so many other choices,like El Palacio de la papa frita, on Lavalle between Esmeralda and Maipu, reasonable, very good place for steak and potato soufle!!!!!!!

Good for lunch or dinner. Puerto Madero is a really pleasant district of Buenos Aires - a great place to go for lunch or dinner as there are many really excellent restaurants and cafes there. Formerly a port industrial zone, the former warehouses have been well renovated and blend with modern buildings.

Beautiful!. It's really a beautiful place for evening/morning walk. Entire area surrounding to river is around 3-4 KMs with some nice attractions around it and as well in the river. There are multiple restaurants available around this area too.

Che!!!! sigue la Bava. this place has some delightful restaurants in the area. its a must go place in Buenos Aires, you will like this place have a nice walk around the area and enjoy the BSAS atmosphere
Not my cup of tea. Modern, clean, and relaxing, but not why I came to Buenos Aires. I did enjoy the restaurant Johnny Be Good, however.

Nice river walk, restaurants and entertainment. This is a beautiful river area with a walkway on both sides and the Women's Bridge in between. Check out the higher end restaurants, the university, entertainment, and art galleries,

Great place to spend a day. If there are people with a lot of money, they are living there. Its a place full of luxury building, luxury stores and great restaurant. Everything surrounded by the Rio de La Plata (port of Buenos Aires). You can't miss it. Even if you do not want to spend a lot of money, at least go there for a coffee. Also it's VERY safe.
Great fun!. Stayed at the Hilton and walked around the Port. Great restaurants and bars. Very safe. My boys (17 and 21) had a great time . The Hilton was fantastic.

Walk, coffee and relax. Great place to take a talk, specially in a sunny day. You can rent a bike, just sit on a coffee shop and watch people walking their dogs. It's a nice place to spend the afternoon.
Delicious place for relaxing. Very nice place for walking or biking during the day and also have a nice dinner in any delicious steakhouse available

The best modern and old part of Buenos Aires. This used to be the old DOCKS, but after renovation in the 1990´s it has become one of the most expensive places in Buenos Aires... full of restaurantes, offices and high end apartments...Great to visit and walk during the day and night.Also, one of the safest places in Buenos Aires to walk...But just in case careful.

Must see in Buenos Aires. A beautiful neighbourhood in Buenos Aires, best to vistit during the week because the weekends it gets packed with people. There are many restaurants to have lunch or dinner. Or you can just walk around or use your rollers.

Very expensive. Everyone recommends Puerto Madero for food so we decided to venture down for lunch. It was way too expensive for us and we wouldn't really be budget travellers. We ended up going back into the city because nothing on any of the menus was worth the money. Nice walk along the harbour though.
Not to be missed. A very lively area of Buenos Aires, overlooking the river and looking at boats sailing. One can just stroll along or go to a restaurant or a bar adjacent and have a good time

Good to visit if you are homesick. If you are from the U.S. and missing home, take a break in Puerto Madero. A modern development section along the water front, it is highly walkable (love the bridge). It doesn't have much of a specifically Argentine feel to it however. You can find several restaurants with a feeling that is more USA-inspired.
Nice Resturants. Puerto Madero is an old port with modern cafe and fine dining restaurants by the river, beautiful for a night stroll. We had dinner at La Bisteca very good quality food.
New and cool. Highrises and a rebuilt warehouse district are the highlights. A great place to go for a more casual night out

The place to be... although this isn't the real Argentina.... This is really a different Buenos Aires... you want to see something in contrast with the rest of the city, this is Buenos Aires moderno ! With some fine dining places (las lilas, la bisteca, el porteno, la caballeriza, estilo campo), ice cream bars, promenadas, bars and hotels (hilton, faena hotel), casino... a place to have a walk....join the luxury of the grand landlords of Argentina/ Buenos Aires...
nice, but nothing really special. i stayed in a hotel in this area, and strolled around a fair bit. it's modern and safe.. well policed.. but not very very much to see or do other than the bridge.

nice place for a stroll. Very touristy, it has a nice view of the river and offers an agreeable setting for stroling, walking the dog or simply having an ice cream in a hot afternoon. Most of the restaurants are tourist traps, though.

Beautiful old port. The view around is fantastic, the place was used in the past as loading / discharging docks for ships, a Captain friend started there during his sailing days.There are nice restaurants where the docks used to be, they kept the old cranes, there's an old frigate anchored and now a museum. Worth walking around and the scenery is breathtaking.

Nice restaurants. We went there one evening and there were very few people around, we were there around 8.00 p.m. for dinner. Later I got to know that Argentinians have dinner later, around 9.30/10.00 p.m. and everything was explained. We got back and had dinner at Casa Las Lilas and it was fantastic! after we walked around and tried to have some coffee at Fredo, very bad coffee, maybe good ice-cream, but no coffee.

Nice Casino and Restaurants.. Puerto Madero is cool but not my favorite area in BA, most of the building are new and i feel it lacks the beautiful architecture and soul that the rest of Buenos Aires has. that being said they have a cool casino on a boat there if you like to gamble and many great restaurants. I think its a good spot for an evening, not to stay..

The Woman's District of Buenos Aires. This district of Buenos Aires is dedicated to the women, most streets have women names and the pinnacle is the Puente de la Mujer (Women's bridge) Designed by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava. The barrio is very modern with very good restaurants.
Place to walking. We walked a lot appreciating the river view. There are a plenty of good and expensive restaurants in the river margins. We also see the ship "war fragata" museum inside.
nice walk. I stayed in a hotel nearby and took advantage to have dinner there, went walking and it was a really good meal.

A great place to spend time. Puerto Madero was originally developed in the late 19th century. The 21st century has seen the area redeveloped into one of the trendiest areas in Buenos Aires with luxury hotels, offices theatres, cultural centres and cafes. Some of the buildings are up to 50 stories. The many interesting sites include the "Woman's Bridge" and the corvette Uruguay, commissioned in 1874. With my wife I explored the area for around 2 hours stopping for a drink in one of the many very good restaurants. The weather was fine and sunny which made for a great walk.

It's beautiful!. This place is very very beautiful! I walked with my family, but this place certainly would please my friends! I went to afternoon to see the sunset ... fantastic! There are several restaurants options, cafes and bars ... the night went to the restaurant La Trattoria Parolaccia, excellent! It has options that appeals to all tastes and a good service... Atteption with cabs! Attention to the taxi drivers ... they somehow deceive you!
A place to go in Buenos Aires. The old Dock area became a very busy comercial area full of restaurants and stores is a place you have to go when in BA
Buenos Aires vacation. Very interesting place. Full of amenities with excellent places for dining and to enjoy spectacular tango shows.

Great walking tour!. I explored this new part of Buenos Aires on foot with my friend. Very clean place and nice restaurants, cafes and pizzerias.
