Very modern architecture, wide sidewalks and very clean area. There are places to visit such as the Woman's Bridge, The Sarmiento Frigate and another smaller ship called Corbeta, both museums now. This is the place if you want to relax in Buenos Aires, far from the crowded streets.

Nice place. We stayed at the Hilton - Puerto Madero is a very nice revitalized section of BA. An old port within a walking distance to the presidential palace with plenty of restaurants. Quite modern and safe. And within a walking distance to the ferry terminal if you would like to visit Colonia del Sacramento.
nice but not genuine. this is the new place to see and be seen but it hasn't the real Buenos Aires spirit. some good restaurants around

Puerto Madero. This waterfront area was very highly recommended by several people and travel websites. I will say that fore me, personally, it did not live up to the amount of hype it was given. The waterfront walk is very nice (nicer than the one in my city for sure), but aside from water and what I assume are expensive restaurants, there wasn't much else to see. It could be that we did not walk far enough, but there did not seem to be many attractions. If you are looking for a relaxing or romantic stroll however, it is an excellent choice.
Best relax time !. Is the best relax time, nice, cool and paceful place to visit. Many of the best restaurants and bars of BAIRES. Great drink a white wine with seafood, outside. SAFE FOR TOURISTS.
lively renovated area. renovated port area, with good variety of restaurants and bars. Nice river views. There is even an ancient tall ship transformed into an interesting museum.
the port. lots of bling bling restaurants. very expensive for buenos aires. tourist trap but you are on puerto madera, the port. some of the restaurants are more like eating in manhattan.
Some interesting architecture around the dock area.. Restaurants are for tourists--bad and expensive. Mostly an enclave for tax dodgers and uninspiring residential buildings.

More than just another Neighborhood.... Puerto Madero is one of the newest neighborhood of Buenos Aires with less than 25 year of existence. Its was an old port area dedicated for loading grains and export goods, but was totally renovated in the 90's, creating one of the most expensive areas to live in South America. It has some of the most expensive hotels, a really great variety of restaurant to chose from, an university, a casino and some of the most expensive buildings. The area as well has a very beautiful bridge call "The Women Bridge's", with a very unique design and that changes colours at night. Also, usually is the sitting port of one of the historic Frigates of Argentina. In my opinion, the best features is its security, with the neighborhood under the Prefecture Police jurisdiction and has an impressive set of cameras. Probably one of the safest places in the Capital. Historically, there is not much to see but still its a must....

Skyscrapers by a nature preserve?. Puerto Madero is a stark contrast from the rest of Buenos Aires. Sleek 21st Century high rise buildings full of expensive condominiums are within eyeshot of the city center's 19th century buildings to the west and to the east, a major nature preserve along the Rio de la Plata. It almost felt like a different country. The architecture is impressive, if a bit ostentatious. I only wish I'd had more time to explore the nature preserve.

Trendy modern area with well preserved past.. This trendy modern area is on the waterfront and provides an eclectic mix of old warehouses converted to modern apartments,restaurants and bars. This area is complete with the old cranes which serviced the area so well, for so long.The highlight for us was inspecting the 1879 85m Barque " Presidente Sarmiento". The entrance fee is only 5 Pesos.
Puerto Madero - Beautiful. The whole are was fantastic - I actually started looking at real estate. We ate at an excellent restaurant and hung out all night

New neighborhood plenty of restaurants near the river. Really I recommend this place if you want to eat well, different kinds in an elegant place, food from all over the word, only you have to chose the right restaurant, some hotels near, if you take taxi is five minutes from city center(without traffic)

Great for visit and perfect for restaurants. This area is one of the most popular areas in Buenos Aires. It was the old area where storage buildings and port related where located and now they have made a beautiful place with restaurants, nice Hotels and environment.
Good for one time visit. It is a very calm and un-populated place. There is just one bridge worth walking on. Good for family.
Amazing location. Puerto Madero is the most exclusive area in Buenos Aires. It has lots of very nice restaurants by a canal. It also hosts an incredible ecological sanctuary.

Plenty of restaurants and bars. If you like night life this place is safe and full of bars and restaurants. I've been there few times during my visit in B.A. and it's ok place. I mean, it's a port. So there's not that much you can expect from a port :)

A regular waterfront place. Puerto Madero is a water front river area with a walkable bridge..
It has shops and different bistro. It has condo living which they say is expensive. The view is nothing to ravel about

Upscale neighborhood with excellent restaurants and a beautiful walkways next to the river.. All sorts of restaurants and shopping. Check restaurant ratings on this site and chose one to your liking. Plan a stop here for lunch or dinner.
modern stroll area. A place of restaurants at waterside, tranquillity among the hustle of a metropolis. Adding some text now to fulfill 100 characters

Fair Enough. To me it had nothing new to offer since the whole neighborhood is a good old version of urban landscape with high rise buildings and modern renovations and construction taking place but yes compared to other vibrant neighborhoods of Buenos Aires this is definitely different. I loved certain art installations that I saw while taking a stroll around these neighborhoods. It is good for that taking a good walk soaking in the views and maybe dining in one of the restaurants around but we warned it can be really expensive and if you are travelling by car, you will be searching hours for a good parking spot.

an interesting area with an artificial canal, restaurants, shops and appartments. This area has been reconverted about 10 years ago. It is a little outside the city center and offers a very nice residential, commercial and entertainments places.It is nice to walk there for an hour and possibly have lunch or dinner.

A different view along the riverside of Buenos Aires. We were staying in Palermo Soho where we preferred the restaurants (better selection at reasonable prices) but we very much enjoyed our morning walk along the river. It was interesting to see the re-development of what was once the original Port (similar but a little different to many modern cities) - old warehouses converted into shops and apartments as well as the very modern pedestrian bridge...we couldn't quite see the curves of a woman as the Architect/Engineer? intended but it is a beautiful structure. (See photos) There was a Spanish guitarist playing on the bridge, it was a sunny day and such a relaxing thing to do. The other thing we enjoyed doing was a visit to the historic Argentinian ship moored near the pedestrian bridge - a very small entry fee & well worth a visit. After that we just had a burger for lunch at an outdoor cafe (on our walk back to Metro) as we read from TA that the restaurants in this area are overpriced for what you get.

Is Your Money Really Burning a Hole in your Pocket?. Do you really want to pay through the nose for mediocre (at best) food in Puerto Madero, instead of having a superb culinary experience at a fantastic restaurant in Palermo, Recoleta, or San Telmo for 1/3 of the price?!? Did you go to Buenos Aires to buy a beautiful leather jacket at factory/outlet prices, or spend your hard-earned money on the same old uninspiring brand names at the frou-frou shops in Puerto Madero?! Is your money really burning a hole in your pocket? If the answer to any of the above questions is yes, then you'd feel right at home in Puerto Madero.Puerto Madero is definitely NOT the place to get a feel for, and experience, the authentic Buenos Aires. Yes I dare say it's a safe and manicured spot to visit and walk around for a bit (albeit ONCE), but it feels incredibly contrived, not to mention it's painfully far from the Palermo and the Recoleta [or even the San Telmo] neighborhoods, where most of the scenic and the otherwise interesting activities and the restaurants are. In short: We found Puerto Madero to be a glorified tourist trap, where the ailing Argentinian/Buenos Aires economy hopes to scalp the unsuspecting vacationing crowds. A contrived dog and pony show with very little (if any) redeeming value. If you must satisfy your curiosity about this 9th wonder of the world, then limit your rip-off exposure to window shopping and, for the sake of your children's college funds, stay away from those overpriced restaurants.

3.5. It's pretty nice, with a nice sight of the river. The security seems reliable, and the streets clean. It has a cheap movie theather, but the dinning places are pretty expensive. It's hard to park, with so many cars being there, and the parking place isn't cheap either.Got a museum-boat and a casino-ship.

DOS HOTEL IN USA. Excellent restaurants
International Cuisine, excellent " asados" great wine, great ambiance for all kind, family, couples youth groups, and business
Beatiful place. Impressive place. The only problem is if u looking for a place to eat between 3pm to 6pm, they have not a lot of choice. Most of the restaurants are re open after 8pm

Fun afternoon and evening on the waterfront. This is a nice way to spend an afternoon or evening. The view of the night skyline is particularly lovely. The Women's Bridge is worth many photos as well! It is a great place to have a snack, dinner, or a drink, walk around, browse the shops, and visit the art museum.After dark it is full of nightlife and a lively scene.

Great place to walk and eat. We spent quite a bit of time walking along the river enjoying the great views and the fresh air. If you are not feeling like being inside this is the best place to be. It is a modern pier with a cool walking bridge as it's center piece. Their is also an old ship you can board and take pictures on. The best part is the reward for all of the walking we did. There are tons of awesome restaurants along the pier. I would go back to enjoy the view and try a different restaurant.

Beautiful views!. This is a great area to take a walk and maybe grab a bite. It is different from the architecture found every where else in BA, more modern. It is also much more quiet so it can be chance to relax and enjoy the views.
Great place. This place has been renovated and great stroll for families and couples.. Close to the old Buenos Aires and great restaurants along the way..

Nice place to walk and dine. If you're looking to experience an Argentinean parrillada this is the place to go. It's full of restaurants and waterfront strolling paths. You will find many restaurants and price points in Puerto Madero. It's definitely a must see when you're in town.
Great riverwalk. Wonderful to get out and see some of the sights next to the river. Beautiful restaurants and a great view of Buenos!
Lovely neighborhood. Nice place for a stroll. See the port . Take in a tango show and have dinner at one of the many restaurants.

Nice place for dinner and night walks. This area was revamped some years ago for tourism. If you like meat, there are lots of good restaurants in this area. If you don't like meat, you won't find anything to eat. The area is nice, and walking at sunset is a very good way to end a day.

Modern and enjoyable!. This area is so different from the historical parts of Buenos Aires, I enjoyed exploring it as a change. Most of the American chain hotels are located here along with many trendy restaurants.

A good promenade. It's the best place to go for a walk , to have lunch or dinner or why not an icecream or a coffee if you can´t afford the prices of the river side restaurants
The view is amazing your are ten minutes from Plaza de mayo but you are far fom the noise of the city.

Twilight afternoon walks. Enjoy crossing to the modern side, walking on the evening while lights turn on, until it gets dark. Get a coffee on the sidewalk by iCentral Market, opposite to Hilton's Hotel road.
Great place to visit. By day or night, it's a great place to take pictures and have a good meal! If you're in Buenos Aires you'll have to visit Puerto Madero!
A very quiet and beautiful place. The best place to go for a walk away from the noise of the city.The beauty of the skyscrappers are amazing.

Excellent Choice to have lunch or dine... Many different kind of restaurantes next to the riverside.. Puente de la Mujer, you can have a walk with an excellent view of the Yachting Club and the modern and tall buildings while you choose your restaurant. You can miss it. Couples, businessmen, families... Etc

BAD AIRS NOT GOOD AIRS (BUENOS AIRES.). puerto madero in buenos aires is a very expensive place surrounded by tall buildings that are mostly empty due to their high prices with real estate at a standstill as who wants to invest in a country without any guarantees. Three Shanty towns are very near and to make things worse I saw a couple of rats one evening on the sidewalk ( its on a very dirty river "rio de la plata"). It is a common place for weekenders to wonder around as they are unable to afford the high prices of the restaurantes in the neighbourhood. Evenings it is full of tourists .for dinner who are not aware of the rip off they are in for. Security is a major topic as thieves on drugs all over with killings,shootings and evenkidnappings taking place while the pólice look the other way.My opinion is that criminals work together with the authorities. If this isnt the wild west I wonder what is.

Cant miss it. Just walking by the port is amazing. You may choose from so many awesome restaurants to eat and while you eat you also watch people go by Then grab an ice cream cone and walk down to the wonderful Puente de La Mujer.... what a wonderful scene this is.Love Puerto Madero!

Great rehab of old port. Great for a walk along the canal, lot's of good restaurant/bars. Interesting business and residential developments with an american lifestyle touch. This could be in any big 21st century modern and upscale location in the world. Thus it lacks a bit ofcharacter and local agent indian flavour.

Puerto Madero Neighblorhood Buenos Aires. Puerto Madero neighborhood spreads out along the Rio De La Plata riverbank. Rio De La Plata is an estuary on the southeast coast of South America between Argentina and Uruguay. Puerto Madero neighborhood represents the latest architectural trends in Buenos Aires and is considered one of the most successful waterfront renewal projects in the world.Beginning in the 1990s, there was local and foreign investment in regenerating and refurbishing Puerto Madero. Developers created elegant houses, offices, lofts, private universities, grand hotels, and restaurants. This new district was quite a change for a city that grew up "turning its back to the river”. Led by the opening of the Buenos Aires Hilton in 1999, luxurious hotels, state-of-the-art multiplex cinemas, performing arts theatres, cultural centers, and office and corporate buildings, including Oracle, are mostly on the east side of Puerto Madero. The streets are full of affluent young techies and college students.Puerto Madero redevelopment was of interest to renowned architects all over the world. Today it's the “preferred address for growing numbers of young professionals and retirees. Increasing prices have generated interest in the area as a destination for foreign buyers, particularly those in the market for premium investment properties”.Every street in Puerto Madero is named after women. The Puente de la Mujer (Women's Bridge) is the newest link between the east and west docks of Puerto Madero. In 2008 Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat, the wealthiest woman in Argentina, inaugurated a museum in Puerto Madero, the Fortabat Art Collection.
Great harbour!. The best place to walk, bike and eat in Buenos Aires! Dont miss this area. Go and explore the hole city!!!
Great New Use of Land. I like that way that this old shipyard and warehouse district has been turned into a beautiful combination of shops, condos, and housing, Greatr job, BA!

Saturday stroll . Strolled around this area around 10am on a Saturday morning. It was quiet, clean, safe, and had a bunch of restaurants and cafes to choose from. Would recommend to anyone to visit and wander around, or have a good workout running around in the mornings.

Great Place for visiting!!!. I recommend this place, You can find a lot of restaurants in everywhere. In Puerto Madero you can go to Woman's Bridge. I ate in BullDog, it was Great!! I loved Puerto Madero so much!!

Nice walk by the river, great restaurants!. This is the port of Buenos Aires, now a tourist area in an upscale neighborhood. It's packed with excellent restaurants and beautiful views of the river, bridges and yachts. There is a casino if you are into gambling. And if you are a little of a history buff, you can visit one of Argentina's historical fragatas that is parked there for people to visit. It's always packed with people and it's the safest place in the country, with its own metropolitan police. You can spend a lovely day there and have amazing food in any of its restaurants.

the Port of Buenas Aires. Puerto Maduro is the upscale restaurant area of the city. The food is expensive compared to elsewhere but everything is first world cleanliness. It is a short cab ride away and many hotels have a free shutlle for their dinner tour.
Interesting. the place is beautiful!! I loved walking through this port. is clean, there are restaurants, galeries and an old ship museum.

Oasis in the city. After 5 days in Recoletta, we decamped to the Faena and we were so happy we did. The pedestrian (albeit touristty) dykes and the eco-reserve were a nice change of pace from the bustle of the "city" We also felt EXTREMELY SAFE! There were always people walking and jogging and it felt great to be walking around late at night surrounded by couples and families. Close to restaurants and we walked up to the Obelisk, cafe Tortoni and enjoyed the Faena.
Nice Neighborhood. Beautiful place to visit. good idea to rent a bike and ride around the area. Also there are really nice restaurants at the port (a bit pricey though)
Charming and also modern district. Safe, nice, beautiful new neighborhood in Buenos Aires. With nice restaurants, bars and some cafés. Quiet during the day, but with many options at night.

Very attractive and modern side of BA. The city has done a good job of reclaiming the old port area. Quite trendy neighborhood, with a modern feeling. Lots of hi-rise apartments in contrast to some beautiful old buildings,[ Post Office, Defense Headquarters].The yacht harbor in the middle is a fun diversion. Lots of restaurants.The police is provided by the Prefectura, which is by far the most competent and honest Argentine constabulary, and it feels that way.The place is a bit of a bubble, and really does not reflect the true BA.

Mix of new and old. It is a modern area with new architectural designs and buildings.At the same time the docks give an old look. It is a nice area to walk around,specially near the docks, on one side are the old buildings and across is the modern construction..

Nice wandering spot. With less traffic, great restaurants and an all around interesting study of urban renewal with a nod to history, Puerto Madero is cool. It would be even better if there were options of things to do when it starts raining. But I really like walking along the water and imagining the area back in its first heyday.

Peacefull Oasis . Very nice on a sunny day as it is a World apart from the noise and heavy traffic on all neaby streets. Lined with topnotch restaurants and a great view of the skyscrapers and punte de mujeres.

Walk, lunch, dinner, everything!!!. Like this place very much!!! lot of fun!!! in sunny days you can walk and visit the Reserva Costanera Sur, a green area to go birdwatching and see the river...I recommend this ;)

Beautiful Quiet Modern. Loved this place. It is starkly different from the rest of Buenos Aires. Modern & expansive & very quiet. I just passed through it by Bike and stopped for about half an hour. It looks like it would be a very nice place to sit in a cafe of have lunch or dinner.
Lovely. Wonderful walk around the Buenos Aires marina. All around there are fancy restaurant and bar.A good place to have a very good time!

Waste of time. After reading the great reviews on trip advisor about Puerto Madero we decided to visit and take lunch. I have to say I was sorely disappointed. Ok so the area is nice and you are right by the water but there is little else to say. Unfortunately the restaurant we ate in could be any old tourist trap with over priced food and bad service in any area in the world.Skip this and visit Palermo or Palermo Soho where you can see lovely neighbourhoods with great, welcoming people, great service and wonderful food and wine for great value.
nice place, good meal. Walk by night and have a great dinner. 15 min walk to downtown. Good variety of restaurants, parilla, sea food and more.

old docks refurbished with excellent taste,. very lively area full or restaurants, fantastic hotel (FAENA) and amenities, around 2kms along the riverside.worth visiting the Frigrate Liberty, the hotel Faena, a fantastic beef restaurant (the best in BA) called LAS LILAS.
Restaurants. Te best food of buenos aires, met , sushi, mexican, italian, nice walk arroun, nice views, reserva ecológica
Excellent safe area. Very good choice of restaurant located in a regenerative docklands area. Very pleasant to stroll in the evenings soaking up the atmosphere

A great place for dining or living. I used to live in Buenos Aires,and came here various times for dinner.I've often thought of moving back to Buenos Aires,if I did I wouldn't mind living here because it's located in an excellent location. Furthermore,some the finest condominiums for rent are located here. And of course there are all those excellent restaurants as so many other visitors to this site have commented on.However, other than the restaurants I don't think that Puerto Madera has a lot to offer tourists. The architecture is new, and isn't so stunning. I'd only recommend it for lunch or dinner.,

Lovely place to walk around. There are lots of restaurants and cafes in this regenerated dock area. Worth a visit to sit and drink a coffee or have lunch and watch the world go by. Beautiful architectural bridge (see picture below). Great at night too with a range of lovely places to eat lots of them with verandas overlooking the water.

Pretty place very upscale. Part of my bike tour, beautiful area to walk/bike etc. Good museums and history here. There are three schooners they have turned into museums that are basically free, and it is a good place to take photos of the river and modern BA.

It was a great place. I have family in BsAs, but still, I travel there as a tourist. The first time I visited Puerto Madero, in 2002, it was a beautiful place, with a great atmosphere. Well conserved, full of flowers and light. All the best restaurants were there.But now, 13 years later, the place deteriorated a bit, all the good and new restaurants are elsewhere. Anyway, the place aged but without that retro vibe...It's still a place to visit, but, if your trip is short, consider visiting the japanese garden and the rosedal park, along with a great walk at the palermo soho neighbourhood, because all the good vibe and atmosphere that once Puerto Madero had, palermo soho enherited.

A great place to visit when in Buenos Aires. The restored docks of Puerto Madero is a lively area full of bars and restaurants. It has a number of interesting vintage ships that can be visited for a modest entry fee. Beyond that is an ecological reserve much favoured by local people for walking, running and cycling. In between the two is pedestrianised area that contains an assortment of refreshment stalls, mobile bike hire and repair trallers, mobile a sweet and toy sellers and everything required for a family afternoon out.

Great Restaurants at Buenos Aires. When in Buenos Aires one must visit Puerto Madero, Great place to walk get a nice view of the river and eat a very nice Meal. The whole section is full of wonderful restaurants I have tried three or four of the and they all have been excellent.

Not too exciting. Peurto Madeira was boring when we went on a Tuesday night. Perhaps it is more exciting on the weekend. Didn't eat there so not sure of the restaurants. Nice bridge though. Otherwise I would not recommend an area to go to.

Puerto Madero-a variety of choices for dinner. We wandered down Puerto Madero, enjoying the view of the water. The entire area is mostly restaurants, and since we weren't ready to eat, there wasn't much more to do than enjoy the view. But at night, with the many culinary choices, it's a great place to hang out and enjoy.

Villegas at Puerto Madero. We had dinner here as we drove around the Puerto Madero area. This is a real nice restaurant by the river. The service is excellent and the food is great. Select the tables by the river for a nice view.
Great view. Puerto Madero is the newest neirborhood in BA. It has an amazing view of the canal, the tallest buildings in the city and great restaurants too.

the new part of BA. 1- looks like a new neighborhood in BA.
2- where you can have a nice dinner, or breakfast, the atmosphere is kool.

A Leisurely Stroll. Walked from one end to another and viewed the various sites along the way: Puerto Cristal building, several restaurants and bars and the many moored boats, barges and sailboats, a gleaming view across the river and of course the usual bikers, joggers and walkers all enjoying the scenery. Of course there is the rotating footbridge, the Puente de la Mujer (Womans Bridge) that is the striking focal point....
Go during the day. The neighborhood can be kind of sketchy at night. There's some restaurants but not much other than that.
Water. Looks like Rotterdam. You can hire a boat or eat overpriced sushi in one of the restaurants. Nice place if temperatures are rising in BA.

Nice and new, but a not much personality. This is the newest, fastest-growing part of BA and you can tell. The buildings are new the restaurants are a bit corporate and trendy and there just doesn’t seem to be a ton of personality in this place unlike the rest of BA. That being said there is nothing wrong with Puerto Madero and in fact you do need to stop by, but just be warned that it’s not that special. There is a TGIF Fridays here. Enough said.

Vibrant. Modern upscale living, restaurant, and shopping area along the river built from old brick buildings. Along with the new high end modern high rises and the aforementioned features, this is the coolest non-colonial area of Buenos Aires. It's THE place to go for after work or weekend get togethers. High on the list of singles, it's a great long area to walk with a date. Or, there are many nice restaurants on both sides of the river. During the day, there are many families and moms with strollers. Puente de ls Mujeres spans the river. Come here to experience the other side of Buenos Aires.
Great running place. I loved to go run there at night although there is not much more to do there other then some mediocre food and to drink.

Love the open space and Puente de las Mujeres. My whole family loved strolling in Madero along the water near Puente de las Mujeres, visiting the museum Frigate, strolling to the Hotel Faena and having a biftec chorizo jugoso sandwich at La Costanera that I gather can get dangerous. Although you can feel the wealth in the neighborhood apartment buildings it is also the only place we saw people begging during our entire trip to Buenos Aires.

Nice walk..... Puerto is full of over priced restaurants, while some are excellent they to me are worth what you pay for. However, I love visiting Puerto Madero just for the walk, if you walk behind Puerto you will find the reserve where you can escape the noise of the city traffic....

Walking and drinking with a ncie view. If you are with your girlfriend it's a nice place to lunch/dinner, you can walk aside Puerto itself and have a great time. If you're traveling with friends, you can grab a beer at Take&Go, sit by the river and enjoy your time talking and watching people goes by. There's nothing much to do, only walking, talking... Puente de la Mujer is located here as well.
Go for the FORTABUT museum not the restaurants!. A few hotels and restaurants and the ferry port. Not much reason to visit really. Loved the Fortubut (sp?) Museum.

BEAUTIFUL!. If you are visiting Buenos Aires, you definitely have to go, not once, but at least twice to Puerto Madero (one during the day and one at night).Beautiful area to walk around, have lunch, do some shopping, and great for nights out.

BRAND NEW AREA OF LUXURY FLATS AND RESTAURANTS. After the financial crash in 2001, when Arentina defaulted on it's debts, they controlled the currency, but allowed any foreign investment of any kind to attract dollars. Puerto Madero - the dock area in the heart of the city was 're-furbished' into luxury flats and very large fancy restaurants for the rich and wealthy Argentinians. the poor were moved out and re-housed in the Barrios at the outskirts of the city. It is beautiful, with some amazing buildings, but is dull and characterless. There are 4 large schooners moored there which for 4 pesos, you can clamber all over. It is the sterile equivilent of London Docklands.

Beautiful but nothing special. Puerto Madera is a beautiful, clean and modern remake of the waterfront, but it's nothing you can't see in any major city on the world. Nothing distinguishes the glass and steel architecture. We had a nice walk there but preferred the grittier parts of Buenos Aires.
A lovely place for a stroll. Nice area to walk through- great restaurants and art, interesting architecture. The sunken ship and leftover cranes added to the charm of this area.

Ask the locals about the history of this place. Peurto Madero has an interesting history. The rich and affluent have invested their money in building the port and later realized the port was not feasible due to shallow waters. The cranes on the banks of the port were left behind since it was not economical to move them to another location. I suggest talk to locals and know the story behind building this place.
cool area. the area has really come to live over the years and is not only an evening/ dining place as the neighborhood has grown with people living there
Honeymoon. Very nice place to visit.. So many options to have for lunch/dinner. Also, calm, quite walking areas within the surrounding parks. Must go if you're visiting buenos aires

best place to have dinner. This place is very nice to have dinner.
There are many restaurants , and you can choose Italian , Asian, Argentine, Brazilians.
I've been in EL PORTEÑO which is Argentine Restaurant, and It was great place. I recommend you.
Nice place to chill. Wide boardwalk, nice view day and night, and make sure you get reservations at Cabana Las Lilas! Great place to go for a walk, or a bike ride, or just grab a bench and just relax

Was a quiet area on old port. Lots of fast food, few people when we were there.. Lacked character but a pleasant break from the city. We went after the sunday market in St Telmo, so was quite a contrast.

A new side to BA life. A great location for restaurants and just a walk from La Boca and the parks. This old warehouse district is now a trendy apartment/office area with restaurants and entertainment - plus the marina.

Great place to walk around. This area is old harbour and nowadays developed as a trendy place. You can have a very pleassant walk around the whole area and time to time stop to relax on a bench or by many cafes and restaurants. In the evening this area is very different when all bars and night clubs are open. Great place to visit.
Boy it was HOT!. Beautiful to see these port-lands being reclaimed and re-purposed. It was very hot during our visit, and the groves of trees were a welcome relief.

Pleanty of choices. A very well done renovated dock area with many really good restaurants and coffee shops on both sides of the harbor. Easy walking. Love the job done in preserving the cranes as an integral part of the water walk. Pretty dark at night, but seemed relatively safe. Short walk from many of the area hotels. Use care when crossing the busy streets in the immediate area.

Rebirth of an old port. What used to be warehouses and docks have been renovated into shops, banks, restaurants and housing. It is nice to walk along the water and cross the footbridge named for all mothers.

I thought it would be bigger. . .. Nothing really special to see here. It seemed to just be bars and convention centers for business travelers. The water is not very pretty to look at and the pedestrian bridge from the photos looks smaller in person.

I thought it would be bigger. Nothing too exciting here. A long walk from downtown to see a bunch of chain bars for business travelers. The pedestrian bridge looked bigger in pictures and was pretty lackluster.

A great afternoon stroll. There have been a lot of comments that this area is too gentrified and touristy. I get it, and if you are stopping in Buenos Aires for one day on a cruise ship, I would skip it. However we were in town for 2 weeks, and this was a pleasant spot for a walk and a great lunch at Las Lilas. Stick to the Argentinian owned establishments (yes, there is a Freddos there) and enjoy the view of the bridge, board one of the boats and relax. We walked to this area from the heart of the Calle Florida chaos and it took 15-20 minutes with no issues.

The new vibrant side of BSAS. Whether its morning or evening take a stroll by the iconic new side of the city which is a few miles away from San Telmo. The contrast is simply amazing yet both very captivating. Lots of nice places to stp by for lunch, a few drinks or an ice cream and see the Argentinians passing by :-)

Modern and touristy. I enjoyed location of this area being on the river. It is a trendy and modern part of the city. The restaurants here were not as good as in other areas such as Recoletta and it seemed to have a bit more of a touristy vibe than other areas of the city. It would be somewhere I would visit for a couple of hours in the afternoon but wouldn't spend a day or have a meal here.

Far from most everything in central Buenos Aires. This is a somewhat newer development of high rises, shops, and pricey restaurants. Pretty pedestrian bridge. This is not much of a tourist area, but rather a yuppie area to live. About six blocks from lower downtown area and about ten blocks from Teatro Colon.

An Evening Stroll. It was beautiful and we could see the women's bridge from the walk way. There are lots of restaurants to chose from and if you have a family and want fast food it is also available here. I think it was a Burger King. The steakhouses are accommodating and most people eat later in the evening. (like 8 pm) Food was delicious but can't remember the name of the place we chose. Most restaurants have their menus on the wharf so that you can see what is offered and for what price. The temperature was pleasant but take a sweater to be sure. I would stroll here again.

Hotels and Restaurants Line the Seaport. Nice walking seaport lined with hotels and restaurants. Many steakhouses can be found here, Las Lilas is preferred. It is a very nice place to visit however there are many other places in this amazing city to see. If you find yourself here you should walk over to Dock 3 to see the lovely bridge - Puente de la Mujer. Great area for dinner and a great place for an evening stroll.
Great restaurants. It's nice place for an evening walk. There are lot of good restaurants along the way. Take a walk down the bridge if you get the chance.

Impressive Wharf. A short ride from the main square Puerto Madero is becoming the place to live in BA. Quality shops and restaurants line the waterfront, keep walking and take in the older part of the harbour. We found a museum of Humour just a short distance away and whilst we couldn't quite translate the cartoons say it all.An Impressive bridge linked the two islands and we found it a very nice place for lunch and drinks

A "different" Argentina.. Area famous for high end restaurants and hotels. A soon as you visit you will see the difference between here and the rest of the city. This is an affluent area with new high rises and mix of commercial and residential. Great to ride or Rollerblade. Have a walk and photography.Careful where you eat!!! Many places look fancy just to be tourist traps!

A pleasant contrast. Puerto Madero is a modern bustling area full of shops and restaurants. It's on the water so has real atmosphere. It is quite a contrast to the rest of the city which is so old. We noticed a lot of people strolling or seriously walking for exercise. It's a big area of reclaimed land and there's a beautiful old frigate with lots of history which has been turned into a museum. It reminded me a little of Canary Wharf in London, as there are offices, stores and residences all together in the same space.Some of the restaurants are pretty high end, but there are a lot more affordable ones too. For families there are even a Mcdonald's and ice cream parlours, so there's something for everyone.

Beautiful Area with modern buildings and lovely park. This area is worth a visit if you want to see the magnificent transformation of the old dock area into a beautiful modern city.The area has the old warehouses converted into restaurant and apartments. The promenade along the river is beautiful and serene and there interesting statues placed al along. Behind the tall building are the parks and the lovely large Eco-park also worth a visit.

A Pleasant Place To Stroll. Puerto Madero has the feel of so many renovated, repurposed seaports. Nonetheless, it's a pleasant place to stroll with many eateries to choose from. The footbridge spanning the Rio de la Plata by Calatrava is a beaut.

Beautiful!. It is very beautiful, welcoming and safe all around!!The bars and restaurants are great and for all tastes (just a beer or a fancy meal).If you're looking for boats chances are you won't see them, which is just fine, of course - just don't feel disappointed (like me the first time I visited lol)I'd only ask for some public restrooms (sometimes if you're just walking around you may have to ask for a "favor" to use some place's restroom).

Waterfront Area to Spend Some Time. Very nice area. Looks like a great place to walk along the water and spend some time. There are a number of waterfront restaurants that would be a great place to relax.
dinner. yes we are going there 4 persons for dinner the food is very good, special lomo, and red wine, the price is high but it's ok.
The modern part of Buenos Aires. A very safe part of the city, plenty of available parking on the street, many bars and restaurants to choose from, some pleasant walks alongside the canal
City Harbour. Busy magnet for tourists and locals alike. Large selection of restaurants. Nice views of the new skycraper area in Buenos Aires.

Nice area to stroll. A refreshing place to visit when you're tired of the heat and bustle of the city. Lovely walks beside what was originally supposed to be a port area, although apparently the canals built were never really deep enough for the original purpose. The bridges are lovely, and both sides of the port are highly walkable. Many of the buildings on the far side are very new, the more historic ones are on the city side. There's not much shade, so on a hot day, it's best to leave this for late afternoon.
Puesta del Sol. If you like take your time and experience a lovely terrace, drink and food, try the Lupita Mexican bar. It was a great experience.
Walk during the day and during the night. Nice place to see other side of Bs As. You can walk and relax in one of the many restaurants all around. Very safety and very clean.

Night life. Well, Puerto Madeiro it's pretty much one of my favorite places in Buenos Aires. At morning there are some really good restaurants, and at night it has the beauty and a great place called Asia de Cuba. Asia de Cuba before 2PM its a Restaurant, good place to have dinner and stuff. After 2PM the night club starts inside ASIA DE CUBA and that place rocks!
A bit over-hyped, but in a city that is suffering..... Puerto Madero is perhaps best visited for lunch and an art gallery or two. Restaurants with a view of the turning basins/harbour are nice.
Gentrified. A gentrified strech along a waterway lined on one side by many restaurants and on the other bank by a marina, an interesting museum and high rise residence and office buildings.
Weather is perfect if you like cool temperatures. Sunny and not too hot like their summer weather. Nice temperature for outdoor visit. However, sunlight is short compared to summer.
Nice area for a walk. A nice safe area for a walk, drink and meal. Interesting bridge and ships to see and visit. Plenty of resturants of varying types and prices

The high class of BA - The only suburb which looks modern. Stroll by the water front. We had dinner at peruvians food restaurant La Rosa Náutica and had a great time, still there are many other selections on the waterfront. Reservations for dinner recommended.

Pretty, but not much to do. I pictured this as a bustling waterfront area with lots to do and many locals. However, presumably due to the proximity to many hotels and business centers, the area ended up being a bit of a tourist trap without much to do except walking around. Admittedly, it is pretty, but most of the restaurants are overpriced and nothing special. I wish I could rate this higher since I was really looking forward to it, but it just wasn't a great experience.

Many restaurants to choose from. Do not pay the full amount at these restaurants. Check the bill before paying, sometimes there are items listed on the bill what was not really on your plate or in your glass

Nite Life - Puerto Madero. Johnny B Good Bar & Grill is an upbeat establishment overlooking the Port.The ambience is cheerie, bright and somewhat funky with huge life-like murals of Chuck Berry, Bob Marley and Jimi Hendrix on the walls.The food was good, but the service was somewhat slow...that gave me ample time to admire the decor without worrying 'bout spilling food on my shirt :-)The music was 'ole school' which one would expect with a name like "Johnny B Good"!The place has a sub-level, I suppose one can dance downstairs.I love this place!!!Arnaz Escribano-Guzman

My favourite part of Buenos Aires. I really liked this area! It's a great place for walking around, people watching, lots of restaurants, nice views of the river. I really liked walking around here as you get the feeling of being in the city without the absolute mayhem that goes with it. We ate in an Italian restaurant here down near the end and it was nice though some of the restaurants were on the dearer side. That said, there's a Burger King and a Mc Donald's here too which was handy for ice cream when it was so sunny. A really lovely part of the city.

GO AT NIGHT - PREFERABLY FULL MOON!. YEAH, YEAH, TOURIST TRAP..... but you cant beat the views of the river, boats, people watching, etc. - and its an easy walk from most parts of the city. "probably" safe at night, which is not sayable about many other parts of B.A.! ( on full moon nights the astronomy peeps set up telescopes....)

We go to PM for 3 reasons only. 1. Exercise. Lots of space for walking. We can really rack up the kilometres and earn a good lunch at...2. Marcello's. For the grilled eggplant, the great pastas and good wine list. And...3. The small but lovely Amelia Lacroze de Fortabat art gallery. After 4 visits, we have yet to get tired of the eclectic permanent collection and mind-expanding temporary exhibits. Other than that, PM does not hold much appeal for us. But then, we don't come to Buenos Aires for the Starbucks or the TGI Fridays!
Posh dockland area. Safe, modern district full of good restaurants and nice clubs. Highly recommended, Fantastic place to spend an evening. Around few luxury hotels.

Nice place for a stroll--when it's not too hot. Lining the wide canal not far from the riverfront, are restaurants of all types. Not a lot of shops and if it's a hot day there's no shade except inside. But the walk lines both sides and goes for several LONG blocks. A very modern pedestrian bridge spans one place and older ones for auto traffic in a couple others. Walk toward the river into the nouveau neighborhood of high rises and along the real waterfront--actually looks like a wetland area. A lovely park all along there and you'll find the Humor Museum, a small place with a collection of cartoons. Everything in Spanish.
fancy and fussy. For Argentina newly rich people, Puerto Madero has many fancy restaurants / bar as well as nice view

This is the best place overall to find the best that can be had in BsAr.. The row of building that make up the Puerto Madero water front area were at one time warehouses for cargo imported and exporter from the port of Buenos Aires. As break bulk and pallets gave way to massive cargo containers, these building were abandoned and fell into disrepair. The port was too small and much too shallow for larger ships and the surrounding area had no place for the acres needed for incoming and outgoing containers. Then a couple of decades ago, these building were rehabilitated. The exteriors of the building were sand blasted and revealing the beautiful, thick and solid brick walls. The restaurants here run from the casual to the up scale and from less than $20 per person to much more depending on your taste, your wallet what wine you choose. There is something for every taste, from pasta, to steaks, pizza, and even sushi. There are at least two places to buy ice cream, if that is all you are looking for. We have eaten there very often since 2004. If you walk on the waterside of the building, many restaurants have menus posted on stands so there is no pressure to ask to see a menu. If you get there for dinner at 7:30PM for dinner you will think business must very, very slow. Come back a 11PM and in most places the tables will all be taken. Unfortunately, in some places service, starts to slow down. I say, enjoy. We were there on the night of the full moon in March. Just perfect.Just looking for a place to enjoy an evening and stop in for just coffee or a cold drink, you will have come to the right place.Area seems to be perfectly safe day or night.

Nice area to spend a few hours or have dinner. Walking around Puerto Madero is a great way to spend the afternoon. There is plenty of room to ride a bike or walk or roller blade. It's a newer section of BoA and part of an economic development effort. Plenty of restaurants, bridges, cafes. It is near the new museum and the waterfront. I enjoyed this area of BoA.

Modern side of the city. Near to Buenos Aires downtown. You can find nice restaurants, coffee and bars. Generally the zone is expensive. A good place to walk and sightseeing. Puerto Madero has two areas: One on Alicia Moreau De Justo Avenue, the old Buenos Aires port buildings, and other area behind that is the neighborhood more newer of BA. It is not a traditional Buenos Aires place.
standard waterfront renewal. It is your standard world wide waterfront renewal with condos, restaurants, etc. Personally not worth the effort to go out of your way to visit

Lovely canal-side dinner. Clean, modern, safe area; though tourists may find it somewhat lacking in South American ambiance. Several restaurants alongside the canal, which is a delightful spot for a peaceful dinner.

Nice to walk and feel Buenos Aires from a urban site.. For those who live in Melbourne or Sydney, this place have a resemblance. Though for us, Argentineans and mostly porteños (local name for those who live in this city) Puerto Madero is a landscape not very often in our large country.It has the most new and expensive places to live in Buenos Aires (maybe comparable with places with longer history). However, is not a close neighborhood, therefore, during weekends and holidays has the best option to walk, bike or rolling.Please take a visit to any of the restaurants or cafes you could have there. Is one of the most exclusive places to visit just with your map, camera and sunglasses.

New Port. It's sparkling clean and filled with corporate hotels, tourist attractions and while the Portenos are proud of it, it's not super-interesting, well, to me at least. Old port, intelligently re-purposed.

Visit Reserva Ecológica Costanera Sur. If you like rich people and businesses this is your place. But i think this is a great place to go running and eat some decent street food. Dont get suckered into the buffets on the city side. If you enjoy good food this would ruin your day.

Great eating location. Puerto Madera is a really great location to eat as there are LOADS of excellent restaurants. Best is Cabana las Lilas a brilliant steak restaurant. It is also a nice place to take a stroll along the waterfront as this is a modern area that is policed by dockside security. Pretty area with lights reflected on the water.

Lovely Stroll On Rio de la Plata River. We chose to spend the day at Puerto Madero. We found it very quiet during the day . It was also hot with no trees for shade, although plenty of outside bars with umbrellas for shade and nice cool drinks. Many were jogging and working out. Many new luxurious condos are being built here and many new restaurants .In the evening Puerto Madero comes alive. Disco bars, restaurants and people just strolling enjoying the scenery.If given the possibility would return especially in the evening.
new ba. to see how portens make the mark on modernism its the best place to see the conversion of the old river port into a chick upscale modern new residential area.

Nice for walking on a pretty day. It's not what you may think...just good for talking a long stroll along the "river"...stop at one of the cafes on either side. Get a caiprinia or another refreshing beverage and some appetizers. The bridge is the architectural highlight....nothing like it anywhere else.

Quite boring. I thought that this would be a really busy place to go and wander and have a few drinks, however there really isn't much to see and all of the restaurants are really expensive compared to the rest of BA , and there wasn't a cafe or bar to just sit and people watch , however ther weren't actually many people there anyway !!
Buenisimo. Great Restaurant AreaNext to the Rio de la Plata RiverDifferent kind of goodSafe to walk and opens till late A must in Buenos Aires
Nice ambience. Not much to see as such but a nice place to have dinner by the water, although prices are a bit steep compared to BA in general.
Great development. The redevelopment of this area is a resounding success, it is full of great restaurants an a great area to jog around and workout in general.

Great Restaurants ... Nice Place for a Walk. According to the locals, this area was an abandoned mess some 20+ years ago. Today it is home to some great restaurants and across the channel some of the most expensive real estate in town. Known mostly for it's restaurants, Puerto Madero offers many choices from elegant sit down to fast food. Take a stroll and read all the menu's before making your choice. Or better yet, work your way down the way and try them all if you have time!

A MINI CANARY WHARF. A pleasant location for a stroll which we had on a very quiet Sunday afternoon.No real buzz to the place that day but it has all the ingredients when you add people.Lots of very nice restaurants,but we just stopped to have a coffee. The water & the tower blocks give a back drop for some excellent photos.The bridge " Punte de la Mujer " is an interesting construction.Plus of course you you have the art collection of Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat housed in one of the buildings -well worth a visit.
Good choice of restaurants. Puerto Madera is a lovely area for a gentle stroll and to have a meal. There are a large number of restaurants to choose from offering a variety of cuisine.

Visiting Puerto Madero, Argentina . Centrally located between most important streets of Buenos Aires. Very easy to take transportation, taxis, subway, etc.Excellent restaurants, most of them next to a river with a good view to high buildings and many things of the city. Excellent to walk around the area and take photos.
Beautiful + featureless. It´s ok but not something you can´t miss down. If you have a free afternoon it´s a worthwile, otherwiswe...

Great Restaurants. If you are looking for a place to eat in Buenos Aires, you cannot go wrong at Puerto Madero. This string of red brick buildings is home to a number of fine restaurants. We walked along, reading menu boards until we found the one that seemed best suited to our tastes.

Interesting area. We spent a couple of hours just walking around this area and eating lunch in a very nice outdoor cafe. Quiet pretty area - worht a visit. If you take the Buenos Aires tourist bus tour, you can get off here and spend some time just walking around.
Like any other new port area. Like any other new post area - all restaurants and high rise buildings with no shade in excrutiating heat
Restaurant row; no shops. We expected a mix of shopping & restaurants based on statement made by tour guide, but it was all restaurants. No shops. Not really within walking distance of city center.

Good place to visit. Great to walk around and take in the sights and culture of the area. Some good cafe's to take a seat and people watch as you drink your coffee and drink in the surrounding area and culture.
Excellent place. This is an excellent place to have a walk, lunch and dinner. There are many options. It is really great and charming place.

Amaizing wiew. Is a good place for walking, the wiew is amaizing. You can understand the evolution of the canal. There are many restaurants but they are expensive. I recommed to visit the Fragata ARA Sarmiento
A pleasant walk. This area has tableau displays to explain the evolution of the canal's complex. It was full of restaurants . The Information centre along the walkway was particularly helpful.

Quiet hi-rises. Puerto madero is an architectually challenged blocks of blocks of hi-rises, more than likely provide a pleasant living for young professionals. There are quite few restaurants along the waterways in a few blocks of converted brick industrial buildings. The two museums aside (the Fragata ARA Sarmiento & the Las Fortabat) there are no other interesting tourist sights.
beautiful. The view is amazing, and it is good for walking. I bet the restaurants are expensive, so I didn't even try one.

Probably the newest area in town. The port area is mostly all new and shines. There are a number of nice looking restaurents, many with outside patio seating available. The area consists of mainly two or three streets that run north and south bordered by the water. I can't say I would reccommend it very highly compared to the rest of BA
The modern Buenos Aires. One of the best ways to view the new Buenos Aires, in a quiet, modern, international and lovely place.

Puerto Madero - Cafe and restaurant society. Restored docklands area full of places to eat and people watch! Great at lunchtime, evenings and weekends. Buildings of character plus a couple of naval museums to keep all the family entertained. More a meeting place for food and friends rather than a destination in itself. Worth a visit and close to San Telmo and other city centre sights.

A buble in the middle of the city. Very old red brick buildings, what used to be the main port of the country is today a beautiful neighborhood with huge sidewalks, a lot of green and the best, full of restaurant in the riverside. The area has a mix of office buildings, pubs, restaurants and apartments but just few small shops and no shoppings at all. It makes the area very relaxing and never crowded. Plus, is one of the safest areas in town. Great for a day walk + dinner.

Nice, new, not as fun, funky or interesting as the rest of B.A.. Was here for my birthday with a group of friends who like to shop and dine out. Puerto Madero is a nice, newer, cleaner area of Buenos Aires on the river. It's a nice walk along the water and you can sit at a cafe and watch the Portenos excercise and enjoy the area. There are several very nice restaurants here (Las Lilas de Cabanas) as well as some rather typical touristy eateries, like TGI Fridays (yawn). The big thing to see here is the Puente de la Mujer (Spanish for "Women's Bridge") designed by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava. It's a beautiful and striking modern foot bridge that defines the modern area in which it has been placed.

Cool aera to walk, look and eat. Puerto Madero is one of the newer developments in BA, it is always fun to walk along the walter, pass by lots of different restaurants, coffees and shops.It is not only a place tourist are drawn to, but also locals enjoy spending their free time there.Price are a little steep - but this is often the case in the trendy areas of BA.

One of the more beautiful places in Buenos Aires. The Old Docks of Buenos Aires Port have been transformen in a new neighborhood. Restaurants, Big hotels like Hilton, are mixed with Port structures and machines creativo a cool atmosphere. Very nice place!!!

Revolutionary change for the better from my 1988 visit!. Revolutionary change for the better from my 1988 visit! This formerly derelict part of the city is now the thew "south beach" of Buenos Aires with a bustling nightlife, great restaurants and modern skyscrapers. Well worth a visit of 1/2 day or more.
Fun place to visit. Mainly modern restaurants but do visit the Sailing Ship Uruguay which visited the South Pole on many an expedition. Good photographs and explanations in English and Spanish

A lovely river walk!. Take your pick of great restaurants that line Puerto Madero. It's at least a mile or two long. I would recommend the Madero Buffet and Grill for the buffet and parrillo. Good value.

The newest neighborhood in BA. It is the fanciest neighborhood in BA, plenty of sophisticated restaurants and modern buildings. It also has a beautiful natural reserve next to the river where Argentineans use to jog and walk on sunny days.

Very good sightseeing of Buenos Aires!. This place is very nice to walk on by during the day and also during the night with all the lights on!Incredible place. I recommend the Woman Bridge (El Puente de la Mujer).

nice and secure place to walk, lunch, dine, or whatever. Puerto Madero is the newest neighborhood built in Buenos Aires, very classy, by the river.You can enjoy nice restaurants with different menu options, almost all of them excellent! or go to the movies, or just walk around and enjoy the nice breeze....

Love AR. I love Puerto Madero. I travel for business here all the time. It's a nice place to stay with the coffee shops along the water where you can sit and relax after work. Lots of restaurants to choose from and safe at night. I can walk to a restaurant or the pharmacy from the Hilton. They have all the amenities you need within walking distance.

Modern Buenos Aires: excellent utilization of an old port area. Puerto Madero probably is the best sample of modern Buenos Aires development. Lots of restaurants and modern buildings constructed along a gorgeous waterfront placed very near downtown, The modern constructions make a very interesting contrast with other developments in the same area that used old dock warehouses completely refurbished but maintaining the external looks.

great for those who have money. it is interesting to see what used to be rambles changed into one of the most affluent areas for those who have money. This was a shipping and receiving from boats years ago and then left abandoned. Now it is a place where those who can pay extra can find the best of Buenos Aires - in food and other areas. It is a nice area for those of us who do not have this life style to visit an window shop and see some of the nicer areas - it great to dream.

Peaceful Waters. Puerto Madero is a very peculiar and different place from the rest of Buenos Aires. You will find a downtown place with so many attractions! Food, disco, small shops, markets, and first level buildings, offices, embassies, the home of celebrities, etc. But the most beautiful thing is the River surrounding all the structure, the River is like to be in Peaceful Waters. Is one of the most emblematic places of the Capital of Argentina. Personally, I love Puerto Madero from the first day.

The newest district in Buenos Aires. Although lacking the character of other districts in Buenos Aires (Palermo,San Telmo, La Boca) Puerto Madero is a very "walkable" place. The promenades by the channel, the restaurants, the tall buildings, the Fortabat Museum and the "Puente de la Mujer" (Woman´s bridge) by Calatrava are attractions both for locals and tourists.It is definitely worth paying a visit.

A pretentious place.... Built on the old river docks, there are some cool office buildings, expensive restaurants, and very expensive condominiums... The location is very convenient as it is very close to the downtown and business district, but everything is overvalued and overpriced here...the food, the office space, and the apartments... Lots of government officials live in this area... up to you whether that is good or bad... I would only recommend a visit on a winter Sunday afternoon for a nice stroll next to the water and a cup of coffee...
Puerto Madero - Buenos Aires. Something similar to London's Times south bank, full of good restaurants, museum, a yacht club and a bridge that is the single work by Calatrava in South America

Walk at Puerto Madero. This is a new area in the city growing still with nice buildings, full of restaurants with a wide offer. Very nice for a walk, quite safe. Best time in the morning and evenings.

Don't miss it!!. Puerto Madero is a must visit! It is beautiful! Great for a good walk! It has beautiful views of the city and you have a river with great spots for your pics of Buenos Aires!!Besides you have plenty of outstanding restaurants for lunch or dinner where you can try world famous argentinian asado!Don't miss it, you' ll love it!!

restored warehouse area , nice restaurants, nice walk, take a look at the Women's bridge -. Our offices moved to puerto Madero back in 2001 , when the area was just starting to pop up. During the last 14 years Puerto Madero has a become a very busy area in terms of people living, working and going out for fun. If you are visiting Bs As it is worth going there for a walk and for lunch or dinner.

New district. Very different then the rest of Buenos Aires the district is new lots of new condo, boutique a lot of restaurant, nice place to spend an afternoon, there is a old sail ship you can visit The Uruguay, also the famous bridge Punte de la Mujere.

Nice waterfront, stretching from the touristic waterfront to Reserva Ecologica Costanera Sur. The area includes several restaurants, and a large new development dominated by fancy high-rise buildings, and a few more places to eat, which you can cross to get to Reserva Ecologica Costanera Sur.
Lovely Riverfront. Gorgeous Riverfront area with tons of restaurants. We enjoyed the view while dining outside at many of the great restaurants.
Restored Dock Area. This is a restored area that old warehouses where turned into lofts, shops, restaurants & businesses. It is a great place to stroll. don't miss the Women's Bridge.

Great views of the waterfront. This recently developed waterfront area offers great views of the many new hotels and offices springing up. A pleasant pedestrian zone in which to stroll and enjoy a drink and a seat with a view in one of the many clean bars and waterfront restaurants. On the down side, I found the atmosphere very bland and international, I rather missed the more stimulating atmosphere of the older Buenos Aires where equally good food, without a waterfront view, could be bought for half the price. Having said that, well worth an hour or two to stroll round.
nice area for a stroll and a meal. I liked our afternoon walk and lunch here. I did not find the food expensive, we ate at a restaurant with a buffet and got a discount for using US cash.

Great place to people watch with a drink. Lovely, clean regenerated marina area - plenty of places to eat/drink, although they aren't necessarily the most 'unique' or original. (i.e. you'll see plenty of chain / franchises). Spent a fair amount of time sitting with a cold drink after work, catching the evening sun and people watching. Really relaxing and definitely worth a visit. Very busy at the weekend - tourists, locals, runners, people rollerblading etc - good atmosphere and great place to be based.

Calm and relaxing area in BA. Puerto Madero is a a great relaxing location in BA away from the busy streets. There are about a dozen restaurants in the area, but all are quite expensive as they appeal to many tourist. I would visit this area to relax on a park bench and take a break during the day.
Lovely waterfront. A scenic area with many restaurants, though not always as good as their high prices might suggest. Go for the stroll and a snack, maybe.

Nice place to walk around . Puerto Madero is a nice place to walk around with shops, museums and fine art. It looks much better at night. Didn't like none of the restaurants around so we just had a drink while we visited the place. The rescue of the old port was a great opportunity to make this place have a very special taste.

The new Buenos Aires. Buenos Aires is like a mixture of Paris and Madrid where the old and the very old collide in beautiful harmony. You can visit Barrio Norte or Recoleta and feel europe in the air, but then you see Puerto Madero and you'll breathe the new Baires. Located where the old Port was, now renewed and developed where you'll find the finest dinner places, fantastic views and really important office buildings. At night you can get beautiful views of the city and is a great walk next to the water.
Up and coming area. Lots of restaurants and bars, and Madero Tango. Old port with tall ship, and artistic (opening) suspension bridge

NY Countdown. Had my countdown at Puerto Madero. It was awesome! Lovely view with continuos of fireworks shown. The beautiful river reflection of the buildings in the night. Day time, it was high end resturants and hotels nearby. The street was very pretty for a good stroll along excluding the sun.A very good day to chill by outside any of the bar/resturant.

Годится, такая ягодица. Comfortable (as well as in the immediate vicinity).Comfortable (as well as in the immediate vicinity). Once be worth it. Fed Up? Continue your way to the nearest Costanera Sur Ecological Reserve. Stock up on a course, drink and maybe it's a sandwich. Anyone his ;)
Hilton Puerto Madero. Great location and surrounded by wonderful restaurants within walking distance. Very safe modern area of Buenos Aires and the staff is amazing accomodating.

Great place to spend a day. Puerto Madero is the old port several ports ago dating back into the 1800's. The brick warehouses have been converted into restaurants, bars and high end shops. They turned the street between the old warehouses and the river into a very pretty pedestrian walkway. Most of the bars/restaurants had outside seating on the old dock area and covered making for a beautiful afternoon casual lunch. There were a lot of portenos there on a Wednesday afternoon eating, strolling etc. There are two old wooden frigates moored there and available for tours (small fee). The newer bridge is an artistic design and well worth seeing and using of course. The area is close to two subway trains - we were using the red line. There are high end hotels located across the river as well as restaurants and bars in newly constructed buildings.

nice. great placeThis is a nice, new and clean part of the City at the "old Harbour" of Buenos Aires which now rather Looks somewhat as a river. Their are plenty of bars, Restaurants (many quite expensive) on both sides of the water. The houses around Puerto Madero are high, new ,modern and likely expensive. Many "Portenos" come here to...

Modernity comes to BA. The docklands area of Puerto Madero was developed only since 2002 and it's amazing how quickly it was transformed and absorbed into the life of the city. It provides a relief from the bustly porteño life, and has some really interesting architectural feature for the modernists. Don't miss the Faena Hotel, its interiors are designed by Philip Stack. If you can't stop by for a cocktail by the pool, just pop in for a peek, they let you do that...
At last we found it!. A long-ish walk on a hot day but interesting to see this new development, particularly after our unintentional visit to the near docks area (not to be recommended!).

A vibrant, clean and modern side to this exciting city. This area of Buenos Aries is spacious, modern and vibrant, up-market restaurants mingle with tall glass fronted office blocks. The walkways are clean, wide, well lit and safe. Green lawns and sculptures abound.The place to be seen.

Modern Upscale. Puerto Madero is very safe and modern. Personally I love the area since is very open, clean, safe and elegant. Unfortunately is very expensive to stay at. Puente de la Mujer if very nice and it has a great view of the city at night.

Nice semi-harbour feeling. This is a nice, new and clean part of the City at the "old Harbour" of Buenos Aires which now rather Looks somewhat as a river. Their are plenty of bars, Restaurants (many quite expensive) on both sides of the water. The houses around Puerto Madero are high, new ,modern and likely expensive. Many "Portenos" come here to Job, there is also an outdoor Fitness "park", a Museum, with a stone woman sculputure at the entrace "cut" into parts. Recommend to go for an easy evening in a safe area.
Nice sightseeing and walking leisurly. Nice views walking along the harbor side, good restaurants for relaxing and enjoying the food, i.e., beef chorizo

Where BA entered the 2nd millenium. Over my 3 visits to the city since 2008, this is the only district where I can say I have seen a significant improvement as judged by the number of new buildings and attractions, and the level of upkeep and maintenance of the area as a whole. Elsewhere one tends to see a city crumbling in the face of administrative ineptness and political chicanery. Maybe it is relevant that every street in this Barrio is named after a female, and that Calatrava’s highly praised white bridge joining its two shores (actually, a rather ordinary effort by his superlative standards) is called THE BRIDGE OF WOMEN. Built initially to allow the largest ships of the early 20th Cent. to actually tie up and dock on city land, Puerto Maderait could not handle the much larger ships that followed, and degenerated into an unused dockland waste that was rejuvenated by legislation and massive investment starting in the 1990s and largely supported by foreign money. Old warehouses were converted into luxurious apartments, hotels and restaurants, cinemas and theatres. Spanking new luxury hotels sprang up from scratch, such as the Hilton, and the Faena (to which the designer Philipe Starck and the architect Norman Foster contributed), buildings that you simply must step into to see where the rich and famous eat and sleep when not at home. A whole cluster of elegant (but not always) high-rise commercial buildings have sprung up, and pay attention to the Edificio Republica (the work of Cesar Pelli, the country’s most famous architect, renowned for Kuala Lumpur’s Petronas Twin Towers), as well as the Boston Bank Building and the Repsol YFP Building. The Universida Catolica Argentina has a fair-sized campus that includes an Art Pavillion. Another religiously – inspired construction is the lovely Iglesia Nuestra Senora de la Esperanza, while art raises its head yet again in the shape of the Fortebat Collection and Museum, a recent addition donated by a celebrated lady noted for age, enormous wealth, and nastiness. I did not get a chance to see it, and I gather that admission is quite expensive but well worth while. Among the street art that you should not miss are the Font of the Nereids ( a lovely example of what this city can do with its spare water), and Edward Pla’s monumental suspended globe The Sphere Dream. Finally, you also have two classic sailing ships known to all Argentinians (The Sarmiento and the Uruguay) moored in the river that you can climb aboard with your kids for a step back into naval history.

A good visit. This is a business and shopping area of the city, well worth a visit. We were there on Sunday, it was full of tourists and families enjoying a day out. There's a huge choice of eateries as you walks along the long dock area. There are two boats to visit - the Fregata Sarmiento and Corveta Uruguay, each one only five pesos per person. Both are well maintained and very interesting, with a member of staff on hand to answer questions about the history of each one.A lovely atmosphere in the area, worth a visit, we found it a very safe place to be.
Nice daytime walk. Disappointing during the day. Mostly restaurants. Plenty of shade on the northern side of the south bank.Maybe better at night, didn't try it.

Great place for fun and good food. Love Puerto Madero, this part of Buenos Aires gives provides you with a different experience in Buenos Aires and you see more westernized side of Argentina. I love the marina, restaurants with great food and entertainment. This is a must visit place for me each time I go to Buenos Aires.
Nice for a walk or eating. Nice area for a walking, day or night. There are several restaurants along the way. Many tourists walking,
Very nice and new. A wonderful, upper-scale area full of shopping and restaurants. It's clean and new and a must see when visiting BA.

Newer Section of Town. We walked through Puerto Madero. It was the new section with upscale hotels and restaurants. There was a walkway along the Nature Preserve area that was scenic and was prolific with food trailers.

It's nice for a stroll. It's nice for a stroll along the river. I didn't think it was anything special. There are restaurants along the way and one can see the skyline of the new Puerto Madero apartment developments on the other side o the river. I guess it's nice to get out of the city centre a bit and have more space. I didn't walk across the river to this modern part of town but took the bus through and it looked nice. Might be safer than the "old" BA.
Europe in South America.. the have turned old docks in the best residential area in buenos aires. nice stores, a lot of good restaurants. spencer !

Nice and clean!. The puerto madero is a nice place to walk and have dinner!!!
It's also good to drink some drinks with a view of Puente de la Mujer!

Needs more development.... ...but not necessarily chain restaurants, and this was the only place we encountered them in B.A. (other than McD's and Starbucks). It was a pleasant day, so a nice stroll, but the time could have been better spent in, say, Caminito in LaBoca.

Awesome. Amazing place to live in. Very beautifull, very quiet and comfortable.
Parks, landscape, skyscrapers.
Nice area to walk, shop and eat!. this area is very nice and safe. you can walk throughout, shop, stop on one of the many terraces of the good restaurants in the area

Bit boring on a Friday night. . Arrived at 1030pm and restaurants were busy with diners, mostly familes.
The ships & women's bridge were nice but not much else to see.
The bars weren't very full, we left at 2am. Perhaps to early, who knows.
It wasn't as funky as I was lead to believe

Pop by if you're in the area. Beautiful place. Used to be an old port area that has been converted into apartment buildings and offices. Lovely place to have a walk through, see the Woman's bridge and have a meal.
The view is very relaxing.
No No no. Not worth going there, this Place could be anywhere - not typical for BA . There are so many more places to go to.
Beautiful view. Very nice to sit and enjoy the view and also enjoy food in the evenings. Lot of nice places to eat around this place.

Great Place to Hang Out Have Dinner. We recently visited Puerto Madero during a visit to Buenos Aires. We went to the casinos and then had dinner at one of the steak houses along Puerto Madero.You will need to take another cab from the casino to the restaurants. This is truly a great walking place that is very relaxing and safe.

Great for a walk without broken pavements like the rest of BA. Staying at the Hilton this neighbourhood is a great place for a stroll and a bite to eat somewhere. We walked from one end to the other and stopped for a pleasant outdoor lunch at one of the many steakhouses. The City's footpaths are becoming very dilapidated so it was great to find somewhere to walk safely and relaxed!

Nice to walk, but nothing else than that.. It is nice to walk nearby, why not? But you will not find much more things than a couple of bars and restaurants. If you have more than 1 or 2 days in BA, go for it. Otherwise, don't waste your time.

Beautiful night stroll. This is a path along the river that is just beautiful as the sun is setting. A large ship that resembles a pirate ship is a make shift museum during the day. The evening light hitting the buildings of the east side of the river at sunset is gorgeous as the lights on the boats and buildings slowly come on. It is lined with great little food stops as well as some well known restaurant chains. There is shopping and parking on the street.
Ok if your hotel is close. Very much a tourist area and the prices reflect it. If you are looking for something for lunch on a day that is a holiday you will find a good place to eat.

Puerto Madero. Puerto Madero is the revived old port area of Buenos Aires, now a fashionable residential, shopping and eating district. The streets are wide, traffic filled and not particularly pleasant or interesting to stroll. The harbor has some old ships to view, some nice restaurants with pleasant views but this is not really a tourist destination. In fact, Buenos Aires itself is not really a tourist destination, more a comfortable residential city, Manhattan without the museums or theaters, Paris without the history or monuments.

nicest part of BA. i think this is the new and upcoming section of the city . The faena hiotel is here and it is a knockout- phillip stark design . restaurants are top notch and on the water . Only down side is not much shopping , still have to go to recoletta for that
