Best place to relax. A great place to walk, with a nice view and a park just behind. The park is called "Parque Mujeres".Restaurants in that area are quite fancy and expensive.

A great pace for a good walk and lunch.. This is composed of a series of buildings along side the old loading docks with restaurants all along the way. There are very fancy, very simple and in between, but definitely a must in your trip to Buenos Aires.
Wonderful Area. Great place to walk along the water on a nice day. Tons of good places to eat. Close to San Telmo. Watch the rowers move up and down the waterway.

Nothing Special. Every city has a redeveloped area in which is clean and shiny and with restaurants and such. This is Puerto Madero. Problem is that compared to BA it is souless. If you live in BA great for roller-blading, jogging, walking, etc. I just didn't find it compelling.
take a stroll. this area is nice to walk around in the day or evening. there are lots of restaurants, clubs, bars and attractions around.
Great place for drinks or dinner. The place is fantastic, a double row of cafes and restaurants on both sides of the river, with a view of the Calatrava bridge

Asado was great. Need to come back again for more red wine and meat.
I found the perfect mix ( 2 bottles of Rutini wine for every kilo of Asado!)

Must go. It's a beautiful place to walk around. We went in te afternoon, so most of the restaurants were closed, but we walk along the costanera and visit La Fragata Uruguaya, a beautiful ship museum.
Nice. Is a nice place to walk, to have a coffee at the end of the day or to have a lunch! On Sunday there's a lot of people doing sports.

Definitely Worth Your Time. If you like walking/strolling, eating or enjoying a good drink with nice views, I'd highly recommend you spend some of your time here. It's one of the best, and probably safest, after dark walking areas in BA. The selection of eateries, from simple coffee/tea and snacks to full-on 800 gm porterhouse steak, is nearly endless. The pedestrian bridge is beautiful in design and sight (especially at night). It is also great for running. I believe one loop is just over 2 miles...it might be longer though. 2 miles is a complete guess. One catch, eateries are more expensive here than just a few blocks away. You definitely pay for the view and atmosphere, but in my humble opinion, it's worth it.

Great place to walk. if you want to take pics of the womans bridge and the boats, you need to walt through puerto madero. You'll need a full day if you want to know everything: the docks, the bridge, the costanera, a typical "bondiola" (bread with pork), beautiful at night also!

No atmosphere. We found Puerto Madero a bit of a let down, although we were on the wrong side of the water I think. So stay on the old side as it looked to have much more ambiance. But it too new and the place lacks the charm of BA. Modern isn't always best.

The neighborhood to be in. This neighborhood is new, beautifully designed with many good restaurants and some nice shops. Take some time and walk around. This is urban renewal at it's finest and the use of old abandonned buildings is really well done.
Nice place for mid day drink. This area is modern and nice. Good spot to stop off and have a drink on the water. Good people watching and lots of places to eat, drink.

Puerto Madero y el museo de fortabat. Puerto Madero is a lovely place to visit for day trips. There are so many things to do. For one thing I just love to visit the museum of Amalia LaCroze de Fortabat. This museum contains the private collection of Mrs. Fortabat plus other temporary exhibits. The museum is very modern and enjoyable. So is really all of Puerto Madero, the biological reserve is a beautiful place to walk and enjoy the sky line of BA. There is also the museum of comparative sculpture in the art school of Ernesto de la Carcova, where replicas of famous sculpture can be admired.Puerto Madero is divided in two sections separated by a canal. The west side is more exposed than the east side. I prefer the small cafes and restaurants on the east side, while the ones on the west side are more up scale and tend to be more touristy. A nice long walk is on the wide and tree lined Costanera avenue " . In the summer bring a hat, lots of sun screen and start early.Don't forget a " Café con leche con medialunas" in one of the cafes on the east side, where most of the locals eat.

Wonderful Docklands Development. The docklands area of Buenos Aires is known as Puerto Madero. Since its founding Buenos Aires has been a port city. The Madero required the construction of a series of closed dams interconnected by bridges. The construction work began on 1 April 1887 and concluded on March 31, 1898. In less than a decade, however, these port facilities could not keep pace with the growth of commerce and between 1911 and 1925 construction development concentrated on a more open dockland further north along the river called Puerto Neuvo. Like many major port cities, this area declined in usage between the 1950s and the 1980s. In 1989 a corporation tasked to redevelop the area was formed. The former docks buildings have been transformed into apartment blocks and commercial centres. Wide pedestrian walkways border both sides of the river where there are numerous high-end stores and restaurants and nightclubs and art galleries. There is a marina full of large sail boats and yachts. It reminded us very much of the Docklands area of Dublin. It too features a Calatrava bridge as a centrepiece (where we were fortunate to witness a fashion photography shoot) and a permanently docked frigate sailing vessel.

Nice area. This is a very nice area that was renovated recently. It has a number of restaurants and coffee shops. It is a nice area to walk and visit, we did it at night and during the day and we felt very safe.

Clean, architectural, and a place to skate and walk.. Puerto Madero is an upscale neighborhood which has a small port that people boat in, and a park that stretches its length more than a mile i believe. Very busy park, and booardwalk with many restaurants on the water. A few clubs here, a nature preserve walk out to the river, and sometimes concerts. There's a kid's playground by the nature preserve entrance where the fountain and stairs are. Also some five star hotels in the area where Leo Messi stays sometimes. Enjoy!
Good Sightseeing. I enjoyed the local museums and the restaurants. We visited during the day and enjoyed it accompanied by our Argentine friends.

Very clean and very international. We had the best food in some of the restaurants at Madero but also most expensive. We felt very safe in that area probably because it is less touristy than other places.
Nice weather and good sightseeing. Good restaurants and nice weather in November for a walk at night in Puerto Madero area. No many people at night, though.

Loved this area. This was our favourite place in Buenos Aires. Certainly one of the cleanest areas we saw. We strolled for hours and enjoyed a superb lunch at one of the waterfront restaurants. We felt safe here and have talked about this great place to many people since our visit. Plan at least 3 hours here if you stay for a meal and people watch.
Nice walk. Nice walk along the river, lots of restaurants, sail ships, and behind the tall hotels to the reserve for a hike if it's your pleasure.
Nice to walk and eat. Very nice walk on both sides of the canal , reataurants are no cheap but if you only go and have a walk and coffee will have a nice day

Great place to spend time and eat. It's a great place to spend some time, walk around, eat good food, chat with friends and family, maybe catch a movie. There is an imense variaty of restaurants. Seems to be a pretty safe place where you can walk around with no worries (at least in the afternoon). The place is much larger than I thought. Picking a restaurant can be a hard task

Modern, safe and Good Food!!. A special new area in Buenos Aires, see the latest building devolpments by the water. Amazing how an old port was renewed and transformed into a beautiful neighborhood. Restaurants galore in surrounding areas are all first class with good quality service and excellent food. A safe place for bike riding or to visit, day or night the floating Mississippi River Boat Casino nearby.
Nice sightseeing. Great place to visit in Buenos Aires with many restaurant and places to get a dessert. Clean, safety and close of downtown.

A nice place to wander and look.. This area was formerly the dock area for the city. It has been turned into restaurants and shops. It was wonderful to spend a day walking around. There are also two old sailing ships moored there that are fascinating to tour. One was a naval training ship and the other was a smaller ship and actually used in an Antarctic rescue. They were both interesting to tour and I would recommend visiting them both
Nothing special. There are far nicer river fronts in the world. Found this to be quite ordinary. Many huge restaurants but little else to hold our interest. Not sure what all the fuss is about.

There is no better walking place in town. Spend your morning, afternoon or late night walking here and you will always have a good time. Great views, safe environment and lots of cafes, restaurants and shops!

Scenic. Walked up and down the entire length of this part of the city, tons of restaurants and places to sit and enjoy the cool evening and some people watching. Cross the pedestrian bridge to see the locks on the fence left by romantically inclined visiting couples to cement their bond.

Nice Spot. Walked to it from the Hotel Pulitzer. Lovely area to walk. There is a river in the middle and both sides lined with shops and restaurants. Lots of people out exercising, walking there dogs, canoeing or just chilling with the family. Old cargo cranes are painted and used to decorate the area. On one side, there are two ship Museum located in the water offering tours. A Great place to hang out in the day and have dinner at night.

Nice to be at night. Too many restaurant and a nice view/landscape. It worths to spend a night walking and visiting some restaurants. Is the easiest way to have a nice meal, since there are too many choices.

People watching par excellence. The Hilton is 50 metres from the wonderful Puerto Madero waterfront. Sit with a jug of beer and a couple of empanadas and watch the young, the old, the beautiful; the fit and the insane blading, running, roller skating, jogging and skateboarding past between you and the water 10 metres away.In the evening it's lit well and a really safe place for a stroll ..... even well after midnight. Restaurants of all kinds line both sides of the water .... eat late like the locals.A great contrast from my favourite place in BA .... La Boca. Give it a whirl!
Different place. P. Madero is a very important area developed by Rio de la Plata. Very good restaurants, nice parks, good hotels and museums.

Nice place for an evening stroll.... The truth: We were at Puerto Madero only because we were waiting for the ferry to Colonia. But for the couple of hours that we wandered around, we had a lovely time. Would definitely go back some evening to enjoy a leisurely drink by the water.
Great place for walking and eating. Great restaurants.- Expensive. Nice place to walk and to relax. Safe área. Ussualy need a taxicab to get there

Nice place to walk. Its really nice to walk beside the river, has a great view of the bridge and along the main street you can find several good steack restaurants, a must go if you are at Buenos Aires

Nice and calm area in the middle of the city. If you want to get away from all the noise and traffic of the city - this is the place to go. Perfect for a walk, a coffee by the river, or dinner in fancy restaurants.There are also 2 old ships that are museums, which are very recommendable.In the sun you can easily spend hours in this area strolling around and sitting in the sun on one of the many benches.

A nice place to hang around and dine. An interesting area along the old dockside. This is the modern part of BA. The docksides were renovated and now hosts plenty of restaurants and coffee shops. It is very nice, and safe, to stroll around the docksides during any time of day, enjoy the modern BA skyline and to dine in one of the good restaurants. We really enjoyed the evening there.

Puerto Madero,a place where you can walk SAFELY!. It's an old eighborhood that has been completely recycled> Buenos Aires has become a very dangerous city but here you are really safe> Most politicians either live or work there ,so they don't admit any burglars to compete with them!

A really nice place for a walk and dinner. Puerto Madero is the newest neighborhood in Buenos Aires, it's a really safe place, with lots of new building and a huge amount of restaurants. It's a nice place for a walk during the day and also to have dinner, you will find a few of the best restaurants there.

Not the place if you want to know Buenos Aires. As a Porteña, I would never recommend to visit this part of the city if you want to get to know Buenos Aires. True: modern buildings, nice area, revitalized warehouses, full of restaurants. But: only tourists and politicians go there. It is very expensive, and nice. And similar to areas next to the port with piers in New York, Miami or any other city. Buenos Aires is not that area. Buenos Aires is Palermo, Recoleta, La Boca, Belgrano, Parque Patricios... There is so much to see in the city before going to Puerto Madero, that yes, i surely grade it with 4 starts, but if you are in a rush, this will not be your priority for sure.
Vibrant area. Very nice, vibrant, alive area of Buenos Aires, good restaurants, by the water, new buildings, close to cruise ships.

Amazing and Safe place in Argentina. Eat great food in a great restaurant. Visit the full of history Fragata Libertad, walk trough the Woman Bridge, smell the ecologic reserve air with amazing views!!! Puerto Madero is an amazing, modern an complete place with a great architecture to spend the whole
day alone or with your family!

Things to do,. Beside the nice walk and places to eat, also if you walk about 500mts east you will find an entrace to what we call la reserva ecologica, which has a beautyful wiew of the city and is a very plaseant walk, take a camara with you, you will love the wiew. also on sundays evenen in the south exit of la reserva ecologica there is a kind of flee maket and the city provide shows with argentinian music and dance.

Beautiful place!. Puerto Madero is a great place to spend some time when visiting Buenos Aires. The original port, built in 1890 has been renovated as a "gourmet area" where you can taste many of the wonderful argentinian meals, including "asados and empanadas". Beautiful and safe to walk at night, crossing the stunning bridge designed by Spanish architect Calatrava.

great visit. Excellent place to take a walk and visit any of all the coffee shops and restaurants that are in the area. Well protected zone in comparison to the rest of the city. It's a group of recycled buildings from the old port of Buenos Aires. The restaurants are generally overpriced.

Enjoy the river, walk, hace a drink riverside. This was an abandoned place two dacades ago. Now is full of restaurants, boutique hotels, lounges, new buildings, museums. Lovely to walk around after your visit to San Telmo. Keep walking

nice walk and view. if you want to spend some time in walking and enjoying at sunset, i really recommend this place.There are a lot of bars and restaurants. It also has the Woman's bride what is really beautiful.

Good for walk and relax. It's amazing to think that Puerto Madero once was an abandoned place. They really made a great urban project there. it became a good place to walk and relax. I didn´t go to any restaurant there - most of then are overpriced and hyped.

definitely worth a visit in Buenos Aires. Puerto Madero is a great example of urban living in the middle of a big city. The obsolete red brick warehouse buildings at the port were renovated in the 1990's and now house shops, cafes, parilla and other fine restaurants as well as a few US chains such at M'D's, TGF and Burger King, so something for everyone! They is also a floating maritime museum docked there abroad a gorgeous old sailing ship. Cross to the other side of Puerto Madero strolling along the Puente de la Mujere, the Women's Bridge .. the gorgeous, simple design pedestrian swing bridge that elegantly spans the river. The other side of the river has more modern buildings and apartment blocks, the Hilton Hotel as well as some nice shops, cafes and restaurants.Both sides of the river at Puerto Madero are well worth strolling and the views back to the city are lovely from the river .

Underrated Part of the City. I really have no idea why Puerto Madero is as slow as it actually is. It has the Woman's Bridge.. water views, an amazing revitalized warehouse district full of great restaurants; and my favorite part... the Puerto Madero Casino.. right on the water.
Very Pretty and Modern. Puerto Madero was part of our Buenos Aires Private City Tour, it is very modern and pretty. We stopped to have a nice chilled beer while overlooking the water

Loved it. A fascinating combination of old and new architecture, especially Calatrava's stunning Puente de la Mujer footbridge. Hours of fun to be had strolling around, watching the rollerbladers and taking pictures. Like Portishead Marina but bigger and everyone speaks Argentinian Spanish!

Art, Food and Strolling About. Puerto Madero is the totally remade district by the docks. You can walk awhile or take a stroll admiring the modern architecture, bridge and warehouse conversions, and you can stop for a nibble or meal at dozens of cafes and restaurants. We visited the Fortabat art collection which made a pleasant hour of examining works ranging from Argentina's colonial heritage to modern Latin works and contemporary masters. We actuallyvisited Colonia in Uraguay by hydrofoil, (which docks in Puerto Madero) and then spent the late afternoon into evening here, and it was one great day.

Lots of good Restaurants. We finished up at Puerto Madero after half day tour for lunch and found that there were a large range of restaurants to choose from, catering for tastes and how big your wallet was. All of them had a view across the river/water gazing on modern office and hotel complexes. A very modern part of Buenos Aires

Area of chick restaurants. The walkway along the river up to the port is the new gastronomy center of the city; they are however more expensive than similar cuisine served in San Telmo and in Palermo areas.

Clean, interesting, and secure. If you're already in Buenos Aires I would make some time to check this place out. There is a cool park in addition to the updated port area. Lots of great restaurants and shops as well.
great area. nice dock area of BA, excellent for a long walk avoiding the traffic and loads of bars and places to eat

Turisty, But Worth A Visit. This is one of the more popular touristy areas in BA. Only about 20 years old, this modern area is the revitalization of the old run-down harbor area. Restaurants and shops abound on lower levels, with upscale condos above. Prices and crowd are more upscale than other areas, but for a change of pace from the older, historic neighborhoods, it is certainly worth a visit or two.
Great place to visit. Lots of great restaurants and bars in this area, great views across the river. A lovely place to go for a stroll.
Fun area for dining, shopping or morning run. Wide selection of great restaurants and nice views near the waterfront, had dinner here and ran through at sunrise the next morning.
A little bit of Dubai or was it Liverpool?. A great place to walk or go for dinner or have a drink and people watching. It's very safe, easily accessible, up market and lovely in the evening.
Don't miss this neighborhood. Great restaurants; nice for a morning jog; don't miss what's beyond the riverwalk - the ecological reserve. Get your choripan from the food trucks!
Nice for a walk around. Really enjoy this part of BA. Also great to take a walk to the Costanera, to buy a choripan or cheap steak sandwich on the roadsides - perfecto!

Puerto madero. It's a good place to stroll around in the evening, taking in the sights of the workers strolling home from the business district. Good eating places and coffee shops etc. the ship museum would have been a delight for kids although we opted not to view. The bridge is unusual in design and good to see. Nothing really stunning or fascinating for that matter from others ports / docks. An insult to compare Cape Town v& a waterfront which is awesome. Just a good area to chill in the evening but nothing out of his world.

Nice Place for an Evening Stroll and Dinner. The modern and very clean Puerto Madero area of BA is a perfect place to take a nice stroll before or after dinner. There are a number of very good, high-end restaurants here to tempt anyone's taste, though pricy for BA standards. A wonderful pedestrian only promenade takes you in a large circle on two opposite banks of an inland waterway called the Dique and across two bridges, one is very modern and quite scenic. After dinner, grab a dulce de leche ice cream at Freddo, a great BA ice cream establishment, and take a nice stroll. The lights are beautiful.
Great renovation. We ate dinner in a lovely restaurant overlooking the water, and even at midnight families were strolling. It is a great area.
Plenty of great restaurants. An oasis of peace away from the traffic where you can walk at leisure, or just stop for a snack and watch the world go by.

Lovely stroll by the river docks!. This is the best alternative to the dirty crowded and traffic noisy streets downtown. Go there mid morning and make an appetite to sit at one of the many steakhouses which are not cheap but in most cases offer a set price menu for lunch.
Scenic. Beautiful walk along the river. Clean, safe and tentiptive with food.In the evening the scenario is beautiful.
Interesting newly renovated dock area. It's a interesting are with lots of restuarants and office areas.we liked the openness and the whole dock area has been renovated with interesting elements.
Gorgeous area. Really nice, well laid out, brand new. Lots of private security and amazing views across the river. Lots of attention to detail with random water fountains.

Redeveloped Port Area with lots of restaurants. Puerto Madero was a defunct area when I first visited BA in the early 1990's and in 15+ years has been developed into one of the hot spots in the city with offices, hotels,condos and numerous top rated restaurants. You can go down there and walk the canal area checking each restaurant out, if you so desire.
Great place to walk around. Long stretch of restaurants and and couple bars, but mostly high end restaurants. Had a couple nice breaks on a 4 hour walk through the area.

Upscale and lots of restuarant choices. We ate at Marcelo's Italian restaurant and the walked the bridge and surrounding area after dinner. There are a lot of nice and good quality restaurants and bars to choose from. I was told to make a reservation and did. The riverfront is nice for an after dinner stroll.

Upscale neighborhood in Bs As. This is a newer and modern neighborhood in Bs As. Nice to go when nice out to walk around its parks and streets. It offers a few variety of restaurants and shops. It does not have a lot to offer just yet.
Beautiful area. very nice place to bike ride, run, or walk... away from traffic and pollution. lots of nice restaurants and cafes; great place to just hang out.
Nice. Its a nice area to tour and stop by for a bite to eat -- but not a lot of shade -be prepared with an umbrella or hat for cover. It get very hot!
Great spot. Great spot to have a coffee, glass of wine or a meal by the docks, especially on a nice warm afternoon.

Very beautiful . This is the best place in Buenos Aires, quite nice to walk by and lots of restaurants.
Very beautiful at day and night.
Restaurants. Very pretty view of the river, especially at night with all the lights, our favorite restaurant is Las Lilas, the service was superb and the food was exceptional

Feels like Manhattan devoid of people. There is no reason to spend any time here unless you are heading to the top notch restaurant in this area. There are high rises and some museums, but the place is bland and boring.
Vacation. Loved knowing Puerto Madero. A simply beautiful and fascinating place. The buildings, the people, the atmosphere is great. The architecture of the buildings is amazing.

Place for tourists. If you want to know the argentinian way of life this is not the place.
There are good restaurants but also bad ones.
The view is beautiful and that is it.

And so it came to pass that ..................... Argentina finally realised that if it smartened up its capital and had an area of luxury flats (there are hundreds of them) and restaurants then the money would flood in. This area goes against the Socialist ideals of successive governments and is a welcome escape from the stifling amounts of traffric that choke the city. This area is the old docks area which has been renovated to a VERY high level.... think St Katherine´s Dock in London ,,, but think 6 times bigger. This is a credit to the capital and should hopefully inspire the powers to be to clean up the rest of the city! Go there to promendade along the pathways that now line the four docks.

Lovely. Lovely waterfront, a mix of the old and new, all 6km of it if you walk all of the way round. Great places to eat all round the harbour, literally dozens. There is also a couple of large masted sailing briggs/museums moored in the water. The area is also just off the Plaza de Mayor and really quite convenient. Only down side...the water is a murky brown akin to a Welsh river in spate after heavy rain. It's caused by silt coming down the Parana river, not anybody's fault but unattractive if your used to a nice bit of aqua azul. Hence the loss of a star.
Romantic. I was there many times. Day and night, I prefer it at night mainly less crowded and all lit up. Theres many bars and restaurants right on the water.
Nice cafés and restaurants. Pleasant walking along the marina and stopping for a coffee or very nice ice creamFelt completely safe walking about

Day and night - unforgettable!. I read hints about making a visit by day and by night, i decided to do both. I didn't regret! The sight is lovely, there's many restaurants and bars open until late at night, so you can enjoy a long walk by the docks.

Wonderful renovation of the old port. Puerto Madero is one of first port areas of Argentina. Although it was a planned and well-designed area, it was not ever really used due to the river not being suitable for this task. Over the past 20 years, this area has been cleaned up, and revitalised into a buzzing and exciting restaurant and accommodation precinct. With its close proximity to the central shopping district, Casa Rosada and other tourist areas, it is a perfect place to visit for a long walk or for a meal. New Year's Eve fireworks are also launched from this location. The yacht club and on the other side, roller skaters and skateboarders make this a pretty and interesting historical, but modern recreation area.

Not the most interesting. Puerto Madero offers lots of places to eat but other than that, there isn't much to do. Walking around this area wasn't that memorable. Given other places in the city like Palermo, Recoleta and the Plaza de Mayo, this area really isn't all that interesting. To give you an idea, I am a person that takes a lot of pictures but I didn't take a single picture of this area of the city since I wasn't at all impressed. If you do go, I'd recommend going for lunch or a dinner only.
Wonderful Location. Nice walks along the quay. Tons of restaurants. Away from the hustle & bustle. Love this quarter of BA

The other side of Buenos Aires. Very modern, sometimes flashy and interesting. This is the last part of Buenos Aires to be developed. As they say "Buenos Aires has its back to the river, because the immigrants did not want to go back to where they came from at all", but here it is opening up towards the river. Nice buildings, hotels, parks and avenues.
Nice for walks, beautiful landscape.. Beautiful place with lots of restaurants. Especially at night, you will find a beautiful landscape! Nice for long walks too!
Great for a walk. Really nice place to go around for a walk and take pictures, really nice restaurants around the area

Lovely place for walking, enjoying a drink and of course eating.. I loved the place. Its very relaxing, good for walking and sipping a drink whilst listening to music. Restaurants are good, some pricey but others well priced.

One of the nicest areas we found.. I liked this area, great for walking and dining. Great restaurants with views of the river and bridge -relaxing walk over the bridge - only negative at night is the mosquitoes! so bring repellent. We ate at Spettus- which was excellent churrasqueria/steak house- not for those on a budget.

Fantastic restaurants!. Great to walk around. Decent places to have a beer. Touristy but in a good way. Wonder who the architect is who designed the bridge? Norman Foster? Would be interested to know.

Bright spot in BA. This area is really nice. What a surprise. Warehouses converted to restaurants. Many steak and italian restaurants for you to enjoy. Plus, boats and other items on the river. Beautiful bridge for walking across. You must try an Argentina steak
Pretty place. The only one problem in that place is the price of things hehehe. However you have to visit there and enjoy amazing buildings and the famous Ponte de La Mujer

Lovely. It´s a lovely place to walk, have an ice cream and simply enjoy the view and the company.
It´s simple a river side place with a lot of restaurants. Good to relax.

Puerto Madero. Good place to visit at anytime during the day. Good for a walk along the quay, visit to a museum or simply have an ice, a beer or a great dinner at one of the several Steakhouses. Expect higher prices!!!

Well worth the walk along the waterfront. After a torrid morning walking through the San Telmo market, being sprayed with a sauce bottle (usual attempt to scam the tourist - and having my cardigan ruined), it was a relief to detour to the river front and walk along the peaceful wide promenade without any potholes or broken paving. Lots of very classy looking restaurants and an extremely good ice cream shop - can't remember the name but it is on the riverside corner where Hungry Jacks is located on the cityside corner. Puerto Madero is a break from the narrow streets and gives you a refreshing space of open air to breathe in, plus some fantastic views.

Great Space to Stroll or Dine. My husband and I enjoyed this area a few times. Sometimes we just walked the area and enjoyed a cold beer or a coffee and other times we sat on the outdoor patio of one of the many restaurants for lunch or dinner. This area is popular with locals and visitors alike. There is a lot to see and do here so take some time and enjoy it. Prices are higher for dining, but there are less expensive establishments and times are options.

An air of Melbourne, Sydney, Auckland.... BA is located by the widest river in the world... Therefore it feels like a sea and 10 years ago was build Puerto Madero, a rich business district by the water. It's the only area in town with skyscrapers and that's why, when I was walking on the docks I felt like in another major harbour city.Its secret though is an ecological reserve at its edge where you completely forget you are in the busiest capital city of South America! A green jewel to relax and chase away the city blues!
Modern Buenos Aires . A must go when in Buenos Aires. The place is nice and clean, many restaurants and boutique stores and great views. A very nice place to walk.
A must to go place. Puerto Madero is one of the must to go places in Buenos Aires, with excellent restaurants and a magnific 'coast' road to walk along. Very well designed.
Puerto MAdero. very safe area with lots of restaurantes, to me the ebst iof Buenos Aires + all good hotels like the HILTIN is right there

A different type of Buenos Aires.... I like the area, Very clean, neat, lots of nice restaurants. The view in the afternoon is amazing. When the sun sets, you can see the reflex in the glass buildings and it was beautiful. The "Fragata Sarmiento" is there, you can pay 2 pesos ( less than $0.50 cents and go inside. It's a museum. Nice short visit to do something different.This is the new fancy area of Buenos Aires....In a hot day, you can walk by the river and you'll feel in a different place.
Nice place. Is a nice place, where you can see the arquitecture of buenos aires, also you can drink a cooffe in Starbucks while you are walking so is really beautiful place.

overlooked and spetacular. a repurposed section of the city,, formerly the port area's warehouses. The old buldings have been transformed into cafes, the old hoists and other port equipment remain as if scultptures..all alongside a canal. GREATDAY
Nice area, good parks. We had the best choripam ever at The Costanera! It was cheap and it looks it is for local people. The are of the docks is nice although it is very trendy... I liked it!
Nice area for dinner and strawl. Nice place to spend your evening in BA and get some good italian or Argentinian food in that area facing the port. Great place to go after 10PM.

Nice place just outside the city center. This is a nice place just outside the city center and in walking distance to many nice little restaurants. Definitely one of the better 'free' things to do close to the centre to keep you occupied during the day. This will not remain on my 'must see list' but always worth a look around if you're looking for something to do!
A lot of fun. We stayed at this area in the Hilton. Nice area, lots of bars and restaurants. We even saw some singing events as well. Really nice to walk around. Clean and safe
the ship visit. now have the option to visit the ancient war ship as well,ideal passea for the day, the night has many options for taking photo

A place to walk, eat, see and fall in love. Puerto Madero is an old port, transformed into a place to live, eat, jog, enjoy and love, old red bricks warehouses turned into apartments buildings and restaurants, offer to locals and visitors alike a great mixture of places to eat from traditional Italian, to sushi, to mexican, to true argentinian BBQ, is a MUST SEE on your trip to Argentina
good walk. Lot of restaurants, but sort of expensive. Very good to walk. the view of the bay is pretty awesome!Get away from the taxis guys who try to sells rides to an outlet neighbor, it's a trap!

Beautiful place to take a walk. Puerto Madero is beautiful, the argentinians tend to say it's a whole different world from Buenos Aires as it houses the richest of the rich in Argentina. It's beautiful even if you're just taking a walk. A lot of good places to eat and the view is great.

Worth a walk by. This was a stop on the bike tour that I did in Buenos Aires. It is exactly what you expect, a bridge. It's worth a stop, some pictures, and maybe a walk around for a few minutes. That's about it.
Nice Part of Town, If you can Afford It. Puerto Madero is a wonderful spot for a stroll or a lunch on the harbor that was never used. It is the Recoleta for the new money. It is plenty safe.

Nice new area with the best restaurants. This is the newest area with all of the best restaurants. We ate in Lilas which was wonderful and in Osaka which was equally enjoyable. Just be aware that after eating at Lilas we were able to walk around, Osaka was on the wrong side and we jumped right into a cab to get back to our hotel

A must-see in Buenos Aires. Walk through this "neighbourhood" of Buenos Aires to see and experience what a city can do with reclaimed land and old docklands. We were blown away! Very impressive buildings indeed! Lovely Bridge of the Woman representing a couple dancing tango and trendy restaurants and cafes along the waterfront

Modern, beautiful & peaceful!. This is the newest neighborhood at Buenos Aires City and also is one of the most modern ones. During the evenings this place is peaceful and quiet you can do long walks from one dock to the other and on the way you ll see nice restaurants, bars and upscale shops all along the river. Enjoy a meal & drinks with your friends at Puerto Madero! It worths!

A city inside a city. This place amazed me because I never thought of finding such a modern place. It's like a small new city born inside the older one.Lots of shops, restaurants and beautiful sidewalks.Visit the Fragata (an old school boat)

Brilliant modern district. Puerto Madero is a modernistic upscale district of Buenos Aires featuring high-rise residential buildings, canals, warehouses converted into lofts and restaurants and Puente de la Mujer by Santiago Calatrava. An excellent choice if you are after a nice meal, cool late night drink or just a nice stroll or jogging ground
Lovely ambience !!. Beautiful area both,at night all lit up and during the day. The restaurants,although pricey are worth a visit

Nice lunch. We found ourselves in this area for lunch as well as to see Rosa Tango. The bridge of the man and women is thought provoking. I'm glad I visited but also glad I chose not to stay in this area.

enjoy a relax walk around. needless to say this is a place where many tourists want to be however not all restaurants and bars are good. get some advise from your hotel concierge and book in advance. be also careful with pick pockets, I witnessed a couple getting stolen when sitting on the terrace of a restaurant. overall you will find the ambiance is really nice so definitely worth to pay a visit and plan diner

Not that impressive, just average.. Buenos Aires can be compared to other cities by the sea, such as Sydney for example. However, compared to the Sydney harbour, Puerto Madero isn't anything special. There are some interesting things to acknowledge such as the Fragata ARA Sarmiento, and the Puente De La Mujer. There is also a large ecological reserve close by that is worth a visit. The port itself isn't anything to get too excited about though. As to be expected there are lots of restaurants and shops nearby. Worth a visit, but an average experience.

Delightful Redevelopment of the Old Port. We visited Puerto Madero during the day and at night. Both were delightful. During the day, you can admire the beautiful reuse of old warehouses into multi-use buildings with residential, restaurant and office uses. At night, the Women's Bridge by Santiago Calatrava is a masterpiece, well lighted in the old ship channel, a pedestrian connection between the two sides. Many restaurants are in the area and several hotels.
Beautiful!. Take some time to walk through Porto Madero and take some pictures. Also choose a restaurant to eat a nice meal with a perfect view!

The New BA offers something for everyone.... Liked the concentration of restaurants in one place and within very short walking distance from Hilton.
Disliked that there was no guide to the places....we relied on trial and error in our choices...and there truly are good, better and best in Puerto Madero

Beautiful architecture, could have a little more to experience!. This is a more residential/business neighborhood of BAs. The restaurants are not the best, and it's distant from most of other city's atractions. Taxis are hard to see at night! Worths for the visit of Puente de la Mujer, and the best hotels in BAs, if this is your preference for accomodation.
Sexy and chic. Go around, have dinner at el mercado in the Faena.... walk the bridge and breathe the upscale Buenos Aires of the last two decades..

Getting better. Visited Puerto Madera in 2011 and thought it may be worthwhile having another visit- it has had considerable new development since then and has many good looking restaurants and cafes. It is extremely safe for visitors and the information stall on the city side was useful and the staff most helpful.

A place for a wander.. Lots of restaurants and cafes, of course touristy so expensive. Dock areas are quite interesting to look at, but there's nothing major happening around here except loads of people. Beware people eyeing up your belongings. 1-2 hours plus food, or a visit to the close-by ecological reserve.

Best restaurants in town. Being in Buenos Aires, you will eat steaks (sorry if you are a vegetarian). This is what they do best.In this area you find vinotecas and churrasquerias for all budgets and all occasions. Avoid the typical tourist places with tango and music. My suggestion, one thing at a time... If you are there to eat, eat. You will find tango places later. The folklore often is an excuse for poor food...
Nice Area away from the city bussle. Nice place to visit and plenty of places to eat.....also recommend walking around the park area allow yourself 2hrs and stroll slowly around

A bit over rated. Think this area is a bit over rated. It's very modern with some decent places to walk around but if you're from a develop global city there really isn't much to see here other than some over priced restaurants.

Totally redone. This area has been totally revamped during the last ten years. It is very touristy and an easy walking area, whereas most of the rest of Buenos Aires is not. A busy commercial district. Lots of tourist restaurants, all busy.

Touristy, Expensive. They've done a nice job revitalizing the area, but it's just a bunch of expensive restaurants. If that's your thing, you should check it out, but we were more interested in historic and cultural BA.

A more modern side of Buenos Aires. This part of the city didn't exist, at least not the way it looks today, when I first visited Buenos Aires many years ago. Today is a place full of high modern buildings and great restaurants. If you are planning to have dinner somewhere there and it's already cold, don't forget to visit also by day. It get's very cold there by night, as there is a lot of open space and the wind can make you run to get a cab and go back to your Hotel.

OK but nothing special. I don't know if I'm missing something but this place had nothing special. Long brick bldgs that were old warehouses and a walkway with lots of eating places, none looked that special. Bought delicious ice cream in one of them. 2 historic ships that are small museums, no big deal. Roller blade lessons, graffiti and a dirty river were the sights. Also people in South America litter like crazy. I suggest see it and make up your own mind only to judge it against all the other districts.

The best place to visit. Puerto Madero is one of the best place to visit, a beautiful intra costal view walking area with plaza seats to relax and enjoy the view, lot of restaurants, aboard to Fragata Sarmiento today converter on marine museum. There is also a Casino where the food is so good and all you can eat. Casino is building in a real boat.

Lunchtime on the waterfront. Plenty to look at, including 2 historic ships the .Uruguay and the Sarmiento. Good choice of nice restaurants, easy walk back to Retiro where our hotel was. DONT stray too far away from here, the commercial port is a bit rough!

Riverside, Buenos Aires style.. You can walk along the area, with several restaurants that caters to all budgets (from Burger King or McDonalds to gourmet food).It is the frontier between old Buenos Aires and the modern tall buildings where corporate and financial companies are domiciled.The Universidad Catolica Argentina is also located at Puerto Madero.

Rather anodyne. Puerto Madero could be a dockside development anywhere in the world. I've been a couple of times and there's nothing really 'porteno' about it. It's difficult to get to via public transport and the area between it and the nature reserve behind is not particularly salubrious. Looking around the good ship Sarmiento, docked near the elegant Puente de la Mujer, is a worthwhile diversion, though.

Very good location to stay. I was lucky to live there. Having two sides of promenade, beautiful and comfortable, with great views, full of good restaurants, cafes, old-ship-museums, and having a great gallery. Close to downtown. In the evenings a guy with three telescopes on the street shows beautiful argentinian moon for the tips. Feel safe there and comfortable at any time.
Awesome. My favorite place in whole Buenos Aires, this place is really relaxing and the restaurants near there are amaizing! you can drink a beer or eat with an amazing view to the river
Visit other things if time is short. Puerto Madero is certainly a niece part of town but consists mostly of overly expensive restaurants and shops. Spend more time elsewhere.

Excellent location for day and night Dining. We visited this area several times during our recent trip to BA. Be sure to explore all the docks 1 through 4 and on both sides of the river. You will find every possible dining option for every possible budget. Well worth the visit.
Modern with no character. Went thru neighborhood on hop on/hop off tour bus. This area is very modern with little to no character as found in the rest of BA.

Nice new area in Buenos Aires. I like Puerto Madero a lot! Huge new open-space area with nice riverside and lots of open-air cafes + restarantes. I can spend there whole day just enjoying sun and wind and cappucino ;)There is nice new bridge and one old ship for check it out as well. For those who like space - it's one of the best place in BA.

Great Tango and dinner show. This Tango show was modern but included a lot of different styles....very professional. Meal was excellent and included beer and wine. Got a special rate by paying in US dollars at the show, hotel had arranged the booking and transport to and from.

Good place to visit if you are in Buenos Aires. Restaurants, cafés, some museums, and a bit of history in a place well located and safe at any hour of the day or night.Long list of restaurants to recommend..Walking along the piers is quite nice.
Great place to visit. This is a very nice place to visit, it has restaurants with all the typical Argentinian food, great meat and so on. Go visit it if you ar in Buenos Aires.

Restaurants, cafes, place for the kids to run around. A touristic area with lots of restaurants- fancy ones next to reasonable prices ones. We love going with the kids- they can roller blade there, run around, eat ice cream. Also, most restaurants in Buenos Aires open at 8:30pm for dinner. For those who eat earlier than that, most of Puerto Madero's restaurants are open all day.

Nice place to walk around. Its an old port area that was renovated and now has hotels & restaurants along the water. Its a great place to walk and great people watching especially when the weather is nice or on a weekend. However, I found the restaurants on the water are very expensive and average at best; a bit disappointing to me. Also, a great place to go for a run; especially in the morning when few are out.
Place to go in Buenos Aires !!. Beautiful place to visit, quite peaceful. You can a lot of restaurants where you can eat and drink. I recommend this place.

A different place to visit!. Puerto Madero is my most beloved place in Buenos Aires. It has a truly unique atmosphere of a blend of the new and old. Puerto Madero had been designed as a freight port, but later the design was found inadequate and its usage was terminated. Many years the area stayed abandoned, but in the nineties the renovation started which turned Puerto Madero into one of the most luxurious neighborhoods of Argentina and, possibly, of South America. The old red-brick warehouses were refurbished preserving their original texture and color. Even the dock cranes were preserved and painted! One of those houses the tourist information desk. You can find some of the best restaurants and cafes of Buenos Aires there, many of which, however, are quite affordable for a middle-class customer. There are several wonderful museums in Puerto Madero, two of which are ships (Corbeta Uruguay and Fragata Sarmiento). There also are several arts museums such as the great Fortabat Art Collection and the exhibition hall of Universidad Catolica Argentina, which is also quite interesting. If the weather is fine one can have a great time just strolling along the Diques, enjoying the views and a refreshing breeze, watching the kayaks sailing to and fro...

The ex-Docklands in Buenos Aires. Excellent, well designed, sophisticated, fun, vibrant.Whether you go there early in the morning, lunch time, afternoon or at night this is an excellent part of the City. During week days you can share with local that works there or visit the area for lunch. Popular for business men.I would easily live there :-)

newest neighborhood in buenos aires.... nice place to go to... quite different in weekends compared to weekdays... both nice... you can walk, bike, roll, eat, etc... enjoyable.... great at night, many of restaurants with outside or inside dining... great during daytime... just sit and relax on a cool sunny day...
cosmopolitan area of Buenos Aires

The old port of Buenos Aires. During the day a busy hub for business, and some tourists, whereas a balmy night really brings out both tourists and Argentinians alike. The refurbished warehouses and a really old schooner vessel and old fashioned port cranes, lend a maritime atmosphere, which is truly magical. It`s not the sea you are looking at , but a river, but it all really blends in, coupled with great security, as the Coast Guard is in charge there not the ordinary pólice, and that really makes a lot of difference. The multitude of restaurant gives the whole área an incredible ambiance, so on a warm night this place is very hard to beat.

perfect for lunch or dinner and a stroll. Like the London south bank, Puerto Madero has that mixed flavour of docks and chic restaurants, modern buildings and expensive shops. Branches of river on both sides, the city close enough to reach Puerto Madero by all means of transportation makes it a very populated place, tourists and locals alike.I love to have lunch on Sundays on a sunny table watching people walk by with my dog at my feet and a gorgeous meal in front of me. Don´t miss it.
"The cool place". New places are open on the daily basis. Great places to eat, to run or just hung up with your friends. Spend time there and eat a "choripan" close to the river… You will enjoy it.

Very popular. Great place to visit and to taste very good food, and wines.It's the old customs and port facilities. New restaurants are located in refurbished and upgraded places, from Buenos Aires .Last century.Very nice at night.Very relax at lunch.
Old area renewed. The porto madera extends along the old port area of BA with modern office buildings, lofts, restaurants and cafes. A very lovely place to stroll and dine during the day.

Nice river view. This boardwalk was built not long ago and has filled with restaurants and bars ever since. It has a nice view of the river, especially at night, and of course many, many restaurants, most of them quite expensive. So if you´re looking for a nice place to stroll and get some of the river breeze, this is the place. If you want to have dinner and have a bit of money to spend, it´s worth it.

Nice walk to get around of this new part of the city. There is people in Buenos Aires that hate this neighborhood and people that loves it.Its a (quite) new development of the city so it looks like a maquette sometimes.Nice view of downtown Buenos Aires from a river perspective and also good place to skate, make a bike tour or just seat in a nice cafe and enjoy a cup of coffee.Gor a cultural visit you can visit the Fundacion Fortabat Museum and the Faena Arts Center.

best part the city. Puerto Madero is a place that you cannot miss if you are in Buenos Aires. Its a place full of parks and high rises. You also have very good choices of street food and obviously the best and cheapest hamburger of Buenos Aires.

The newest and coolest neighbor. Puerto Madero is the newest neighbor in Buenos Aires. A former dock area, it has been renewed with cool restaurants and bars, with a variety of food offerings (from Starbucks to La Estancia). After a good barbecue you can stroll through the Reserva Ecológica, a nice coastal park nearby. There are cinemas also, and the only casino in Buenos Aires.

A "must" of Buenos Aires. The newest borough of Buenos Aires grew after recycling most of the old docks and warehouses of the old port. Great place for strolling, dinner, fresh air in summer days and a very nice sightseeing of the city.
Nice place with lots of restaurants. Definitely a place to go in BA. Lot's of nice restaurants with good price. Italian, bbq, hamburgueres, ice cream..

docklands revamped. This is one of the few areas in Buenos Aires where you can get an idea of the fact the city is built on the widest river in the world!
About 20 years ago the old docklands began to be redone and today hosts, restaurants , art galleries and a lovely walk. Don´t miss!

Cosmopolitan. Beautiful area for strolling, eating and people watching by day. Great night time venue with an abundance of restaurants with outside or inside dining. Very cosmopolitan area of Buenos Aires. Worth a visit especially on a lovely sunny day!!

Sempre uma boa opção para visitar. Puerto Madero has always been a good place to visit in Buenos Aires... Great place to come, walk around and pick a place to eat, out of the mant types of restaurants available. Worth your time
Great place for afternoon or dinner. Great place to visit - great restaurants and food, good wine and shops. Don't miss Rojo Tano at Faena. Expensive but worth it (not for under 18).

It's the place to go in B.A.. Exceptional food is available at a number of restaurants in this swanky district. The last time I was there I enjoyed grilled Chilean Sea Bass with a white wine and caper sauce. I ordered a bottle of Argentine Malbec and spent a couple of hours enjoying the view and people watching from my table. Exceptional service, great dining locations, and museum type attractions all are offered in the Puerto Madera area. Don't miss it!

The new face of Buenos Aires. Puerto Madero is the new upper classes neighborhood of Buenos Aires. It follows the trend of redevelopment of city ports like Chelsea in London, with its own personality. The modernity, the open spaces, the air, the proximity to the river, the nature are exceptional. It is a bit remote but you can access the shopping mall and restaurants by bus.

Great place to chill. Spent almost an entire afternoon just chilling in Puerto Madero. The views are pretty, the wind is gorgeous and I chatted with a few random locals who were hanging out in the area during their lunch breaks. Restaurants are pretty pricey, but if you are up for just sitting there with a good book and a nice view, it is perfect.

A waste of time. Unless you're staying at one of the hotels in Puerto Madero, there's really no reason to go. Sure, the ecological center is nice for a run, but the place isn't well kept, or with good signage, plus recently, over a ton of dead fish washed up to shore and they were put into garbage bags and just left along the river bank, making the smell just terrible, which is just a step down from the normal smell of the Rio de la Plata. The habitable area is just new buildings with overpriced/low quality restaurants below and overpriced and poorly built apartments above, and sadly, we happened upon the area when Justin Bieber was in town taking over the Faena with gaggles of screaming protenas of the tween set which didn't help at all in making this a worth while sojourn for the day. There are so many other fascinating barrios in BA that one can easily avoid Puerto Madero.

Nice place to eat. There are lots of restaurants in the area, from buffet all you can eat (lots of options, good price but not very good meat) to more expensive ones. Siga la Vaca is very traditional, but I personally do not think this is the best meet. Cabaña las Lillas is expensive, with excellent meat.

Nice sights not much more. Puerto Madero is a good place to ride a bike or if you like seeing new buildings and some under construction. Being the richest area of the city its filled with nice buildings but the prices of everything are more expensive than the rest of the city as well. It's one of the things you have to do in Buenos Aires if the weather is nice but don't plan a day around it.

More cities need to do this. What a great example of urban revitalization.This is one of the best things BA has done in years.They took the dilapidated old port and made it the new hot spot, bring people down to the port, and the area is safe as well. Lots of restaurants + lots of tourists = lots of cash for the BA Govt.

Great place to run walk and eat dinner. Ran and also walked along the river and later dined at Sigue la Vaca (follow the cow). Super food and atmosphere! It was totally packed on a Thursday night. We had to wait 30 minutes but it was worth it. We walked around north to south to kill the wait. The breeze was invigorating.

Another fancy area. Just like many other ones... A very expensive area, very clean but with no charmin at all... there´s noone who can really live here. Only turistics things and nice parks! Good to pass by for a few minutes only!
Colonial copycat. Looks just like the south bank of London's River Thames, think Butlers WarfHigh priced (for Arg standards) but quality food. Very long windy walk!
Lovely in the sun.. This area is full of eateries. You can walk and watch boats, see the old cranes and marvel at the lovely new walking bridge.
Water views. This area is new and pretty touristy. But worth the trip to check it out. Lots of good upscale restaurants to check.

Great options and the modern side of BsAs. I was in BsAs for a business trip and my office was located 10 mins walk from puerto Madero - it was great as I we had so many options for lunch and dinner without getting the same steak and wine offer the entire time, moreover a nice walk next to the water.

Redeveloped Boardwalk on the Water. Puerto Madero is the modern face of Buenos Aires, right on the river with upscale restaurants, apartments and hotels. Perhaps lacking some of the classic charm of other parts of the city, but clean and pretty

New, clean and modern. I understand from co-workers living in the area that Puerto Madero was the original port which had been completely renovated a few years back after the main shipping port moved further north towards AEP airport. Lots of new restaurants, shops and Hilton which looked very nice from the outside. Lots of security and felt totally safe walking there at night. My only knock is that the area lacks character and you wouldn't know you were in BA vs any other new/modern waterfront part of a city.

Safe area to walk off excellent meals. This is the newest and safest area of the city located in the redeveloped area of the old port. There is a multitude of very good to excellent restaurants, although they can be expensive. Walking in this area after a late dinner is recommended as it is well lit and patrolled by the Cost Guard. The Puente de la Mujer (Women's Bridge) is the newest link between the east and west docks of Puerto Madero.
Lovely for strolling. A modern area Close to the river. I liked the skill of all the dogwalkers keeping up to 12 dogs on leaches. Restaurants on the expensive side.

Beautiful place for a drink in a sunny afternoon. We went there on a Saturday afternoon, really sunny and it was great! Drinks and food are expensive, but you are in one of the special places in BA - it is worth going and walking along the water and bars
Very nice place to walk!. New part of the city, very modern but organized and a lot of good restaurants. I liked the view and the boats?

Walking by the channels of the Buenos Aires harbor. Nice to see a piece of town that homage the WOMAN, all the streets has woman names and even a park was built in their honor. Nice to visit la Fragata Sarmiento as well, an old ship from Argentinian history.

Nice place to walk on a nice day but not necessarily a highlight. The port area is pretty and was especially nice on a spring day. However, while there were a number of restaurants along the river, they seemed a bit overpriced and not necessarily worth eating there. If you have limited time in the city, I would not go out of your way to visit this area. On the other hand, if you want a nice walk or run or bike ride along the river, its a good option. There are a few nice shops, but only a handful.The nicest place in my mind was the Central Market, which had a take-away area with nice dessert and coffee.

amazing at night. Puerto Madero is an incredible place to visit, whereas you do it during the day with your bike/skate or at night. Although, at night it is one of the best places to go in the city, if not the best, since it is packed of great restaurants (which are a bit pricey as well) and the skyline view at night is unique.

Spent our first morning.... In Buenos Aires for 11 days, spent the first morning exploring this area. Nice waterfront, sucky water colour though... buildings are well restored, nice vistas. The bridge is neat, probably sexier at night as per photos we've seen. The Frigate parked in the locks is quite impressive to visit and worth the stroll on itself.

Love it.. I know everyone thinks it a tourist trap, but it's a great place to go for a walk and drink in the environment. People watch and eat good food. Most of the restaurants have lunch specials that you can see from roadside of puerto madero.

Argentinean South Street Seaport. As a native New Yorker I found Puerto Madero to be a welcoming sight as I felt I was at South Street Seaport. The quantity and quality of restaurants in this area are amazing and varied so there is something for everyone. We found a casual bar called Bar Bull that was typical bar food, eighties music and fun. Would definitely go back here. Also, Mexcian restaurant, DF was very nice.
Waterfront. As in many cities the old river front has been upgraded and there are lots of restaurants and bars and nice areas to stroll about. We had a buffet lunch at La Bisteca which was splendid.

Hit the docksides and enjoy the day.. Recently renovated dockside area in a section of Buenos Aires, this has many restaurants and a few shops to boot. There is a ship/ museum to see there and wonderful long and lovely promenades on both sides of the canal/port. It is comprised not only of professional commercial offices, but also a working dock area as well as the restaurants. It is interesting to watch and stroll in the area during the daytime. Like another reviewer noted, a sunny day would be best but there is no shade, so plan accordingly. I'm not sure about it at night. Our group enjoyed the area so much, that even though we were only in town a few days, we went there twice. Nearby is a ecological garden, but it was closed at the time we were there.

Nice area to visit for lunch and a stroll. Really pretty area for walking and dining. Located on the water it is a nice area to stroll on a pretty afternoon. There is a lovely park in the center of the area and some pretty buildings to see. Most of the buildings are newer, more modern structures so it is an interesting contrast with the older buildings across the bridge.
Could be anywhere. Clean, yep. Good, way overpriced restaurants, yep. Newly built expensive places to live, yep. Sanitized, yep. Interesting, nope.
nice, quaint area. was old shipyard with huge buildings converted to restaurants and shops. Very pretty, by the water and a more expensive part of town. Nice to visit and see the sights.

pick a sunny day to visit. Puerto Madera is made up of various shops and restaurants on the waterfront.it is quite exposed so to fully appreciate this excellent area, pick a sunny day to visit.great selection of restaurants just a short taxi ride from the centre
Lovely walk. Very romantic to walk and pick a place to eat. The restaurants in this area are quite expensive but it's one of the best places in Buenos Aires.

Nice place (but be aware). Beautiful place, right by the water the photos are amazing. Went on a Sunday and walking while the sun was setting was really beautiful. I thought I would find better options for restaurants. We really struggled to go back to the hotel, there were no taxis at 9 pm, we had to walk (3 young men followed us, that part was really scary but we walked really fast and they lost us). Also remember to bring a jacket even thought it's hot during the day because when the evening starts, the wind can be freezing.

Like Europe, but not where it belongs. It's a place that is very Europe like where there should be something else, like a trully Argentinian scene.It's something we've all seen and that I fear all the cities tend to.Hated It!
very nice area. I would recommend this area any time you are in BA !!! It's more hip, cleaner and has nice hotels, bars and restaurants.

Eating in a restaurant in Puerto Madero. You have to walk in Puerto Madero by night and stop in one of the many restaurants you will find. they are all pretty much the same... Order à Bife de Chorizo, if you like beef...

Good place to take a promenade. Nice port. A lot of pubs, bars, restaurants and a cute pedestrian bridge in the middle of the port. You can arrive at any hour, even late in night. The just opened a Mcdonalds place, coffee shop included. They have benches and amusements at any hour of the day.
Citi Life for Cool Folks. Good restaurants, beautiful views of the river, and an old ship to visit. Careful leaving the area, though, as there is a dangerous area close by.
Beautiful. Great neighborhood to go after a day of sightseeing and shopping and have dinner there. The best restaurants with a lovely view.

RELAX IN PEACE, NEAR THE CITY CENTRE. Puerto Madero is a re-develped docklands area of Buenos Aires. It has numerous parks and play areas for children as well as wide roads and boulevards. All the roads and walking areas are evenly surfaced and ideal for recreational uses, such as jogging, skateboarding and roller blading. It is amply supplied with cafes, restaurants and bars. All within a few minutes walk of the city centre.Presumably this is why it is a mecca for the city inhabitants (portenos) at weekends and public holidays - especially during the warmer months. There is a reasonably sized supermarket located towards the eastern end of the area.Puerto Madero is generally expensive when compared to the surrounding districts, but this does not seem to deter locals and tourists alike, from visiting the area.There is also a large nature reserve in the area immediately adjoining the River Plate and next to Av. Int. Hernan M. Giralt. This same avenue boasts a host of 'parillas' or open air, semi-permanent outside grills or bar-be-ques.They serve simple grilled foods such as steak sandwiches, sausages, hamburgers and hot dogs. Every parilla has its own mouthwatering display of self-service salads, sauces and fillings for the customer to feast upon as well as supplies of cold drinks. Also provided are simple seating areas, consisting of just tables and chairs. Popular with workers from the nearby office buildings, these eateries are popular with -in-the-know' tourists and ideal treats for children. The prices are very reasonable, the service is friendly and the eating experience is most enjoyable.
Puerto Madero - something for all tastes. Clean, hip, happening with a wide variety of eateries, restaurants which is likely to suit most, if not all tastes.

Nice walk along. Take a walk along Puerto Madero or a bike ride. A great area filled with nice restaurants. Visit the turist office built in one of the old cranes of the harbour. A most perfect fitting design!

Nice for a stroll. This was the old commercial port of Buenos Aires. It has been recycled and has many restaurants, cafés and a museum (Fortabat's). It is nice to go during the day and stroll by the river . If you are short on time I would skip it.
puerto madero. nice place to visit. long walk to do on the docksides.a lot of restaurants, ice cream (freddo) but be carefull with taximen, as cthey know that turists are here

Puerto Madero was marvelous. Iit was unfortunate that I visited
Puerto Madero on my last day in buenos aires, it is a wonderful sight and if I had visited earlier, I'd have visited again. However, I was happy to visit the
Puerto Madero bridge and the community there and I'd certainty visit again whenever I'm in bueos aires, Argentina... Chao

Nice walk. Puerto Madero is a relaxing place to visit in Buenos Aires. You can walk along the river enjoying the scenery and then have your meal at one of the many different competing restaurants. Take some pictures of the famous bridge their.

Worth a visit if you are eating out. Very nicely re-developed area. Not a lot other than restaurants but very nice to walk around and lots of choices for places to eat. Easily walkable from Avenida De Mayo. Eat at Los Lilas which seems to be one of the best restaurants in Porto Madero. really nice atmosphere on the outside terrace overlooking the water

Posh but expensive dining. In every major city with a port the area around it is generally avoidable thanks to safety issues. But Puerto Madero is in every sense everything that a port area is not. For starters, it has a vast selection of restaurants, then again, it's a nice place to walk, and at night it's safe if yu want to sample some of the best restaurants in the City. From TGIF to mostaza to places such as Asia de Cuba it has a vibrant aura around. One bummer is the area is noticeably more expensive than similar places in othe parts of the city. But then, it offers a unique experience which outweighs the price differential. Cab's are plentiful too so go for it without a second thought.

Eat somewhere else!. The restaurants are pricey, dreadfully slow service and less than average food. In a city where eating out is a pure job, and hugely affordable for great food, this area disappoints. Visually, it is an interesting stroll people-watching and for yacht fancies
better steak then La Cabrera. We had a wonderful dinner Monday evening at this portside restaurant. The food and service were excellent. The steak is as good as it gets.

Nice area - safe but expensive. This is a nice area - very safe and well policed. The restaurants are very expensive. Great for an afternoon stroll in the sunshine. We visited on a Thursday night around 9pm and it was really quiet!

Over hyped. This is essentially a nice promenade along a canal, which is lined on one side with over priced underwhelming steak houses. There are far better places in the city where you can have great steaks and sausages for much less. I guess we missed the nineties or early 2000s when everything was better and less expensive in Argentina, including their legendary steak restaurants. The port itself has nothing out of the ordinary to offer.

Nice stroll along the waterfront. While looking for Buquebus ferry terminal we chance upon this pretty waterfront with chic expensive looking restaurants lining up the walkway and yachts in the marina. A couple of ships or armada there for visitors to wander around. A nice stroll indeed in the slightly chilly sunny afternoon.
A place to see!. Puerto Madero is a very nice, modern and safe neighborhood, many fine dinning restaurants, also a floating museum, you can take a very nice walking in the evening.

Lots to see and do - wonderful area. Fairly recent (wikipedia tells me 1999) reclamation of the historic port and construction of shops, restaurants, hotels, condos. One of the great ports of the world and a nice mi of the old and new with restored old cranes over the water and new sailboats in the harbor. I would recommend a visit for anyone planning to come to BA

Good place to see. It's the so famous port of argentina but sadly there's no port there anymore. It has become a so touristic place, where I wouldnt say it is not beautiful, on the other hand, I think it's one of the nicest things in Buenos Aires, but as I said before, it's not a port anymore.

A very hip and safe area for visitors. For visitors I would recommend staying in the many hotels in Puerto Madero as this are is very safe, but more importantly this area has many restaurants by either side of the river. This place is still developing so expect to see more exciting restaurants when it is fully developed.More nature lovers there is a huge eco park flanking one end of Puerto Madero, which I understand is busy with activities on week ends.What is lacking are shops and a shopping mall for the tourists in Puerto Madero, so tourists still need to go out of Puerto Madero for their shopping. That's where the threat of pick pockets are, especially in the open air markets and the notorious Florida street shopping belt. A friend's daughter lost her wallet which was pinched from her handbag while she was browsing at items outdoors.We stayed in Hotel Madero which is well located and a good and clean hotel. We had a chance to check out the Hilton at the other end, and the Hilton is also a good hotel.

Doesn't Fit Original Stye of BA. Man-made is all I have to say. Modern area, which resembles nothing like the rest of BA. Overpriced restaurants on the river, etc. Area looked like it belonged somewhere in California, not Argentina.
Lively and fulfilling. Great architectural renovation of vast old shipping warehouses...an abundance of extremely good restaurants and speciality shops as well as outdoor cafes ...

Rather boring walkway with average restaurants. I simply do not understand how this place gets mentioned as a major tourist spot in Buenos Aires. It looks like a wharf/dock area that you could find in any major city but surprisingly with even less charm. Considering how gorgeous BA is I would not recommend putting this high on your list. (or at all)

nice area to see. OK to pay a visit, but doesn't have the ambiance or flavor of the real Buenos Aires. Predictable large tourist restaurants are everywhere.If you have no interest in absorbing Argentine culture, this area is fine.
Very Good place to visi. Very good restaurants , good place to running, good views! Too cold and fog during the morning. Very good places to eat meet.
What a Beauty. Just Walk and Walk and Enjoy the Breeze and the Resturants across. A nice Bridge to cross walk and TGIF and Beer Bars. Also an Ancient Ship worth a beauty for just 2 Rials.

Take a walk along the old shipping port.. Many restaurants, cinemas and shopping along the old port. Nice to take a scenic walk. Old Frigat Sailing vessel of the Argentine Navy is available as a museum and tours.

The modern Buenos Aires. The old port with the beautiful warehouses is transformed to a new exciting place. There are a lot of restaurants and cafes. They are not very expensive and the quality is -almost- everywhere very good.

Extraordinaire. Great history and transformation, I went to Faena hotel and had the most wonderful asado experience at "the Mercado" and dinner @ Rojo Tango was an unforgettable unique and intimate show. Absolutely the best.
Beautiful Place. A beautiful place to walk during the day. Great restaurants. I had dinner at Cabaña Las Lilas and loved the "parrilla".
Beautiful place!. An excelent place to visit specially at night, with all the restaurants and lounges that surround it.

Prefer staying here over Recoleta or Palermo. Palermo is more cool nowadays, and Recoleta is the traditional upscale choice, but I like Puerto Madero more. First, guarded by the Naval Police, it's the most secure place in Buenos Aires. You can walk around anywhere and feel safe, even late at night, though you should always be aware of your surroundings. I love staying at the Hilton, but there are many hotel choices and amazing apartments for rent. Then you have the walkway along the waterway that is arguably the best line-up of restaurants in the city. Also, you are a short taxi ride from Calle Venezuela and other top local restaurants and the Cuba Mia Salsa club. If you need to get to Recoleta, not far by taxi.

A lovely place for a late night walk. The Puerto Madero is a very modern part of Buenos Aires. There are lots of restaurants and shops along the canal. You will find lots of people in the area day or night. A walk along the water at night is beautiful.
Puerto Madero. A good place to take a stroll or stay for a meal. Puerto Madero is a new area with wide walking areas and a good selection of restaurants and cafeterias.Worth a visit.

You will Love it!!!. A walk around the river is always nice... even if the river is not that clean. Around that area you will find the best and more exclusive (for exclusive I ran expensive) restaurants… you find the iconic "Puente de la mujer" Woman bridge… some cool sculptures and such a relaxing environment. This area of the city is famous for the wealthiness of the neighbours; so feel a lit bit of the glamour of the city!!
A must!. Beautiful walk along Puerto Madero. My wife and I went there twice during our four day stay. Many dining options and beautiful sights of the new Buenos Aires high-rises.

Puerto Madero: One-of-a kind area in Buenos Aires. Puerto Madero is a cool a beautiful área in Buenos Aires. If you like to walk by the river , around a Green área you shouldn´t miss Puerto Madero.After a walk, you can have a coffee in a nice coffee house or you can tryi our typical food in very nice and comfortable restaurants.Enjoy!Sandra

Great to Walk around. I really enjoyed just strolling the boardwalk and having drinks at the bars at sunset. Nice place for a couple just to chill and spend a little time together. There is an old ship nearby too.
Lovly. Perfect place to stay with someone you love i reslly enjoy my honeymoon in buenos aires the places are excelents and puerto madero is so romantic bu the night

A great place for dinner and drinks after work. This area is well designed and provides several choices for drinks and dinner in the evening. One of the best recent additions to night life in Buenos Aires.

Just ok. I considered staying in this neighborhood, but instead staye din Recoleta and I am happy with my choice. This section of BA is newer and very nice, but it feels like you are in any new city anywhere. The exception is the restaurants here, there are a lot of great ones to choose from.

Good walking area and good restaurants. It is a good place to go during the day because even during week days the restaurants are full and the area is very lively.
Good chances for great pictures too!

Lovely walk along the marina".
