This fantastic area of Buenos Aires is quite different from the rest, with the marina and plenty of restaurants option. take a walk along the marina and stop for lunch, coffee, tea, take the newspaper or your map and contemplate the city from the side crossing the water, just lovely...on your walk back to the "city" you can pass by Palacio Duhau Park Hyatt and have one of the most beautiful indoor gardens in the city, go and take you glass of wine, or dine if you like...tip? go before sun sets...its just enchanting to observe as natural light dims how the night lights illuminate the garden and back building, do not miss it....enjoy!
Just Buildings. As I say in the title, nothing much to see, just buildings. The best, the bridge designed by spanish architec Santiago de Calatrava.

The newest neighbourhood in BA. This is the preferred district for tourists. It was part of very old harbour stock buildings which were abandoned and later, converted into fashionable restaurants, pubs, cafeterias, hotels and home and office buildings. It has easy access and it's nice on sunny afternoons.
Good Ambiance, great for a slow stroll. Enjoyed Puerto Madero more than I expected. Great place to collect your thoughts or even for leisurely stroll whilst checking out shops and restaurants.
Fancy Shamcy. Did a lot of walking amongst Puerto Madero, didnt go into any of the resturants, a little of of my price range. But a lot of nice sights along the water way. Good place to visit
nice area to walk around. The renovated part is nice to walk around. We believe the restaurants are good but touristy. If it is your first time try them otherwise move on to authentic.

Gorgeous Day Out. We went to Puerto Madero for a day and to walk to the Ecological Reserve. It is such a lovely area, with tonnes of choice of food (we went to Siga La Vaca - well worth it!) and lots of little shops along the docks. We also visited the museum/ship thats permanently docked there (2 pesos entrance fee) which was interesting - they have a dead dog in a glass box!! Its definately worth going for a stroll along the canal side, especially on a sunny day.
madero. One of the few places to walk around without cars and pollution charging at you. The reserve IS beautiful, but the complex is outdated and has no real public space.

Good Restaurants. I went at nigth and with the lights this place is more beautifull than!!! Good plate to go every time, have good restaurants!!!If you go, is better lunch or dinner because there are good restaurants!!
One more facet to see!. Ultra modern and cosmopolitan. None of the character or charm of other neighborhoods, but it is interesting to see what new money has produced.

Lots of Great Food. Over the past several years the waterfront has been completely transformed. If you go to Buenos Aires do not skip this area as you will find great steaks, seafood adn wine here, adn can go for a nice walk after you dine.

A different Buenos Aires. It is the most modern area in BA. Except for the old dockyard warehouses now turned into lofts, restaurants, etc and the old cranes, most of the buildings are new. Lovely area to walk about. Because it is guarded by the Coastguards and not the Federal Police, it is much safer than the rest of the neighborhoods .Restaurant prices are steeper than in the rest of the city.

Worth a visit. Puerto Madero it's definitely a must on any tourist agenda. Beautiful old buildings and amazing number of restaurants, cafes, etc along the river and promenade. Great to stroll, bike or skate.Residential area is very modern, clean and peaceful.Eco park near by. I didn't make it but was recommended..... A good reason to go back!!

Riverside day. Probably the most of puerto madero could be obtained if you take one of the bikes the city provides and if the day is sunny you can tour around puerto mader and have lunch at one of the various restaurants there..

Very Cool in the Summer. Great place to ride a bike, and stop at an outdoor cafe for a beverage or a great meal. People watching, the water, boats are all a plus. Reminds me a little of Battery Park, New York, in terms of the brick buildings. the bridge and waterways make it all but a very unique part of Buenos Aires. If you are bike riding, head past and check out the Ecological reserve.

Puerto Madero. Most modern neibourghood in Buenos Aires. Place nice for walking around, wide avenues and close to the Rio de la Plata shore. Ecologic reserve with lot of birds and trees.
I live in BA
Puerto Madero. A great area to walk, relax and have a delicious meal. It is in the city, but away from the hussle and bussle.The huge variety of gastronomic places cater for every taste and wallet

Puerto Madero, Buenos Aires. The newest neighborhood in Buenos Aires. You may stroll along old piers, today converted into high-end private apartments, numerous restaurants and a nice view of the river coast

New front view area. Quiet and safe area. Full of good (and expensive) restaurants..
Just a nice walk, that's all.
If you visit San Telmo is not far from there (you can walk).
Modern Port area near El Centro. Lots of restaurants by water and often see ships going by. A nice place to stretch your legs and get some sun. Very clean

Nice place to have a relaxed walk. The old docks have been recycled and today there many very good restaurants of all types.
Wonderful place to have a lunch at the sun and then have a walk.
Nice area to walk around. Nice area for a walk or enjoy an icecream, or bar, or choose one of the many restaurants in the area, not particularly a cheap option, but good selection of places

The newest neighbourhood. Nice area to walk along the canal, have a coffee in one of the numerous bars, a lunch in the sun or a dinner under the moon (or inside, of course). Everything is rather new: high towers, hotels, modern treeless parks (low rise plants on a green surface). I personally have the feeling of walking along a high scale architectural model, nice, clean, spotless, sometimes close to perfection, but lacking soul. Though the original buildings of Puerto Madero were the charming red docks that were remodelled and turned into beautiful apartments, the architectural development of the area has overshadowed its charm. Anyway, it is modern, safe, agreable, with a wide gastronomic offer: in short: worth a visit to be able to compare it to the rest of Buenos Aires

A Modern Aspect to an old city. On the face of it - Puerto Madero is wonderful, Modern building, glass and steel, interspersed amongst an old dock land - with TGI Fridays, Starbucks to greet you - You could be in any dockland, in any city in the world. And that is what is wrong with it, in my opinion. If you travel to Buenos Aires, you don't want to be in Dublin (there is even the "same" Calatrava Bridge to greet you), San Diego, Singapore or London's east end - you want to be in Buenos Aires - The old city, the Paris of South America, the architecture, the milongas, the old cafes with style.Yes, it's safe, it's airy, its clean, something a lot of BA lacks, but it has no atmosphere. Some nice, if expensive, restaurants, and on the plus side, some nice traffic free areas to run along, but overall, it does not give you the BA Experience - Pop over to see if for an hour, but only on your way to somewhere else in this wonderful city.

great place!. a very nice place to visit, where you can have a meal or just walk by the river. In the area there are a lot of restaurants to taste argentinean meals or international cuisine. Walk relaxed, puerto madero is one of the safest places in bs as, enjoy!!!!

Very turistic area. Lots of places to see. Restaurants with a great view of the river, modern buildings and very safe too.
A "must do" for turists visiting Buenos Aires. Pretty crowded on weekends.

Nice safe modern area. What used to be the docks has been refurbished to make one of the safest and nicest areas in BA. Not only can you walk around to enjoy the views such as Puente de la Mujer, the canal, the reserve and great hotels (Hilton, Faena) but also dine in some of the best restaurants without having to worry about thieves.

Touristic place. River front area. Business area during the day, becomes lively during the night due to the inmense offer of restaurants on both sides of the canal. This is a very secure area to hang around during the night.
Strongly recomend "Happening" and "Estilo Campo" for meat lovers.

Not so interesting..... Nice restaurants but nothing to visit. Only tourists or businessmen go to Puerto Madero restaurants as they are much more expensive than other places in Buenos Aires. If you like Argentine meat there are many good Parrillas for example Cabana Las Lilas or Happening. You can have a quick walk if the weather is good as neighborhood is reasonably safe.
Nice but empty. It's a nice stroll, specially along the river. If you walk though the neighborhood, it feels that it lacks character, there is nothing special about it, may be because it's too new.

Nice & relaxed. Good to see another face of Buenos Aires although it's very similar to other cities with port. Restaurants, walking or biking with great view and access to one of the newest areas of the city

NOT REALLY BUENOS AIRES, BUT NICE ANYWAY. "Porteños", that is to say natives of Buenos Aires city, don`t mentally include Puerto Madero as a part of their psychologic town map. Inaugurated as a residential and touristic centre (with also some business offices and universities) some 20 years ago, this huge quarter used to be a horrible mixture of port long abandoned deposits and garbage dropping high-grassed voids, where fugitives and thieves searched sanctuary among rats and cockroaches. Recycled at an exorbitant cost, in not completely clear financial operations, during President Menem rule, in the '90s, it became the most expensive residential flats place in town, home for nouveau-riches and well-done politicians (the Vice-President included). Excellent restaurants (mostly "for-gringos") are located here over the docks (now used by sailboats), in a nice environment, with some remote resemblance to the new Thames embankments in London. A walk along these shores is worth the while, visiting the old military sail-ships in display, and crossing through the imposing "Bridge of Woman" (all streets in this quarter are named after renowned local women, no man's name allowed). You will find a lot more tourists than porteños here, but presently it is a must.

Modern Buenos Aires. Reminded us a little of Southbank in Melbourne. Lots of new restaurants and a nice walk along the river. Prefer the vibe of the "barrios" but worth a trip. Check out La Parolaccia.
Great vibe. Loved walking around along the canal, with all the bars and restaurants. Definately a good vibe to the area.feels safe too.

Nice riverfront area, not much otherwise. Quiet during the day, but nice to check out with the restaurants and cafes riverside. Not much here otherwise - unless you're around or if you have a specific place to visit, no reason to go out of your way for visiting. I would imagine this area would be hopping at night.

Safe, but rather lifeless. This development apparently rescued an area of town that was practically abandoned and quite dangerous, but replaced it with a rather soulless zone of pricey restaurants and overly renovated industrial relics. They made the smart decision to leave the giant cranes in place, so that you can at least get a sense of what it was like when it was a bustling port, but then painted them brashly so they look like new constructions rather than actual artifacts. If you don't have much time in Buenos Aires, I think you're safe skipping Puerto Madero. It doesn't have the beat and pulse that makes the rest of the city so exciting.
Beautiful view. Puerto Madero is a good place to visit both in the morning and at night. In the morning to walk around and see modern buildings and at night to eat and have some drinks.

puerto madero. puerto madero was quiet when i visited it on a weekday afternoon. it comes alive at night with all those expensive restaurants trying to get a share of your tourist money. don't forget to visit the puente de la mujer when you walk along puerto madero

Feels like another city!. Puerto Madero was awesome - very clean, lots of nice restaurants (very upmarket and trendy), almost like another city.Would definitely recommend visiting here for some dinner or a drink.

Beautiful Day for a Walk and a Choripan.. It was great to get away from the condensed urban life of BA and walk through a natural reserve area. Its not too big and we didn't have time to walk the long route before it closed at 5:30. But check out the path, it is a great place to walk, run, bike or just be outdoors. And right on the other side there are great food vendors with cheap choripans and more!

Great sightseeing, and nice restaurant choices.. This place (old city port) has been renovated for the tourists. It provides a nice walk along the docks, with a variety of restaurants, stores, bars, and a beautiful view of the city skyline. I suggest a walk around sunset, and hanging out till dark.
Love this Area. Got to see the Pink House. Had a great steak dinner at Freddy's! Saw World War Z in 3D at the Cinemark movie theater, went aboard the ship from the 1800's. Pretty cool area!
nice place nice restaurants. great place to see...nothing nice at night!so try to stay in palermo if you are looking for a hotel or apartment

Nicest part of BA. Pretty safe and lots of things to do and see. Lots of restaurants and all kinds of stores, the bridge with a pretty nice walk, a lot of newly built high rise buildings and the most exclusive part of the city.
Nice spot. Lots of restaurants to choose from. Picturesque area to walk around. The museum ship ARA Frigata Presidente Sarmiento is worth a look.

Nice for an afternoon stroll.. This neighborhood is very different than the rest of BA. It lacks the grit, history, and authentic culture. The old ship on the canal is open to walk around on, which was interesting. It is fun to rent bikes and ride through the park. The sidewalks are flat here so it is good for running and you'll see lots of folks rollar blading. All along the one street is full of walk up parrillas, an excellent cheap lunch or dinner.

Puerto Madero. A real MUST walk around when in Buenos Aires ? Also a place with many good restaurants serving famous Argentinian beef! So ... enjoy a wonderful steak and a few glasses of great and known Argentinian Malbec wines....
Fun Walk. It was a fun walk, very scenic with a selection of cafes, bars and restaurants. Very close to San Telmo and worth a peek.
New seaside harbor walkway - many restaurants. A great place to stroll. An old shipping port reinvigorated with seaside walkways, restaurants, stores and offices.
Civilization!. Felt like I was back in North America...but in a good way. Excellent restaurants and great water views.

An excellent stroll and beautiful old ship (Sarmiento) to visit!. Me and my husband visited Puerto Madero due to its proximity to our hostel, so it was the first thing we saw in Buenos Aires (after The Obelisco of course, can't miss that one even if you try). We enjoyed the walk along the river, where we found an old ship we could visit for 2 pesos per person, the Fregata Presidente Sarmiento. You can go almost everywhere on this ship, it's very nice to see how it used to work and how the sailors lived. Then we saw the docks and had some great coffee and medialunas at a cafe by the shore. There are also many fancy restaurants where you can eat steak.

Nice Area. Stayed at the Hilton in Puerto Madero. The area around it was very nice. People walking around at all hours. The restaurants, especially ones on the waterfront around it are a bit overpriced though. It doesn't surprise me though. An area like that in America would have overpriced restaurants also.

A very interesting new area. We liked everything. The skyline is new but was designed by the most important architects of the world.you can walk along the boardwalk, sit in one restaurant, have a drink in a nearby cafe. Very cosmopolitan

Nice neighborhood. Probably one of the nicest neighborhoods in the city of Buenos Aires. Next to the river, modern, safe (a must in this city) full of restaurants. Very nice to walk around, especially on weekends.
Very nice walk. love Puerto Madero, good place to have a walk. been there a few times- pretty and safe by day and by night.

Interesting show and good food, poor transport. The show was interesting, and intimate. The food was tasty. Well seasoned steak. However, avoid booking the transportation from your hotel. It's a shuttle. They picked us up and held us hostage for an hour and 15 minutes while the driver collected the other passengers.

New Buenos Aires high class residences.... ..but plenty of restaurants, in former wharf buildings, made of red bricks in times when the British influence was quite strong, and with a certain similitude to those of London. Pleasant walk alongside old piers, used now by recreation boats.

Cool bridge but a little dull. We visited during the day so it may be more exciting at night. The bridge was pretty interesting and there was some interesting people watching but other than that, the area was a little dull. I'm sure it livens up at night though as there were many restaurants in the area.

Modern and clean, lots of park space.. We rented some bikes and explored the natural reserve here. It was very beautiful, but the rio plata was very dirty with lots of garbage washed ashore. Also many nice restaurants nearby.

Very nice walking and dinning options!.. We have heard that Puerto Madero was a must-see sight while in Buenos Aires and now we know why. Its a very-very-very nice area with leisure spots, fine dinning, long corridors for walking, shops, etc... we truly enjoy our time spent there... live music, lot of people walking and hangin out, pets enjoying a walk ride... all was perfect for a total relax sunday afternoon!!!... ENJOY IT!.
Work and restaurants. My office is in this area and the views of the sparkling water are fantastic. It's a very clean part of the city and you can't go wrong with all of the fantastic restaurants.

Restaurants. If you are looking for somewhere to eat that is slightly uomarket then this is one area you should visit. There are numerous restaurants all offering good food. They prices are definitely higher than other areas of Buenos Aires. This area is very much like Canary Wharf in London with the area along the river being regenerated. There are yachts moored along this stretch and a couple of sailing ships. Well worth a visit just for a stroll even if you don't want to eat.

Fun location!. This is the area in B.A. that has had the most change. Old warehouses have been transformed into sleek housing and new restaurants. This is where the uber groovy Faena Hotel is as well as the Calatrava bridge.

Try as many restaurants as you can!. Puerto Madero is lined with so many restaurants, covering all different cuisines. Eating outdoors just adds to the experience of being on the water. I was staying in San Telmo which was a little walk away but still doable which was nice before dinner.

newest neighbourhood in buenos aires. similar to the docklands in the UK, this place is expanding and growing every year with new flats, offices, museums, cafes and green spaces.try the faena hotel! is a must!the fundacion fortabat has a great private collection of artfor lunch siga la vaca is a good alternative and lots of beef
Puerto Madero, nice place to eat and take a stroll. One of the areas we enjoyed the most! Restaurants are pricey, but the view from some of them was well-worth it.

Great place to eat good food and have a nice stroll. I went here on a Sunday afternoon hoping to find a nice place to eat. Lots of restaurants and stores were closed. I walked to Puerto Madero from Hotel Bristol; did not take me that long. I was hoping to see restaurants here with English in the menus. There were several places that offered this. I just happened to walk in the first restaurant that had a bi-lingual menu. It was very expensive and I still ate here! The marina is very clean and there are ample restaurants to choose from. There are a couple of big old boats you can get on board. The one I went to had an entrance fee of only $2 Pesos. There is also a very interesting pedestrian bridge. It is pure white and has an unusual spike to it. I believe it is 'the bridge of mothers.'

Over hiped and a touristy. We stayed in Buenos Aires for 3 nights and went down by foot from Recoleto where our hotel was to the Puerto Madero area on a lovely crisp autumn day. On the way down we were approached by a couple who threw a nasty smelling soupy liquid on our clothes and proceeded them to rip us off. Watch out when you are walking around Buenos Aires for these crafty pick pocket-ers which unfortunately take the fun out of walking and enjoying the city . The restaurants down in the Puerto Madero are very touristy and over priced for the quality of food served, in our opinion.
Meh.. Just walking around. Over priced restaurants. Remember to order sirloin or skirt steak if you are from states otherwise you eat rump roast- a hunk of it as their "good cut"

A Great Stroll.. This place was great to stroll on. It had a lovely setting, with nice restaurants and when the lights came on it looked lovely. It was nice to walk along the waterfront away from the chaotic city!
Excellent choice of up-scale restauarants. Loads of restaurants to choose from and nice by the river during the day or for a stroll at night. Very safe area.
Great place for late afternoon or evening stroll. Lots of stores, restaurants, cafes. There are a few naval museums on the water so get there before 7pm to take advantage.

Could be any expansion in any city. This area of BA is ok, but it's all new...built in an old port area that had been abandoned for years. It's not a bad place to go...nice restaurants and a few bars...but there is no character here. The neighborhood could be in any city as all there is are new office and apartment buildings. There are so many unique and special neighborhoods in BA that I'd recommend you pass on this one unless you have some extra time on your hands.
Walk around. Nice place to walk around, take photos, sit by and have some sun and, of course, eat well. Lots of restaurants in the area and nearby other attractions too.
Great Restaurants. Delicious restaurants but the area itself is somewhat overrated. The area reminds me of Marina Del Rey in Los Angeles. A wealthy upscale area with little character.

Safe place to wander for a meal at night. This was a very safe place to wander at night to get a meal, it is very quiet here. An interesting place during the day it is the shiny new part of Buenos Aires, I prefer the old buildings but this is a nice contrast.

No historic value, but nice-looking restaurant/bar area. Puerto Madero is a huge urban renovation project on 20 blocks of reclaimed land. There are 4 docks (digues, in Spanish) that form a long strip of modern, high-end restaurants and bars. You can also stroll along the marina and see the modern bridge (Bridge des Mujeres). It's a safe area. In addition to police, many of the restaurants have their own security staff. (Panhandlers will often target diners on the many terraces.)It's popular with tourists and locals alike, particularly for business lunches and happy hours. There's quite a bit of parking. One warning: it's safe to walk to get here by day, but at night, you would have to cut through some sketchy areas to reach the nearest Subte station - take a remise or radio taxi!If you're not dining here, it's not worth the trip on its own, but many restaurants are worthy destinations; so do your research online on places like Cabana Las Lilas or La Bistecca and decide for yourself.

Urban Renovation and its Best. The puerto madero area is a fabulous model for urban renovation. the inlet and port area have all been rebuilt and are now perfect for strolling, dining (although many of the options seemed quite expensive and pretentious), or reading a book. There is also a pleasant park that runs along the river front to have a picnic or take a nap

Come here for a meal and a stroll. This is somewhere you might like or hate depending on your attitude. It is not quaint, or picturesque, but it is somewhere for Portenos to come and stroll and have a drink or a meal. Converted from the old docks, it has a Marina, and an interesting bridge. I know many people hate modern dock conversions, but on a sunny day, it is really nice, and gets you away from the main crowded tourist areas. Bring your Spanish, though.

Unique area. A stroll around this neighborhood was lovely. The converted buildings are definitely different. Because it's a newer area, it's modern and clean. We, unfortunately, didn't get the chance to dine in the area. Next time!
Great place to hang around. Well kept esplanade - easy to walk and relatively quiet away from the hustle bustle of BA CBD. Havannah coffee, chocolates and great views to sit and people watch
Pleasant walk. It is a nice walk with water views. But if you are looking for a cheap place to eat, go somewhere else.
Great afternoon walk.. It´s a very different face of Buenos Aires (modern, designy, kind of cool) best seen in the late afternoon sun.

Wonderful place for a walk in an updated former port warehouse area. Great walk along the old port area of Buenos Aires. Very quiet at night. We ate in a restaurant on a Saturday night in almost a vacant restaurant. Many restaurants to choose from. We may have been early for Buenos Aires as we were done dinner by about 8:30.

You must visit. There a lot of very very good restaurants there, the views are nice and the food is one of the best I have ever try, you may want to find hotel near there if you are in a leisure trip, i really liked this part of the city

Modern upscale, safe area. Great place to sit and have a coffee etc., and watch the world go by. Great ambiance.
Good area to stroll, nice restaurants. Watch the boats go by in the port.
The Hilton is very close by in the center of Puerto Madera., where you can catch the city tour bus from.

Nice area to spend time and eat. This is a modern, upscale area in Buenos Aires. It is a pleasant place to walk and spend time, with nice views. There are very nice restaurants with many ethnic varieties along the river.

Great place to stay. We spent almost a week in Buenos Aires and stayed at the Hilton in Puerto Madero. Great place to stay because its safe at all times of day and night and you have shops, restaurants and bars a short distance away. Not the 'real Buenos Aires' as it is a more modern and upscale area than the rest of the city, but it is very convenient to get from here to anywhere else in the City. The double decker city tour bus stops across the road from the Hilton hotel.

New and modern area of Buenos Aires.. We spent a wonderful day walking in this area visiting the weekend market that was held during our visit. The area is modern and lovely. A nice contrast to many of the other areas in Buenos Aires.
great walk and food. Excellent food and great walk along the dock, it does not seem as long as it actually is. recommend for all type of travellers.

Don't worry, the Coast Guard's got your back!. So yes Puerto Madero is all new and not the "authentic" Buenos Aires that tourists imagine, but come on, this a metropolis, there's a little bit of everything here and while I love wandering the streets of Recoleta and wandering if this is what Paris looks like, Puerto Madero has it's charms as well. Namely, cleanliness, safety and calm. The area is patrolled by the Coast Guard who are better paid than the regular police, which is why it's much safer than the rest of downtown. Because there's hardly any public transportation into Puerto Madero there aren't so many people, you have to walk to get there, it's worth it in my opinion, especially around sunset. When the weather's good it's a sweet spot for people watching, just watch out for the hordes of rollerskates along the canal. Now this is an expensive area and you can't expect to get a cheap meal here, but if you're willing to pay you have some pretty awesome choices. My favorites are Mirasol (they have the best lomo and then apple pancake dessert, they also have a seafood sister restaurant next door which I haven't tried yet) and La Parolaccia (great pasta and service!).

Beautiful!!!!!. A must walk around and see all this area! Great restaurants too..........We went to a high end buffet restaurant for dinner and it was fabulous!!!!!!!!!!! but everyone in BA eats way way to late!!!!!!!!

Overrated. This place is definitely overrated. It is chock full of buildings and many of the restaurants are cheap chain-food stores here in the US. You are better off spending a day exploring a different town, such as San Telmo, La Boca or Recoleta...
great for dining and views. Osaka was great and the view of the bridge was wonderful. Las Lilas is not worth going to except for the tables on the river.
Nice strolls. A nice spot where you can take long strolls and if needed find some of the most popular restaurants in the area.

Great Value & Vibe. Several restaurants with outdoor tables and beautiful views line the water's edge. Great for dinner, a night stroll or just drinks. Locals eat dinner closer to 21:00 so keep this in mind if you're looking for a bit of a crowd. Prices don't really differ compared to similar types of retaurants in the city so I felt like it was great value considering the wonderful ambiance and scenery.

You could spend an entire week here trying all of the different restuarants. Puerto Madero is a must place to go on your trip to Buenos Aires. I have been there many times to eat at many of the different restuarants both for lunch and dinner.Just about any kind of food you want will be found here. Most of the restaurants here offer high quality tasty food.This is also a great place to go just to watch Portanos.

Great place to stroll.. We have stayed in Puerto Madero our last two visits to BA. It's a clean, newer area and a great place to take a stroll and see the pretty Puerto Mujer bridge. There are a ton of restaurants in the area and all are good but expensive. I think if your time is limited, there are things I would recommend more highly to see and do but it's certainly a lovely place to take a stroll and have something to eat.

Lovely. Beautifully recovered area around the port, with countless restaurants and cafes, with the unusual and elegant Ponte de la Mujer and an interesting frigate museum. People watching at its best, portenos running, biking, roller blading and boating with gusto. Particularly pretty at dusk when the light turns soft and building glow in the mirror of the river.
Great place to visit. Safe with lots of restaurants that appear to be frequented by locals which us always a good sign! Lovely walks and interesting sailship to tour.
Great view. Great view, restaurants are very charming. If you are going to Buenos Aires, don't miss Puerto Madero, I recommend going at night for dinner.
the right place. I really like to ride there. The restaurants are high quality, hotels and stores in this area. Very fancy and safe.There is also a casino.

Just a nice walk. It is a nice walking place and have many goos restaurants, but they are very expensive. No relevant atractions here, just a modern neighborhood. If you are on a short visit won't loose much, perhaps just go there for dinner (if you have some to expend)

Different view of Buenos Aires. The old warehouses that were abandoned for decades have been refurbished into lofts and steakhouses with water facing terraces filling the ground levels. Across the stunning bridge - Puente de la Mujer - glass towers glisten and BA folks jog, cycle and skate along the waterfront. A different perspective on the city not to be missed.

Es un sitio agradable y moderno. It is a must being in Bs As. It is a good place where you can walk and find good restaurants to eat something. A little bit expensive. I like it but I definitely prefer the other part of the city... En mi opinión un sitio que debe visitarse estando en Bs As. Puede uno caminar sin complicaciones y comer algo por la zona. Prefiero la Buenos Aires un poco mas bohemia. Lindo sitio de todas formas.
Great Location. Spent a nice, sunny afternoon walking along the water fornt and visiting cafes. Thee are a variety of food options from local restaurants to TGI Firdays. Fun place to hang out.

Modern Area in BA. Great area to visit and stroll along the front. Many restaurants and cafes to enjoy. Cross via the wonderful footbridge. They have done a great job in converting this area from commercial port to a residential area.

It's a dockside. Towards the end of the 20th century, a lot of cities noticed they were oversupplied with steamship docks and under-supplied with expensive loft living opportunities. Buenos Aires is no exception, and the renewed dockside with its long red brick ex-warehouses now houses a kilometre or so of rather expensive dining and a decent gelateria.It's a bit characterless; the promenading people, and the rollerbladers who come out at least on Sunday evenings, are worth watching.

Urban Development, developing. in a few years it will be a great and hopefully safe night life area, it's a bit drab right now, as larger strips are unoccupied and most restaurants are charging way too much for a view on beige water with a few silly sailboats, okay even a schooner at some point. Great for a stroll from Micro Centro all the way down to San Telmo. Due to the always congested parallel avenue you'll be listening to nasty traffic noise and inhalingthe inaudible part, no doubt.
Nice walk along port. Lovely boardwalk to walk along by the water with many food establishments. Definitely have some helados during your walk, and enjoy a lovely stroll at any time of the day!
Tango show and good food. That part of trip really worth! A great tango show with argentinian food. Good service and tango class after show :D

Wide open spaces!. When you feel like you need some room to breathe (BA can get quite "close"), this is a great place to head. As a woman traveling solo i felt safe and that I could let my guard down a bit. Glamorous and modern.
Modern. Modern buildings with various restaurant options. Completely different from the rest of the city. It was great to walk around by the river.

Excellent requalification. Once a busy harbour it has been requalified in a superb way.Go for dinner and take a picture of the new bridge by Archistar Calatrava which designs a couple dancing tango.While there have dinner at CABANAS LAS LILAS (I suggest reservation) expensive but food and service are top

The modernized BA. Go if you feel like chilling at fancy restaurant. But the port itself is not particularly spectacular. If you are running out of time to visit other parts of BA, i dont see why you need to visit Puerto Madero.
Port. A lovely restaurant row lining the river. Nice walkway and places to sit to relax and enjoy. Not far walking distance from many hotels. Peaceful and scenic.

Upmarket Buenos Aires. Did not visit any restaurants,just had a pleasant walk both sides of the old port area. Very expensive shops and restaurants,but very nice area,since the development has been finished.Worth a visit,to get away from the very busy traffic streets.

Nice for Strolling and A High-End Dining Experience. This is a lovely area of low rise renovated warehouses which front a river canal. It is a nice area for strolling and enjoying a high-end dining experience. It is not unique nor comparable to the great river fronts of the world. However, it is quite pleasant. In the future, I would like to see more retail and casual cafes in this area.
Go go go. Don't even think about skipping the place, you will have great views, walking places and the best restaurants. It will be the best place in the city.

Like so many waterfronts. If you walk around this waterfront you could be in Sydney, London, Copenhagen, Amsterdam, Hamburg, etc etc. It's like so many modern day waterfront developments - slightly clinical and rather monotonous. A beautiful Calatrava bridge makes a visit worthwhile.

Great resturants and vibe!. We loved our time in Buenos Aires, and our favourite place was Puerto madero. good food, great steak restaurants (We were there 3 nights and went to three diffferent ones!. Very well lit and better than downtown

Great for Outdoor Activities and Choripans!. Puerto Madero is a haven for cyclists, skateboarders, rollerbladers and joggers with its wide, tree-lined boulevards and many open spaces. Don't forget to grab a choripan, paired with the many different flavors of sauces, from one of the choripan stands in the neighborhood. They're the best we've had throughout BA!
Like Any other waterfronts. Strictly for tourists and the affluent. Ate at a pricey steakhouse there. Nice but not spectacular views along the river. Beautiful parks nearby.
best for restaurants. good example of gentrification and reuse of old real estate. Best for dining while people watching and looking at the water

Walking by the river. Puerto Madero is an excellent River Port which a few years ago underwent a complete renovation and has become a trendy, well presented area with excellent restaurants, bars, and beautiful hotels. All the old wharehouses were transformed into beautiful private condos, office buildings, and restaurants, shops and bars. With the sailing boats docked along the river it is also a beautiful place for a nice jog, bike ride or just a walk along the river banks.

where the old meets the modern. Wonderful restoration of old warehouse building converted into restaurants. The old port machinery has been saved and serves as sculpture along the. pleasant walkways along the water. This setting is contrasted by a back drop of modern office buildings.

Excellent strolling and dining along the water.. Many restaurants, some so-so, some great, along this long stretch of refurbished port warehouses. Great for couples. Dine outdoors if you can. Stroll the length of the waterside walkway after dinner.

Best part of town. We enjoyed walking around Puerto Madero both during the day and in the evening. The area is calm, modern & a haven from the busy streets. Large choice of restaurants makes it an easy choice for meals.
Nice place. This place is a Must Do in Buenos Aires. You can, for instance, drink sodas, walk, take pictures to luxury builds and atractions...
Lovely new walk by the harbor.. An architecturally interesting pedestrian bridge spans the harbor. The wide boardwalk is a great place for a stroll, filled with families, couples, and singles.

Waterfront bars and cafes. we came to this area to catch a hydro to Colonia de Sacramento.
Like many former dockside places,this has been redeveloped and is now a very pleasant area to walk and enjoy the area.
Interesting. Ladies bridge. Warehouses built into Nice restaurants along the canal. Great for a stroll.walked from Recoleta.

A fantastic addition to Buenos Aires. What a refreshing open area in one of the busiest and most hectic cities in the world. Puerto Madero feels more like walking on the Mall in Washington DC or maybe like Central Park than in Buenos Aires. It is open, comfortable, no graffiti, but it also has great restaurants, bars and coffee shops, lots of trees and green space, and interesting architecture. The water has too much flotsam, but maybe they could work on that. If I had to spend any significant time in Buenos Aires, this is where I would gravitate to.

Up and coming. As the title suggests, it's up and coming but not there yet. Old warehouses and buildings are still being renovated and the prices are as high as anywhere in Buenos Aires. Trendy, expensive restaurants line the riverwalk and even though it's a little out of the way, it's a nice place to have a late dinner. (See my review of Cabana Las Lilas).
Sight and food. a nice place to walk where you can find very modern buildings and good restaurants offering international dishes

Reminiscent of Butlers Wharf (London), Darling Harbour (Sydney), but with the sophistication of Barcelona. Reminiscent of Butlers Wharf (London) and Darling Harbour (Sydney), but with the sophistication of Barcelona.
Home to restaurants, bars and cafes. Mixed residential and offices. Location of the Buenos Aires Hilton.
No traffic, clean and safe.
A great place to sit outside and watch the world go by ... walkers, joggers, roller bladers. Loved it there!

Modern and clean, but expensive. Puerto Madero is the newest neighborhood in Buenos Aires and you can tell. Everything is super shiny and clean but also super expensive. This area was designed to be a luxury zone, though it's definitely not yet reached full capacity. Most days its possible to walk across a four lane road without more that a quick glance both ways. Its a super nice and relaxed spot to take a walk or rent roller skates to check out the boardwalk along the canal. Also gives you easy access to the Reserva Ecologica, which is a great way to get into nature without actually having to travel far.

Like the best piers in the world!. If you liked visiting the piers in San Francisco and New York, you must go to Puerto Madero if you go to Buenos Aires. Is safe, beautiful and has some of the best Restaurants in town. Is a great mix of architectures with the old brck buildings and the brand new resiential towers being built. Great place for business or to visit with the family.

Excellent if you liker new, safe and quiet. Not as close to the "action". My wife and I loved it, but it should be noted that we also love to walk (a lot!) on our trips, so 8 blocks to a metro is nothing to us. We also like clean, safe and quieter at night - we will find the culture, the hidden areas and such during the rest of the day, but once we hit a bed, we like the items mentioned. Puerto Madero is really that - a bit of a walk to the metro (or a walk in general) or a cab to see the rest of the sites. Quiet, lots of police and more restaurants than you could tackle in a month all next to a cool riverfront area. The Hilton was our base for this assessment - other properties in Puerto Madero are likely to be very similar since the entire area is similar from what we saw. Don't stay here if you don't like walking or cabs, since you will have to do one of them each day most likely. (though the metro in Buenos Aires is quiet minimal and I suspect a lot of neighborhoods will require the same walking or cab usage...)

an old port. The city authorities tried to change the old port into an exclusive restaurants center,but they forgot to invest in the surroundings.There are a lot of good expesive restaurants there but they are still located in the old hangars.So once you arrive and saw 1 or 2 restaurants there is no reason to go all along the quais because it all looks the same.
Lovely atmosphere. This is a bit like either Canary Wharf or Albert Dock Liverpool, a lovely, regenerated area with lots of cafes, wonderful for a stroll, coffee and people watching!
Walking, eating and romancing :). Puerto madero is lovely, lots of restaurants and a few pubs, I loved "Siga la Vaca" meat buffet....the pasta restaurants are also amazing.

Cool place to walk around... and there is an inexpensive spot for drinks. We had the big sightseeing through the so called "Microcentro", including several historical buildings and s narrow streets. So, as the evening came, we thought of going to nearby "Puerto Madero" to look around. I knew this place already, so I was aware that most of the cafes and restaurants are only looking for those green tourist bills - if you know what I mean.Anyhow, it was a nice walk and great place for taking pictures. We took several pics on the sunset and some other with the contrast of new and old buildings. Those are surely the coolest from our Buenos Aires stay.But: we finally found a cool place to hang out. It is basically a Kiosk. It is just at the Yacht Club, which at the northern end of Puerto Madero (close to the "Telecom" Building and the "Buquebus" harvor that takes you to Urugay). They had tables outside, it was full of younger people and all you had to do was to walk inside, buy your drinks, pay at the counter and walk outside. So, self-service that is. So we could enjoy the sunset in a nice spot and didn't spend much money for our drinks and snacks.We also saw the "Fragrata Libertad", and old military boat. Pretty cool.By the way, Puerto Madero was built earlier than the Havor City in Hamburg.

Very Touristy!. A nice area of BA but very touristy! You will find that everyone around this are speaks English (and most are American tourist). The restaurants in this area are a little pricey (targeting tourists), but there are some beautiful views of the river and the Casa Rosada.
reminds to the Hafen city development in Hamburg. nice Restaurants, a lot of good architecture on the urban developments and the docks. we felt safe to walk araound at night.

Land of many restaurants. Along the docks there are literally 50 restaurants, many with outdoor seating that look out over the docks/locks and modern skyscrapers beyond. Perfect spot for dinner or drinks.
Modern, new part of Buenos Aires.. Upscale buildings, restaurants, shops, etc. Spent the day bicycling around area and Reserva. Nice photo opps.

Canary wharf without the olde worlde charm. What a sad , soulless area this is. A couple of old boats, some uninspired new blocks of offices and identical-looking restaurants around 2 strips of water, all set in a run down, shabby part of town, with no attempts at landscaping or aesthetic embellishment.
A visit here makes you quite nostalgic about Canary Wharf.
Waterfront stroll. Great to stroll along the full length of the water front and then pick a restaurant out of the supposedly 80 along the stretch!

Bright and airy. The redeveloped port area is a great space to eat, shop or just stroll around for a couple of hours. The highlights for us were the 2 old sailing ships that are open to visitors-life would have been very tough on those vessels, especially travelling to the Antarctic regions a century ago.

Nice place for a walk in the afternoon.. The views are not so fantastic, but it is still a nice place for a walk away from the traffic.
Good restaurants in the area.

A superb area. They have changed an old dock area into a fantastic area with hotels and restaurants. They have kept some old cranes and restored them to remnd you of what was before. To get there you walk through a nice park full of parrots in the wild. A great sight ! An all round good way to spend a couple of hours day or night . Highly recommend the tango show at the Fuena

interesting puerto. protected aerea. like the young people playing in the parcs soccer or skateboarders, the runners and families and couples enjoying a sunny summer afternoon in the parc and on sundays the smell of the asados and the helado salesman on the waterfront with the crowd,

Fantastic area. A mix of the old buildings of the harbor with the modern constructions, the business and hotel towers, the fragatta boats to visit, the Woman Bridge by Calatrava, delicious restaurants, a tango show house etc... A place to go during the day and at night

The newest neighbourhood in Buenos Aires. The architecture is english style, with docks covered with Antique tiles and bricks that used to be the old docks where the vessels used to disembarks their freights, grains and food from other argentine ports. Nowadays, a fancy neighbourhood where american retired people buy apartments.

Worth walking along - day or night. Pleasant walk, nice ship to visit, great restaurants and cafes.
Lovely indeed.
This is a safe and pretty area. Restaurants are opened until midnight so they can call a cab for you after your walk.
Fun area. A bit like the Battery Park City of BA. Great Restaurants, on the water, fun to walk along. Went to Las Lilas for dinner, excellent beef and food in general, a bit pricey, but worth it.
Dreamy!. Really loved Puerto Madero! So many restaurants in one place it's crazy. It was tough to pick one. A great place to have a nice walk along the water.

Very nice area. We stayed at the Hilton in Puerto Madero and were surprised to find so many wonderful places for food in the area. The area is very clean, interesting and was close to where we wanted to be for walking around Buenos Aires.

Pleasant renovated port area. Its hard to see the river in Buenos Aires so this restored dock area is the next best thing. Pleasant for strolling, but the restaurants are expensive. Best accessed at the north end. Trying to get there directly from Plaza de Mayo is a nightmare.

great marina. The puerto madero belongs for sure to the beautiful parts of BA, its new, has daring architecture which pleases not only the working people there, but the tourists for sure. i felt really comfortable there, day-time or at night. so many restaurants and bars are around, very good hotels lining up giving this district a grand liveliness - apparently BA´s are going out there too, well they are having drinks at numerous bars (i.e. Hotel F).and tango-shows are offered here as well - did not go there, as the prices wer ridiculous high. Taxis are always there, maybe you have to wait a minute or two.

Great place for the afternoon stroll. Wonderful neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Great area for a stroll, with all the wonderful restaurants, several old ships (that require very small fee to see), bridges and waterway. Ice cream shops, cafes and plenty of good offers for Happy Hour. Relaxed atmosphere.
Underwhelmed. It's a big brown river with some restaurants. No retail that we could find. I thought it would be nicer. It's under construction so I'm sure in 2 years it will be worth the walk

Days and nights at the port. Over the few days we were in Buenos Aires we visited Puerto Madero a few times - in the morning on our run to the park and also for NYE. Watching the fireworks with a bottle of champagne is an experience that I will never forget. Plus going out to the bars nearby was a lot of fun.

Nice new waterfront area but not many people visit. Nice revitalised area in BA with lots of bars/cafes. Good for a stroll during the day or in the evening but not so busy with people. Some very nice restaurants to visit in the evening but can be expensive.

Walk on the docks on a sunny day. This part of the capital gives off a mediterranean vibe, what with all the cafés and restaurants along the docks, that let you forget the hustle and bustle of the traffic in the streets. You can easily walk here from the center, stroll along the docks, look at the fancy yachts, enjoy a coffee or glass of wine in one of the trendy places, and at the end cross the Puente de la Mujer (bridge) and watch couples show-off their tango skills for dazzled tourists.
Good for a walk. Good for an early morning or late afternoon walk as the weather would be cooler. Many restaurants along the Riverside Walk with varying price range, so shop as you stroll along.

Typical Waterfront Area. Had drinks at the Faena Hotel and strolled the waterfront. Not much different than any waterfront touristy area in the US. Not as interesting or pretty as Southstreet Seaport (NY), Pikes Place (Seattle), or the Ferry Building (San Francisco).
Best Meat in the City. If you had one more meal to eat meat in your life this would defenitly be the place. It makes Morton's or the Plam look like McDonalds.

Cool buildings, felt safe. This is supposed to be the safest area in Buenos Aires, and it definitely felt safe. The buildings were new and looked really modern and beautiful. We spent most of our time just walking, and then biking through the Ecological Reserve. Nice area to walk around. Probably avoid the restaurants if you're on a budget.
Nice place to visit. A good place to waste a few hours with a good selection of restaurants and bars, one small tip don't go until late morning as things do not open early.

Uppity, with good restaurants. Puerto Madero is like a foreign city within the city of Buenos Aires. It has none of the charm of the older colorful neighborhoods. You will find expensive apartments and hotels and high class restaurants. There is good walking along the port edge. It's probably the safest part of the city.
Cool Place. Good place for pictures, safe, lots of people around. Good restaurants. I go to Puerto Madero every time I go to Buenos Aires.
Nice restaurants. This rundown part of Buenos Aires has been modernised with nice restaurants, modern hotels , shopping center and a yacht club. There is also an eco park
Puerto Madero. Good atmosphere and food, prices are higher than expected, but very nice for walking and have chatting with friends in one of those restaurants.

Great place for a Sunday stroll!. It seemed like about a million people were strolling this fine Sunday afternoon, yet it didn't seem crowded. The riverwalks are also well-patrolled and probably as crime-free as possible. There are lots of places to choose from for meals, drinks, and ice cream.

A lovely new part of the city and excellent restaurants. I loved Puerto Madero for its fine restaurants and excellent hiking. I am allergic to gluten, and every restaurant I visited in Puerto Madero could accommodate me, which was lovely.

What a Beautiful Stroll !. My husband and I are spending two months in Buenos Aires from Canada. We rented an apt for the first month in Recoleta and love the central location - we've walked to and from almost every neighborhood from our location. Very much a 'big city feel' here in Recoleta.We took a very short bus ride down to "the docks" - we walked around all the the surrounding neighborhoods, San Telmo and left the Docks until last for a lunch by the water - we had a very affordable - fantastic lunch (65 peso's each) and absolutely fell in the love with this quiet, relaxed, modern neighborhood. We rented an apt for our second month - which cost us less then our Recoleta Apt - but this one includes, pool and gym - The new neighborhood is convenient (grocery and drug store) and a walk to San Telmo Market on Saturdays.We are very much looking forward to our month in Puerto Madero.

Beautiful area for a stroll and a drink. A couple of friends and I enjoyed a nice stroll along the spacious walkway. We admired the beautiful boats and all the lovely restaurants. It's a well-maintained and clean area and definitely worth checking out. We had some lovely Malbec and some greasy but delicious calamari at one of the restaurants. It was nice to chat and kick back as the sun went down around 8 pm. Definitely check this area out!
Good for a Walk. It is a renovated area of Buenos Aires, with a lot of restaurants and offices, not so many stores. It is beautiful to see the river and the skyline.

Safe, quiet area to walk. We went to visit the bridge and see the old ship that is docked here, which my husband LOVED! There are great places to eat right off the waterway. It is one of the safest areas of the city.
Very nice place. Don't hesitate in go around a warm summer night and eat something in the beautiful riverside restaurants.

Great new area of BA.... Wonderful to walk around and see all the new shops and restaurants. Catering mostly to the tourists and the rich so don't be surprized at the prices on the menu. Great during the daytime and the night time. Easy walk from the Micro Centre.

Beautiful walking around area!. We stayed at the Hilton Buenos Aires, which is within walking distance, and Puerto Madero is full of restaurants and extremely pleasant to walk around. It has a Marina/river view which is incredible and we found it to be very safe, with people jogging and bicycling and just having a nice time. Do go!

Safest area in BA. It is the safest area in Buenos Aires, there are camera EVERYWHERE! You have many restaurants, some museums and very close to downtown. You have a lovely bridge that is one of BA's new landmarks. In summer it's great to visit it at night cause it's not that hot and very illuminated. Inside Puerto Madero you have no internal transportation, but you don't need it cause everything is close, you have a tram, but not usefull at all. The best thing you can do is to have dinner (argentinian meat) and the stroll along the docks

Place to walk in buenos aires. Safe and beautifull place with a lot of restaurants, bars, cafes opned till late at night. Many people walk along the banks of the old port. Looks very beautifull in the night time

End of Afternoon and Night. Nice place, good for walk, but my suggestion is to visit at end of afternoon, for a drink or ice cream and at night for a good diner. Avoid go by morning or for lunch time.
Overkill. Too many restaurants in this new section of the city. They charge too much and aren't that crash hot. Very disappointing indeed.

A walk at Puerto Madera. The newest neighbourhood in Buenos Aires. It is very pleasant to walk across the decks of theriver bank and admiring the skyscrappers, the old warehouses that have been converted to elegant restaurants and cafes, the sailing boats. At dask is the best time of the day to go there

Think modern. Puerto Madero is modern. It has docks, ultra modern architecture and an ecological reserve. When I was there there was a good band playing near the ecological reserve. It is definitely worth a visit.

Great Area to Walk. This area is a great walking area to escape the traffic and horn honking of Buenos Aires. My husband and I went for a mid morning stroll each morning while in Buenos Aires. The area was quite quiet - a few other walkers, some joggers, and some roller-bladers. Restaurants were just preparing for lunch. ......nice area to walk.....

Great to visit in Buenos Aires. Besides, the good restaurants, has a great musuem to visit with a great cafe, The Fragata, and the Ponte de la Mujer, with Nice Archtechure, nice park area to walk and run, and acess to Colonia do Sacramento (Very Charmin City), by Buquebus!
The firestrokes in New Years Eave is very Nice to See!
Have to Visit!
Grreat retaurants. A gresat place to find a large variety of restaurants. An evening stroll along the waterfront is a relaxing way to walk off a wonderful meal.

Nice new part of town. Down by the harbour is a new and modern part of BA. It is a very nice area to walk around and if you are not on a budget then the restuarants and bars along the harbour will oblige your appetite. Some very nice places to eat and drink!

Restaurants galore!. Puerto Maduro is located at the waterfront. Many restaurants and a few old sailing frigates are located there. Also, there is a casino that I did not visit is located at Puero Maduro. Taxis are a bargain in Buenos Aires. The exchange rate during our visit was about 5.4 pesos to the dollar.

A brilliant urban renewal project. This is a great district to stroll through, and if you have time, for a meal or a drink. One one side of the wide canal are the renovated 19C red brick buildings, full of restos and bars, many with attractive outdoor areas. On the other side are high-end modern buildings (including the Hilton Hotel). Connecting them is one of the world's most beautiful foot bridges. For history buffs, there are traces of the old port (e.g. scenic cranes frozen in time) AND 2 historic ships of the Argentine Navy, now floating museums (with v.v. inexpensive entrance fees); made in England, but this little fact is not mentioned...

Great restaurants. There are a ton of good restaurants to choose from in this area and it is a nice place to walk around. Would strongly suggest grabbing an ice cream at Freddo... It is expensive but some of the best ice cream I have ever had!
Great place to walk around and eat. This is a nice place for walks, where you can also find many good restaurants. Definetely a must-go in BA.

New years eve. The port is nice to see at day and night. If you spend the New years eve there, you have to reservate a restaurant. It's expensive. Don't go to the Fregata Restaurant. The food is discusting and the staff is not very friendly that night. Be payed 300 ARS for this meal. It's to expensive for 2 dry hamburgers, a bottle of champagne and 2 drinks. But on this night we hadn't any other joyice.
Nice view, with good restaurants. Nice to walk by, have a cup of coffee or specially a meal, as there are very good restaurants there.

Lovely walk along riverside. I would recommend visiting this part of town, we enjoyed a long walk along the river in this tranquil upmarket part of town. We didnt eat there but the restaurants looked lovely. A nice break after the touristy madness that was plaza de mayo

Lacks personality. Puerto Madero is clean and has a nice broad walkway next to the water but it doesn't have the history and charm of other parts of the city (ex. Recoleta, Belgrano, San Telmo). It's a nice place to take a stroll, though, and there are good dining options with outdoor seating along the water. Also in the 'hood is a pretty good tango option in Madero Tango and nice museum with Fortabat at the opposite end of the waterway.

Nice walk along the port. Very nice to walk along the port. We also noticed several couples walking very early in the morning (2 AM) as we were checking out of the hotel. It's a good and safe area that's close to almost all attractions.

New Years Day Is not the Day to Go. Almost 98% of Buenos Aires closes on Christmas and New Years Day. So you will be hard pressed to find any venue or restaurant open. But dur to lack of traffic a wonderful day to walk by the water and see the city.

Impressive Port Area. Was very impressed with the old port area that has been converted into restaurants, shops, and even a university. A stroll along the old wares is safe and pleasant. It is well lit and patrolled by Navy police. 100 year old ships are docked along the quay. Across the port are modern office buildings. Restaurants are a bit pricey, but very good.
Easy trip to Colonia.. New port is very efficient at boat arrivals and departures to Colonia an Tigra. Need to have ticket vouches before to expedite tickets

Wonderful breezy part of BsAs. When you are in Puerto Madero you realise why BsAs got that name as you definitely feel the fair wind that blows. Puerto Madero is a interesting confluence of band new glass and steel buildings on one shore and old red brick structures on the other. A number of good restaurants are available on boh sides and this is a good spot to come and relax after a long day of walking in the heat.Of coruse as a tourist you have to go to the other side over the "puente de la mujer".Enjoy this beaitiful part of this city on your visit.
The new and modern part of Buenos Aires.-. This new area of ​​Buenos Aires, is very modern and nice. This is an old port, and Recycling your total. There are nice parks and is close to the river!

Buenos Aires nightlife destination. This neighborhood graces the Buenos Aires shore, outlined by beautiful architecture and excellent restaurants. I highly recommend a stroll down the harbor, and a stop at the Faena Hotel to feast your eyes and taste buds.
Great location to stay. Great area to walk and eat. Plenty of bars and restaurants. Safe to walk around at night. Enjoyed looking at the high office buildings that were illuminated at the tops.

Reflection of old Buenos Aires to the new Buenos Aires. Beautiful walk and great food in the area, it is a very different view to see on one side of the port old buildings and the other side is new buildings.
good restaurants. There are many nice places to eat in this area. It is also a pleasant stroll along the river,you can also cross Womens Bridge. This looks like a fairky new area.
Relaxing walk by the water. Enjoyed the walk along the water. Take a bit of time to explore the old ship that is docked in the harbor.
Old becomes new. The old, now restored port, is Buenos Aires' most modernneighborhood. Nice place to take a stroll and have lunchor dinner

Nice walk. Went there on our first night in Buenos Aires after 16h in a plane. Worth going for dinner in the area to walk around... But don't plan too much time there. Lots of restaurants, it's a good way to end a long day!

Puerto Madero. Lots of pricey restaurants but still cheaper for an excellent meal, comparable to what you would get in United States. Its a nice walk. Took some nice pictures of the Bridge.
i walked from plaza dorrega in San Telmo to Puerto Madero in about 20 minutes.
New neighborhood. The newest and more exclusive neoighborhood, super nice to walk around, day or night, good restaurants, five star hotels, "the" place to visit these days :)

Very upscale and great walking area. We returned from Uruguay and decided to walk the puerto Madeira. Keep in mind, restaurants are closed until 8 pm when they open for dinner. We walked and walked admiring the views and the water. Old warehouses have been converted to expensive homes on top of retail space.
A nice walk. Fancy restaurants, some nice shopping, great views of expensive boats and high power office building. Is essentially the typical port gentrification project!

Picturesque, clean, but not much to do. A very pretty part of BA, its not too different from Federation Wharf in Melbourne or Darling Harbour in Sydney. Good for taking pretty pictures, especially against the Woman's Bridge. Many restaurants. We had coffee at Faena Hotel nearby, interiors designed by Philippe Starck - the lobby area was a treat for the senses - it looked and smelled awesome and an amazing restroom.

A credit to BA. Although I didn't spend a lot of time here what I did see I pressed me. It is clean and safe, full of good restaurants and having it own security force watching over the place. The views at night are stunning and are every photographers dream with fantastically placed lighting highlighting on what was once a grubby unkept port.

What's the fuzz all about?. All our argentine friends asked, "have you visited Puerto Madero"? They all recommended it. Perhaps our expectations were too high but we cannot figure out what is the fuzz all about. It is little more than a collection of expensive bars and all-you-can-eat restaurants built on recycled old warehouses. May be portenos don't have enough green spaces or walking paths. To us, it was OK but nothing special.
A world away from real BA. Spend your time in San Telmo instead.... or La Boca or downtown. Puerto Madero is too flashy and hence too expensive.

Expensive but upscale dinner choices. Pretty waterside walkway, safe nice place to stroll. Many expensive choices for dinner. We had a great (but expensive) dinner at Las Lillas, if price is no object..go there great steaks. Nice place for a stroll and gellato

Sea and peace in Buenos aires. The atmosphere was peaceful and relaxing in this beginning night.All kinds of people strolling around but not too much. A mixture of ancient and modern buildings. Plenty of restaurants, little coffe shops. A great place if you like walking as it is very big and safe.
great area. lots of restaurants in Puerto Medero. You dont have to eat you can just walk around the area visits pubs, shop or just walk around the area which is on a redeveloped port area
Great couples spot. Lots of restaurants right along the water, a really nice walk. Also if you are feeling up for the casino it is not too far away.
great dining choices. Lots of choices in a small pedestrian friendly and very safe environment. But the price of meals reflects that.
Great Place - bit pricey, but very very safe. Nice walk in the evening, nice marina area, lots of places to eat, and lots of people about - nice calm relaxed atmosphere

Nice place- but not that exciting. This is the one area of Buenos Aires I found a bit touristy and the food was more expensive. It's a great place for an evening stroll, but there is not much to do. The cranes look great- especially at night

Upscale restaurants in the new city area. Old port district, you will really need a cab to get there unless you want a good walk, you will defiantly need a cab after, it's an uphill walk to the hotels in D.T. B.A. Many choices, prices normally on the higher side

A great new addition to BsAs. We walked along the river with a view of the new side of Puerto Madero. It was a very scenic and relaxing walk. You hit the wow factor of seeing the bridge illuminated at night. There are an ample number of restaurants on both sides of the water. It was nice to see that there are new areas of the city as well with skyscrapers. That this was old abounded dock land shows that there are creative uses for dilapidated areas

A great area for a walk and something to eat. This is a nice, new, clean area of BA. Plenty of restaurants to visit and there's an old boat to check out as well which you can walk around inside as it's been turned into a museum.

Pleasant walk, great restaurants. Converted docks, great to walk around, with the beautiful Santiago Calatrava bridge spanning the docks. The restaurants in the docks are also excellent, but are mostly overpriced and somewhat formal.
nice for a stroll. this is one of the cleanest areas of Buenos aires, excellent for a stroll on a summer day, various shops and restaurants, gower it is priced for the tourist, No bargains here

Beautiful Area to walk around and eat at local restaurants. We had dinner at Cristal-elegant, wonderful-super views. The Puente de las Mujeres is stunning. Daytime visits to the two boat museums! Nighttime for dining and just looking at the views.

The Other Buenos Aires. Completely different than downtown... lots of new condos and restaurants.... clean.. grafitti free... great lunch at Rodizio...and dont forget to have a drink by the pool at the HotelFaena

Lovely walk. We took a long walk aaround Puerto Madero which was absolutely stunning. The docks harbour beautiful old ships as museums, the glitz od the glass offices on the one side and the red brick restaurants on the other is fabulous and it was allround a lovely walk to take.

It's hallow, bereft of people, oozing in LA design. Coming from NY I am well versed in old warehouses turned into chic modern (just think of the Meat market district), and having written plenty of resto reviews for magazines I'm also perfectly well accustomed to "LA Cool" design of glass and glare, but Puerto Madero does not not not pull it off. And that's all it aims to do, is merge its name with S'pore, LA or Miami. Walk a bit more to Montserrat or San Telmo or better yet, jump on the metro for the leafy hood of Palermo where you get a bit of cafe history!

Great for dinner & Casino Night. This is a beautiful area of Buenos Aires very good to go at sunset walk take pictures and then have a steak in one of many restaurants in Puerto Madero..after that you can walk to the casino!A good plan too is go biking Dont miss it and Enjoy!
Chic Area. Lively restaurant scene. Safe and walking distance to metro and Plaza Mayo and other areas. Best place to stay in BA outside of Recoleta. And I prefer PM.

Perfect place on Saturday afternoon. To walk, to find people, to find other tourists from your country...To eat... And "parrillada" there is not so expensive! The price is not so different from other restaurants downtown.
Very nice area. Our hotel was located in this area. It is a nice mix of hotels and residential with lots of restaurants, shops, bars, etc, all in walking distance

Muy bonito. This place is good to take good pictures, to eat a great meal (can be expensive), to read a book, learn some Argentina history (you can go inside of a frigate there), exercise or dance (there are discos). Very nice!

Not sure what the fuss is about. I headed to Puerto Madero to walk around... and was underwhelmed. There were a bunch of generic international-looking restaurants, office buildings and not much else. The "Mother" bridge is nice to look at... for a minute. I wouldn't necessarily bother heading down here again.

Fine dinning. Many beautiful restaurants,
be careful leaving late at night, use only a radio-taxi.
The area it self appears quite safe, but the surrounding area
is questionable. Just be careful.

Enjoyable walk along the water lots of eateries.. We had a few hours before our flight so wondered along the Ladies Bridge and enjoyed walking along the promenade looking at the restored Docklands bulidings. Lots of delicious eateries to suit all budgets.Husband went to fantastic steak restaurant here one night.

Be careful. We stayed at a hotel in this area(Hilton) and two of the people
in our convention were robbed. Be aware at all times.
Moved hotels later in our stay to the Mio Hotel in Recoleta. We
felt much safer than the Puerto Madero area. Be aware of
the mosquitos-take bug spray.
Great location and excellent food.. Good for a walk around and excellent job done in refurbishing the old docks and turned them into a great place to visit. Good food too!

Nice place. It is another Buenos Aires. Nice, clean and safe
Has a lot of options to see, eat and drink
Very good access to places, near from some city icons
Pretty. nice place for dinner with a view. There are a few nice restaurants with e view of the river and some bars. Restaurants seem to range from very casual to upscale fine dining.

Great new part of the city!. Nice walks along the canals/dikes. Old warehouses now turned into fashionable housing and hotels. Great dinner at Philip Starck designed hotel Faena restaurant, food was bliss!

stunning part of town. we loved this area which was clean, modern and well cared for , in stark contrast with much of the rest of the city cventre which we found to be 'broken' and full of graphitti.Lunch in one of the riverside restaurants is an absolute delight. Similarly, if you want cheap adn very authentic, walk two blocks away from town and eat at one of the many street food 'Carrillas' serving grilled meat or sausage, with help yourself salads for about $4- fantastic!

A walk past a too new area.. Puerto Madero can be reached from a few major crossings from the main city. Once there you find yourself in fairly busy area; restaurants on the city side, and lunch places on the office side. Most people seem to work there, judgeing by the electronic entry passes dangling from their belts...It is a change from the old city, but frankly rather boring compared to the lively old city center..

Lacking Grace and Character of Buenos Aires.. Here is the Argentine answer to London's Docklands. Eventually -with the addition of shade trees - this comparatively new area, in the old warehouse district, will attain a degree of gentrified charm. In the interim, it is hot or cold, windy and pricey and the entire area - with its soaring apartment high-rises and paucity of street level personal emenities and haunts - is entirely out of human scale and proportion. If you are considering a longer term rental property in this barrio, know that it is a trudge to the Metro -thus locals keep cars secure behind gated walls - and it is the one place in Buenos Aires where taxis seem not to cruise, although on the city center side there is the broad but noisy Avenida de Justo. For some being near to canal water might outweigh these considerations. For the historically minded tourist the Sarmiento Frigate Museum is worth a look and the fancifully winged pedestrian bridge is a photo-op.

Touristy but nice to see. There are many restaurants and bars. The sites are very nice. The old building on one side and the new on the other provides a nice scene. It is interesting. Worth seeing. Have lunch or dinner. Walk around. That is enough for me.
Nice area but not soul.. Good investments. Nice area for walking and enjoy dinner and nights but I prefer sth with more history. That had one and was deleted.

Great for a stroll!. Loved walking around the boardwalk. Make sure to visit the Ecological Reserve - There are many places along it that sell fresh juices, food, and some stalls with antiques and trinkets. Prices seemed much more reasonable than elseware ($8 for fresh orange juice vs. $15 nearby on Defensa St). Lots of locals and they were all lovely. Highly recommended for a relaxing afternoon on a nice day.

Great Environment. It is a very expensive area, but well worth the trip one night to see. La Bisteca or Isla Cabanas should be your restuarant of choice. Make reservations before hand for both places.

Modern side of Buenos Aires. This is the modern, contemporary district of Buenos Aires. It is well planed; with parks, beautiful avenues, great restaurants. You can spend many afternoons and evenings walking, eating or just enjoying the environment.

A soulless stroll. Puerto Madero is one of those modern "points of interest" that could be just about anywhere in the world, wih good but expensive restaurants, some visual interest thrown in as an afterthought, convenient to tourists and therefore crawling with panhandlers vying for their attention. Nothing about it is representative of Argentina or Buenos Aires. If you're staying anyplace else in the city, it's not worth making it a point to go there. There are much better places to eat or visit, with more local flavor.
Moderne. Thé moderne part of buenos aires , so Nice to Walk there during thé night , and eat something , many good restaurants

Efficient and impressive. A great place from which to approach the city sky line of Biuenos Aires by Buquebus from Montevideo, Uruguay, and strategically close to the city centre of Buenos Aires. Just watch out for pushy taxi drivers who charge you way too much. Only use taxis that have a taximeter.

Saturday in Puerto Madero. Walking along Rio de la Plata and having lunch in one of the numerous restaurant was special experience. Meeting friendly travellers from around the globe, you feel surrounded by your closest friends. Later we visited Fortabat Museum and Ecological Reserve

Great area. The growth in this area has been amazing in the last 7 years. Now full of gleaming towers and lots of life. The casino is fun, the stroll along the river is nice, and my favorite restaurant also just happens to be there (La Bistecca).

Good excuse to have lunch/wine while it's raining.. Nice area for a stroll and grab some lunch with a glass of wine. We went on a very rainy day which made it very cosy. Nice to sit along the water and people watch and just relax. Worth a stroll/visit while at Plaza de Mayo.

Great for a stroll. It is clean, relatively safe and there is a restaurant specializing in steak every ten paces. It almost feels as though you are getting away from the grime of, say, Corrientes when you wander along on a sunny day.
For an easy stroll. Nothing much to view, places around here seem way too pricey for the value. $7.00 for a small glass of beer!
Great area in the city. There are a ton of bars and restaurants along the water here and a great view of the bridge! A lot of people day and night so feel very safe.

Lovely place to stroll and dine. We were glad we went to Puerto Madero. One of the BA guide books said not to bother, but we really like the ambiance there. It's peaceful, quieter than the main city, and not as busy. The restaurants are plentiful, and spacious. We were there during a nice afternoon - great weather. If we were ever to live in BA or stay for an extended time. This is where we would want to stay.
not so great. nice view but there is not a lot to see.nice restaurant but very expensive.come only in a good weather.
