Money to throw?. There are fancy schmancy places if that is your scene. Two weeks ago we went to an Italian restaurant - had some fish fillet and salad - what we spent was my grocery bill for two weeks, what we ate was cardboard!
New and cosmopolitan. Not much to see though recommend the Library Bar at Feona hotel and good stroll by the water, not much else to say about this place
Modern. This is an impressive redesign of what the old factories used to be. Fabulous to spend the day walking, a lot of restaurants and cafe's so that you can take a break.

Old docks converted to trendy restaurants and apartments. It's a nice place. Beautiful buildings, interesting stuff to see, a nice park. The street skate starts from here for those who're interested. Or just sit with a coffee and enjoy the view.

Beautiful sunset view. Puerto Madero is a beautiful place to spend some times enjoying the view and eat in some modern restaurant. I suggest Cabaña Las Lilas, is a amazing place, nice decoration and good food.

tired of steak? YOU SHOULD TRY OSAKA!!!!. OSAKA!
Sushi with a peruvian touch... Soooooo good!
Had a pleasure to met one of the owners. Such a gentleman!
It was a great night with an amazing passion fruit pisco sour and beautiful friends!

Fine Dining Fine Arts. In what used to be the old docks of the city harbor, Puerto Madero was re-invented as one of the top dining destinations in Buenos Aires. The standards are very high, including median prices. While there, make the most and plan a visit to Coleccion de Arte Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat, one of Argentina's most celebrated late philanthropists that donated her magnificent art collection and museum for public enjoyment ( I believe entrance fees apply )

Nice but very pricey dining. Our family of 4 enjoyed walking around Puerto Madero. We went on the floating naval museum, ate ice cream at Freddo (a must do in BA...we've never had so many types of dulce de leche ever!) and ate dinner there twice in a month. The restaurants are the most expensive we found in BA, but we enjoyed sitting outside on a nice evening and watching the people walk by. Dinners don't really start there until about 9. We ate at the sushi restaurant and enjoyed it.
Beautiful place. A beautiful place with excelents restaurants. After visiting Puerto Madero go to Parque de las Mujeres to relax

A great place to walk or sit and enjoy the view. Puerto Madera is a lovely relaxed area near the water. There are a lot of bars and cafes where you can sit and enjoy the view of docks with beautiful boats and yachts. It is much calmer than the city center, and much cleaner. There are a lot of people walking, running and roller skating next to the canals. If you walk all the way to the end, to the nature reserve side, there are multiple street food vendors with lots of great choices. It is a fun, peaceful, and delicious adventure.

Fine for strolling, but not much to see. It is a nice enough neighbourhood but distinctly lacks shopping. There are plenty of cafes and fine places to walk. Doesn't seem like there is a lot going on though apart from dining
Puerto Madero. Lovely spot in Beunos Aires, so many restaurant choices, very good service at the restaurants we visited there, lovely to just stroll and people watch

Beautiful. Puerto Madero is quite expensive, but is also right along the water and a beatiful place to have dinner outside or even go to one of hte bars/clubs there. Definitely a place to check out if you're willing to spend a lil bit more money. However, it is also a beautiful place to walk around during a nice day
Excellent Restaurants. Just about any restaurant you pick will be good. The area is spectacular at night due to the great lighting.
Beautiful and new!. We ate at Cabana La Lilas. Excellent food. Great views of the Rio de la Plata. All the buildings around are new. Everything is clean.

A place to visit. Enjoy the harbor and the bars!
For me the best place to stay in town - the modern Buenos Aires of course
Nice Upbeat location. Nice, safe, clean better areas with plenty of young professionals and their families. Selectionof restuarants were very good.

Beautiful place to walk and lunch or dinner. This very famous neighborhood is beautiful and resides in the heart of the city. The old port was transformed into a complex of fancy restaurants and coffes places. You can also just walk by the river and enjoy a sunny day.

Walk along the water. It was quiet in the city due to a public holiday, so joined the locals for a walk along the river. Due to the bridges it is easy to walk up one side & down the other. Many many very over priced cafes and restaurants line the way as do 2 boat museums. These boats are moored in the river and you can visit to see what was a working boat - probably better to go in the week to avoid the crowds - but value at 2 pesos each.The marina was also good for a look at the boats - but these were of the private type - shows the money that is in BA. If you're into roller skating join the skaters. Or just sit and watch the world go by

Nice place to stay but not the real taste of BA. If your travel takes you to Puerto Madero on business, it is a decent area to wander in the evening but it is not where I would stay if I wanted to get to enjoy the real BA. It is too new, too antiseptic and too expensive. Last time I was in BA, I stayed there because my office is in PM but for the week I was there at my own cost, I stayed at a B&B south of town.
Very nice and expensive.. I had a bowl of spaghetti and a salad for $30 USD. This did not include the tip. Overpriced, but the restaurant is on the river, and it was nice.

Nice Place for a Stroll. The port area is sprawling, but easily navigable (they have "You are here" kiosks all over). In contrast to almost all of Buenos Aires, the streets, sidewalks and paths are smooth, wide and well lit. With the exception of the canal and the Avenue along the ecological preserve near the waterfront (the most interesting parts), all of the buildings and infrastructure are new and shiny. As you can see from the images below, a great time of day to visit this city within a city is near dusk: the lighting is beautiful and traffic is at a minimum. From what we understand, after dark, the port is bustling with people eating at expensive restaurants and cafes (they even have a TGI Fridays) and/or going to dance clubs. While we didn't dance, Puerto Madero is a great place to take a stroll.

Needs work and ambience. We walked along the side of the river, the whole way. Not much too see, restaurants only. Needs work and some prettying up. Footpath very uneven to walk on, just like the rest of buenos aires. The good part was the armada Argentina frigate musuem. Only 2 pesos each and lots too see. The best thing was the bathrooms. Clean and spacious for a boat. If you are in the puerto madero area and need to go, spend the 2 pesos. It's a lifesaver.
Expensive. Great place to walk during the day and have a very expensive lunch. Walk and then explore more interesting parts of BA
Very nice transformation of an old port. Lots of nice restaurants, very well done. There are 2 ships you can visit while there as well. Restaurants are a little pricey but the food is good.

You know the joke about Argentines pretending to be European?. Walk by the old "puerto" and you'll see why that is. Stunning boardwalks with great restaurants and atmosphere. An absolute must if you're looking to fall in love with Buenos Aires.

Hate to give it 3 stars. This area is new about 10 yeas now, VERY SAFE and clean some pretty wild hotels, you must have drinks at the Faena this is rock star meets giggelo meets movie star and wanna bees... The unicorn restaurant is amazing and the Tango show very nice. now why I gave the area a 3 star is only because its not Buenos Aires! If you want to go so many thousands of miles away only to feel like you are in your town, then go, but this city and county is so steeped in history, thanks to the Germans and world war two. Buenos Aires is a melting pot you will se the French, Italian, Spanish, British etc... Do I diss like the Puerto Madero area NO!!! Its just not how I want to spend my time in BsAs after a 15 hour flight.

newest area in the city. This place used to be the city docks and was recently refurbished to hold posh apartments and the best restaurants and hotels. Everything is new and it is considered the safest place in the city guarded not only by local police but also by the coastal forces as it placed in their jurisdiction
Nice place to visit.. You walk all around, can visit the Sarmientos Fragata just $2 pesos, also de Uruguay Fragata and then visit one of the many restaurant that are there.

My favorite neighborhood. This neighborhood took my breath away, the architecture is incredible, very clean and there is a selection of restaurants, museums, tango bars, sports bars and people very friendly and helpful, it is an attraction that you should enjoy.
Beautiful popular waterside venue. Modern restaurants next to an attractive marina. Lovely place to spend an afternoon outside minus the cars and traffic.

Upscale area of BA!. Puerto Madero is a great place to spend an afternoon walking around after having a nice long lunch overlooking the water! There are tons of restaurants but only a couple of shopping places which was a little disappointing. At night the lights around the area are wonderful as you could sit outside and dine! Very safe!

Nice and modern area. Puerto Madero is a very modern and trendy area, full of restaurants and lovely to walk by the river.It is very lively at night time and busy during the day. I would suggest you visited the area on a sunny day, since it can get a bit windy due to its proximity to the river.

Very Elegant, Original, Modern, and Nice. I really enjoyed this part of Argentina, the buildings almost have a modern art kind of appearance, unlike the rest of BA, I highly suggest visiting there to see a different kind of style of buildings.

a MUST for Business Travelers. This is a MUST for all business travelers, even thought it might not be the BEST restaurant is an icon your are not allowed to miss.Pros- The food is excellent- Cows are grown by them so that's a good experience- Servings are HUGECons- a bit expensive (like 75 per person)Besides the "expensiveness" its a great restaurant with a great service and awesome stakes.

Great evening venue. If you are looking for a gentle evening out i would suggest a stroll around Puerto Madero in the dark - for some great night shots of the city with stars inthe sky. Also you can get a stunning view of the Puente de la Mujer bridge. We ate in one of the resturants - Cabana las Lilas - reputed to be one of the cities top resturants - but there are plenty of others to chose from at cheaper rates.
Gostei do lugar! Requintado!. I liked the place! Exquisite! View Wonderful! Fantastic restaurants, kitchen barbaric! Really, a great place to start for anyone who wants to know Buenos Aires.

Very unique and full of restaurants. Worth the trip to this renovated former working port and dock. There are so many restaurants to try - pick just about any one, depending upon what you like to eat.Also, just walking along the waterday at bothndaynor night is very charming and relaxing.
Very Nice. Scenic... safe... Nice time. A great spot to have dinner. Plenty of nice restaurants and great service. They really cater to you.

A great evening stroll. Although similiar in design and character to many other "dockland" areas around the world Puerto Madero has the benefit of a beautifully designed bridge, the "Bridge of the Woman". Stunning to look at and consider just how clever the design is for opening and closing across Dique No 3.

Excellent Restaurants. High level restaurants all in one place!Puerto Madero is a group of buildings whit a lot of the bests restaurants of Argentina. Is a little expensive so be prepared to enjoy a good attention and a very recommendable food
New BA. This is the newest part of BA. Unfortunately Museo Fortabat was closed. Worth a visit if time permits but don't break your neck
Romantic. This is one of the nicest areas of the City, perfect for a romantic walk. During the day I didn't find it that nice, but at night, it's just a perfect place to hang out.

Very Modern. Visited Puerto Madero on our last day. Wish we had come earlier! The area is so active -- great place to take advantage of great weather and go for a quick run, or a pleasant stroll. Definitely commercialized with coffee shops every other building, but beautiful area, lots of activity and a great place to enjoy the weather. This area almost felt like a different city because of how modern it is, but it is a nice pocket in a very historical city!
Nice area to stroll and enjoy a nice day.. Restaurants and cafes, easy access to parking across street, some chain restaurants ruin the atmosphere.
Top area of restaurants. You can find many kind of restaurants and several price levels in puerto madero, is easy to get there and is a safe place.
Eh, not much there. A modern development very different from the Buenos Aires character that attracted us to the city in the first place. You can skip it.
Full of restaurants. great pier full of restaurants and big view of the modern buildings. great place for pleasure, walk, bike and run.

Beautiful and Safe. This area has great restaurants and is very safe, even to walk around late at night (the area is patrolled 24 hours a day by the Argentina's Coast Guard.) There are also some good restaurants, but they can be a little pricey.
Very nice place. A place very beautiful, modern and with lots of restaurants. Go there if you want a pleasant walk and a good meal.

Refurbished Area. This area will remind you of that area (inner harbor, riverwalk) of the city that was run down and has been turned expensive and trendy. It is a nice area though with a lovely view of the port and yachts docked here. The sides are lined with (pricey) restaurants and shops. It is very nice in the evenings when the lights come on all around. The riverwalk goes much further than you might think so the whole area will take a good couple of hours to complete walk.

Feel like in 1st world country. While visiting Buenos Aires, you must come to Puerto Madero. This exclusive area is getting bigger and bigger year by year. Hi- Class restaurants and Hotels combined with a very modern architecture will make you feel you are in a first word city.

Nice!!. We did a cycle tour (by ourselves) through the park and Puerto Madero, it's a really quiet compare to the rest of the city and you'll have beautiful views at waterfront! Really nice to spend a day there!
been there since they start build Puerto Madero.. love been there to eat ...stay and drink....the place is so beautiful and nice people there ....i just love it. and i want to go again.

A true example. Puerto Madero is a true example of how you can recover an area of the city - as this use to be shipyards. It's like a mini city that is well designed and organized - ample sidewalks, broad streets, open spaces.. it`s great for a walk and there are many many options to chose from for great dinning - however consider it a little pricey.

Nice waterfront area..... This is a great place for a stroll. The restaurants are good, but a little expensive and always crowded. Take a stroll past the Hotel Faena and hop in and have a drink and see the Philippe Stark decorated interior.

Beautifully renovated area. I never saw this area before renovation, but I heard it was just a row of docks by the Rio de la Plata.Now it it is full of great restaurants with walkways in front and in the back. The whole area became renovated – even across the river, with new buildings and hotels.

Ok. Ok area. If you are an experienced traveler you surely have seen much better. I love to try new restaurants and splurge with food but found the entire area so unreasonably expensive and the service is generally rude. For dinner go to the recoleta neighbourhood, many options, nicer walk and better prices.

Nicest and chic area in Buenos Aires. My favorite place in BA. The area is safe, nice to walk around in the morning or at night. You can find great restaurants here. I specially recommend Cabaña las Lilas for great Argentinean meat. This is the most extensive neighborhood to live so you can find great houses, flats and hotels.The best area to hang out at night, unless you are looking for dance clubs in which case you should go to Palermo Hollywood.
Modern harbor. Very nice renew district. Sidewalk safe for a long walk. old navy wood boat to be seen and visited. Nice area to shoot architectural photography.

i ate half a cow! i need to return to eat the other half!. the "all you can eat" type of approach, the selections of meat cuts, the attention of the staff!....a tip: give a tip to the "asador" and expect the best type of meat on your plate!...try the morcillas and chorizos and do not fill yourself up with potatoes and sushi!...that can wait...:-)
do lunch here. a lot of small open air restaurants in this area which is perfect for a few beers and light lunch. Very touristy.
Fun area to walk around in. I enjoyed seeing the dog walkers and going to the nature area nearby. This is a nice area with expensive condos and apartments.

nice for a stroll. This is a nice regenerated harbour area with very modern buildings. There are heaps of restaurants to choose from with lots of them having tables outside even on a windy cool July day. The best of the restaurants seem to be on the far side over the bridges. We spent some time people watching - loads of folk with cute dogs, skateboarders, roller-bladers. There is a very nice tea shop on one of the corners which also sold excellent ice cream. Restaurants all seed to be pretty overpriced and many closed in the afternoon.

Nice area to walk. Nice area to walk around. The bridge everyone raves about is suppose to resemble a woman or tango dancers or something of that nature. All I saw was a bridge.
When I visited there were plenty of families and couples out for a Sunday afternoon stroll.

New reconstructed area. It's a nice place to walk and stroll in the promenade. The restaurants are overpriced. In the past were there warehouses that were next to the port today is a tourist area . Nice.
Nice area. After a good lunch or diner is nice to walk around, safe and nice atmosfere
Beautiful harbour. Too bad it was a windy day. It's a place with tons of restaurants, pubs, bars and everything you may want to find. Nice boats in a peaceful day
Nice Restaurante and landscape!. You will find lots of good restaurants, differents cousines!

NIce area to walk in and explore. Freddo's ice cream is there as well as many restaurants. It is a pleasant newly redeveloped area, upscale, and having easy access to major attractions. Lovely gardens and walking paths.
Great dining. Puerto Madero is home to many wonderful Argentinean restaurants and steak houses.

Great area to stay, dine, have fun. The whole Puerto Madero area is safe and beautiful, with many good restaurants at all price points. A very good area to stay and dine. Also, you can visit old ships, go dancing and a whole lot of other activities .... and downtown is across the street. The Galeria Pacifico shopping mall is walking distance.

Nice place to walk around or eat. I was advised to go to Puerto Madero by people who live in Argentina and made this my first stop in BA. While it was very nice and a great place to walk around, it didn't have the feel or the atmosphere that I was hoping for on my visit. It was missing the flavor that I had always associated with Buenos Aires, but it was safe and a great place to grab a bite. If you have only a few days, this is something that can be skipped in lieu of some of the other areas (i.e Palermo, San Telmo, Ricoleta etc. that seemed to be more authentic), but if you have extra time, its a nice place to have dinner.
nice restaurants there. nice restaurants there go to cabana las Lilas, Happening, La paraloccia o Marcelo.

A wonderful place to stay in Buenos Aires. All the area is new, there are parks, good restaurantes, security and you can walk along the river and appreciate the view. A place to go and stay if you can.
Steak BBQ heaven. Lots of excellent 'Parillas' along the walk ways. You definitely have to have lunch here at least once.

Overrated.... we visited Puerto Madero 10 years ago while they were still busy finishing the area and it seemed to have potential. but i must say we were disappointed on this visit....yes it is along the river, and yes there are boats and old warehouse/warf type buildings....but really this could be anywhere in the world...nothing special about it in my eyes. we tried to have breakfast there one sunday, but ended up taking a taxi back to Recoleta after a long walk around, as everything seemed too modern and standard, and we always look for more traditional and unique things while we travel. the locals love it and are happy to recommend it, and there are great "design" hotels and loads of good restaurants, just that they are the run of the mill kind of things.....not the cosy cafe along the river kind of thing...
Nice for chilling out or to take night photos. rebuilt docklands. Nice to chill out on sunny day or have a dinner. Good for night photos - a lot of nice light features
just restaurants. If you want to have dinner or lunch, this place is nice. go by the time you want to eat and then after a walk, you can choose a restaurant (nice view of the river)

The newest area in Buenos Aires. This is the newest quarter of the city of Buenos Aires. Full of impresive buildings and squares, it has a promenade near the docks, excellent for a nice walk and full of restaurants and bars.In the middle of that promenade, is the Puente de la Mujer (woman's bridge), with a very interesting architecture.There is also a Marina with many yachts.Excellent views. Do not miss your camera.

THE OVERRATED NEIGHBOURHOOD. Argentines love it, it's the most expensive part of town, apartments cost over 1US million. All new buildings, for a few exceptions you could be anywhere. It lacks the soul of Buenos Aires and it all seems very corporate. Fashionable restaurants have sprung in converted port warehouse built with Accrington bricks brought as ballast from Europe in the 19th century.Very expensive as a rule and not good value for money. If you are a high middle class argentne then you must be seen there. If you're a tourist by all means see it but bear in mind that you can get that in London and New York along the traditional ports that dissappeared when containersation rendered warehouses obsolete. Best seen at night in the Summer.

the modern area of the city. Although it is all new and modern, you can find this look in any western city.We prefered exploring the older rustic areas.The walking bridge over to this area is interesting.It opens to let big boats through.This process takes about 20 minutes.
Nice Place and Restaurants.. Definetely a place to go on your visit!Lots of options on good restaurants!!Loved it!

Fancy place. Puerto Madero is a very fancy-tourist place full of luxurious and elegant restaurants, bars and pubs. Urban landscape with modern builgings, it's a safe area, however sorroundings are not totally safe at night. Besides tourist, it's common to see bussinesmen, skaters/rollers, and joggers (not much in winter)
Madero Tango. Great food, good price, and great tango (the best in town).
Puerto Madero. The restaurants are nice and the place is charming.

PUERTO MADERO-EXCELLENT PLACE TO EAT IN BUENOS AIRES!!!. Good location, nice view, good quality of food: seafood excellent, meals, attention, service staff, comfort, a lot of restaurants of all stars...............safe place

Explore thus beautiful place. The quantity of good restaurantsa is great, you can choose to wonderful barbecue restaurants to pasta and seafood places.I recommend the barbecue pleces, tons of it in this area

European reminiscenses. This relatively new residential - and chic- area of Buenos Aires was until 20 years ago mostly a wasteland, since the silos and other abandoned buildings form the once busy port were mostly derelict.It holds a number of elegant and expensive but somehow understated apartment buildings as well as offices andrestaurants and shops. All of them rather expensive.At first, the whole area seemed rather cold, the trees along itswide avenues being then too young to add any softening input to the rather rectilinear architecture, in many instances reminding the visitor of the newly developed area around Postdamer Platz in Berlin. Now, the trees have grown tall enough to add charm and contrast to the once barren streets and there are severalnice coffee shops where one can sip a good coffee and alsovery nice photo ops, since there is a magnificent bridge byspanish architect Calatrava spanning accross a canal, part of which has been transformed into a marina.There is also a fine museum: Fundacion Fortabat whose modern structure contrasts very nicely against the old brickstructures from the old port buildings. At times, one forgets thatthis is Buenos Aires until some faint tango music brings you back. Don't be fooled by the fact that Puerto Madero has to bereached on purpose, as there are at least three major wide avenues to cross before reaching it from the older part of town.Tip: take a cab and then walk back.
A very nice place to go!. I like walking in Puerto Madero because it's a nice and pleasant. La Puente de La Mujer is a very beatiful bridge... Every time I go to Buenos Aires, I go to Puerto Madero.
Interesting place. Upscale place, nice restaurants good walk besides the river, very pretty place, we had an amazing time there.
Nice area to dine and walk. The area has nice places to eat. Unique blend of new and old. Great to visit

Great Base Station. If you are visiting Buenos Aires, especially for the first time, this is a great area to stay in and serve as the home base for your visit.Safe, Clean and Conveniently located you can walk to many of the places you want to see and easily get taxis to any farther parts of the city.
Great place to eat. Amazing food ! Fantastic asados / parillas ( BBQ meat )A must for any traveller.
Womens Bridge. Great walk, the Womens Bridge is not to be missed, great style and functionality. Dinner at Siga la Vaca is a Buenos Aires experience, eat all you want buffet.

Safe & Charming. Great place to walk around and not worry about your safety. The police are different here, they actually keep the place worry free and orderly. The restaurants are very expensive, as most tourist places are. Go to the Cuba Cafe, have an Espresso and watch the people, enjoy. Its also great for bicycles. The Boat Casino on the south side is funky, the rules are not favorable, as in most of Argentina.
Good for a long walk on a nice day. Similar to many US Harborfronts. Lots of restaurants, some shopping. Afterwards walk up to Florida Street for some "real" BA shopping!
Go at night!. Love this area. So magical...especially with a champagne on one of the wonderful patios on a nice spring or summer night! :)

Safest part of the city with great restaurants (expensive but worth it! In most cases).. Always stay for safety, convenience, and food. This time around needed a SPA and although he hotel I was on had it, they had no availability.... So I went to Hotel Puerto Madero where they have small SPA.... Th facilities were not great but the 120 mon jet lag massage was heavenly and the service level was very high!
A nice walk and Good Restaurants. Title says it all especially after you have eaten at Siga La vaca and you need to walk off some severe stomach bloating!

Lovely. We spent our last Sunday afternoon in Puerto Madero, close to the water. It is a bit far from Recoleta and Palermo (we stayed in both places) but it was much quieter than normal, had some nice steakhouses (we went to Siga La Vaca and also had sushi at Sushi Club)

Modern Buenos Aires. Interesting place to take a walk in the evening or night to work up an appetite for many of the restaurants around the modern and refurbished Puerto Madero. Restaurants are touristy and on the the pricey side, but the one we tried was pretty good. Bring rollerblades to roll around like the locals!
Great place to stroll. After seeing many other tourist sights, Puerto Madero is also a good place to stroll.
beuatiful place. Great place to walk around, lots of places to go eat, restaurants from all over the world, you pick!!! lovely area!!!
Great Area, the former piers. Very nice restaurants, wiht a view. Good and modern shops. Definetely a zone of the city that worths a visit!
Good place to visit. Good place to visit a bit overrated, good restaurants are overpriced and the others nothing to write home about it

Beautiful place. I liked the river and the scenery in general. But, make sure to go with a local. It is a place where many tourists go to but with a local you will be able to know better where to go and where to have coffee or eat.
Fantastic afternoon stroll and restaurants. Enjoy a morning or afternoon stroll next to the water in the newest neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Excellent restaurants and hotels.
Puerto Madero. it´s an excelent place to walk arround, very safe, and full of nice and expensive, and very good restaurants

The most 21st Century part of Buenos Aires. It's slick, it's modern, it's expensive, but it is an excellent place to go to enjoy a moonlit night in Buenos Aires. Make sure to walk along the woman's bridge when its lit up, check out the Casa Rosada from across the water, and enjoy the relative safety and quality of the area's bars and restaurants. During the day, head straight for the Eclogical Reserve, which is a welcome break from the frenetic city. I loved the chorizo I had on the border of the reserve and seeing the coast of the Rio Plata was a necessary part of my checklist. Here is a great place to enjoy that. For tourists here for only a short time, enjoy Puerto Madero as part of a bike tour, for others, make sure to have a day stop and an evening stop.

Modern. Interesting. Not a top attraction.. Puerto Madero appeals to people who like chain restaurants, expensive shopping, and snooty cafes. It's pretty. But it looks like lots of cities in the States, so it's not what I'd come to Buenos Aires to see. That said, the Ecological Reserve and the Constanera Sur (also in Puerto Madero) are fantastic. Get a choripan (sausage on a bun) along the Costanera and then head for a bike ride through the reserve. The views of the river are beautiful.

Take a rest and enjoy this boulevard area. Take a rest and enjoy this boulevard area full of nice restaurants (cuban, argentinian, italian). The famous Las Lillas is located there. It is not cheap but worthy!!
Nice place to walk along the river. The bridge is spectacular..a really nice & long walk for locals & tourists. Lots of restaurants to eat at & people watch.

What a spectacular area. We drove through Puerto Madero on a city bus tour and then returned for dinner. I don't recall the name of the restaurant, but I can say that walking around and across the woman's bridge at night was a lovely experience. It is like being in a different city, it is so unlike anywhere else in Buenos Aires. The architecture reminded me of Dubai.

Good place to visit after seeing all the beautiful and historic sites of BA. I liked the atmosphere since we were there on Christmas Day 2011. Festive, not very crowded, beautiful day! The bridge, Puente de la Mujer (Women's Bridge), by Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava is indeed a gem and well designed.

A Must Go in Argentina. Puente de la Mujer is located in Puerto Madero, I recommend going during the night and then heading to one of Puerto Madero's restaurants or bars. Easy access from either the buses or subte (subway)

Overrated?. Perhaps I missed the good spots, but I found Puerto Madero to be a bit overrated. The bridge was unique and beautiful; however the restaurants didn't live up to the hype. The steak dinners I had there were both mediocre and expensive. I prefer Palermo. An Argentine friend of mine told me that they cook steak well-done by default, so unless you like your beef charred to a crisp makes sure to clarify this with the waiter. (Despite how I sound I am not a picky eater; I was nonetheless disappointed by PM restaurants.) As I said, I could have just missed the good steak houses and it's well worth at least one visit just to cheap the area out!
Interesting. Interesting area. Loved both of the museum ships. restaurants can be a bit pricey
Beautiful. Very good restaurants. It's worth a walk along the riverside. Very good hotels are located there as well.

Nice walking area. We decided to walk aorund during the day. There were only a few choices for lunch as most of the restaurants only open for dinner. The Calatrava bridge was a must see as we had seen others around the world. Had coffee and churros at a cafe by the Hilton. Definitely watch your belongings - a friend was almost pick-pocketed while walking around the port.
Beautiful renovated neighborhood.. With plenty excellent restaurants everywhere. If you like churrasco, go to the Las Lilas!
Fun night time spot. A lively and fun spot to get out at night -- you'll feel like part of the BA nightlife but it is less authentic than other parts of the city.
Great Place For Dinner. A place with a lot of good options to dinner with a good winw

A city within a city. A gerat place to view modern achitecture while still retaining the original atmoshere of the docks area. Jump on the Bus Turistico tour. Well worth it to get to know the area before exploring in detail.
very touristic. It is a very touristic place with lots of mosquitoes at night!

Expensive eating. It's a nice place to walk in the afternoon and evening. However, the food is incredibly expensive for the value. Dinner starts late and is expected to last a long time, so if you're travelling alone, enjoy the scenary and head somewhere else to eat other than along the canal. If you're in a group, it's an okay place to have the dining experience.
Go there!. Nice new area. Safe. Go there when it is sunny, or in the evenings.
This reminds me of Shad Thames!. A great re-developped area of the city - some nice restaurants but a little bit far from the centre. Worth a visit.

Great place in the city to get away from the city. This little touted and often overlooked neighborhood in Buenos Aires is a great place for a leisurely day. It is within easy walking distance of downtown, but worlds apart. We strolled down from Casa Rosada and walked along the canals enjoying views of new contemporary architecure in Buenos Aires. It is a safe and clean area filled with lots of restaurants and bars. We visited the Sarmiento ship which as fascinating-particularly the taxidermied dog. Since we do not speak much Spanish getting the full story about the ship was challenging but with the photographs and maps, it worked fine. After our visit there, it was time for lunch and we stopped at one of the canal side cafes and had a delightful nosh and a huge canister (no other way to describe it) of Quismel beer. It was great to relax, take in the views and people watch. From there we headed across the bridge to the other side of the canal and back to the Ecological Preserve. It is truly amazing that they have restored this wetlands area on the edge of this huge, bustling city. There are many trails and as you move through, it is hard to believe that you are still in the city. We stopped by the Collection de Amalia Fortabat next and were astounded at the architiecture of the building and the collection. This is a must see museum in Buenos Aires. We throughly enjoyed our day there and highly recommend it as a way to escape the hustle and bustle of the Avenue de Mayo and Calle Florida.
Very nice place with a lot of character. Everything was great except Borge's Design. The food, culture and people are great. Would like to return again. Was there in May 2008
great place for nice walking or jogging in b. aires. with a lot of restaurants and bars, this place is a nice area to taste a real local meat or a to walking and spend same time look around

Modern Glam Buenos Aires. We spent our last night in Argentina in Puerto Madero. It is clean, neat, safe and vibey. It is nice during the day but really comes alive at night. Lovely to stroll around and then sit down for a bite to eat.

Restaurants, Restaurants, Restaurants. Expect New York City prices at almost all of the restaurants located here. The food, in general is very good, but you can do better in other parts of Buenos Aires for less money.

A lot of dinning choices. If you don't know where to eat when you get to Buenos Aires, try Puerto Madero, you have so many choices !! They are all lined up for your convenience (italian, meat, etc). Also they pride themselves of being one of the safest area in Buenos Aires as they have their own security
Good meals, nice sites. A lot of nice restaurants in Puerto Madero which is also a good place for pictures as a lot of argentinian wedding couples know well!

Puerto Madero. Similar to many cities which have developed their riverside areas. They all feel somewaht sterile, still developing chatacter. Can get a sind tunnel effect between the buildings.Hard to find access to the river front. Would prefer to walk along the water's edge but this was not easy.Updated warehouses, some restaurants, pleasant walk on the pedestrian bridge over the canal.Had a pleasant lunch, and glad to have visited, but would not hurry back!
It looks like 1st World.. The view, the restaurants, to just walk around the canals.

Very Nice Area of Buenos Aires. The Hilton is located in this area of town. There is high end shopping, great restaurants, and it is very pleasant on a warm sunny day. Nice place to hang out for a day.

one of the greatest places on earth. Go there by night or by day, go there on saturday or sunday and enjoy the spirit of this unique place, the silence without traffic, the mixture of such different designs, the choice of the restaurans, go with bike, rollerblades, jog, walk, feel safe and happy ... a dream came true .... check my pictures at http://www.dfaweb.de/buenosaires
Must see!. Beautiful area in the heart of Buenos Aires, full of restaurants and hotels, also is where the famous "women's bridge" is
Ritzy Restaurants and High Hotels. Lots of touristy beef places to eat. The guys at the ice cream shop (Freddo) tried to shortchange me. Go to Palermo or San Telmo instead.

A Very Pleasant Day. I and 2 other friends had a free day in Buenos Aires. Our hotel was just a few blocks away so we decided to walk the river. It is a very pleasant walk and very relaxing. Several small restaurants along the way, lots of nice modern buildings and some sailing ships worth visiting, which we did. The Women's Bridge is also very nice and adds a nice touch to the area. We also ate dinner one night at one of the restaurants and had lunch at another. All good experiences.
Great place for the evening. The restaurants there are great (most of them, of course), and it is beautiful for a walk in the evening.

Big modern city... didn't come here for that.. It looks just like ANY big modern city in America. I didn't come down here to see that. Check out the more authentic neighborhoods like Palermo, Recoleta, San Telmo, etc.

Upscale, great place to walk around during the day. This is BA's "newest" neighborhood, close to the river. There are a lot of upscale restaurants, clubs, and shops on the walkways. You definitely have to see the "puente de la mujer" (woman's bridge), as it is an amazing piece of architecture. I wouldn't recommend staying in this area, as it is very expensive and not very lively compared to Palermo, but definitely something to checkout! xxx

Good atmosphere, lots of restaurants. This is a very touristic place, with a lot of restaurants of all kinds.We liked more going there during the night. It is a very calm and it seems to be very safe during the night.

good place to walk around and enjoy the scene. nice place to spend the day walking by the water and having food in the outdoor seating areas ...make sure you visit Florida street a few blocks north of this walkway for good deals on shopping

Nice place to visit!!!. It's a very beautiful place to go and share with your family and friends, tango couples are dancing in the afternoon and you can eat, smoke and have some beers at any of the good restaurants you will see through the streets.
Great location. There is one of the world harbors that got a real lift-up, mostly like Baltimore. Can't go to Buenos Aires and not go there fo a walk and have dinner at one of it's reataurants.
It's really just a bridge. Pretty to look at, but don't go out of your way to find it.
A breath of fresh air, literally. It is a waterfront area and is a very pleasant place to have a stroll and a coffee away from the city.

Puerto Madero is nice... but not the top attraction in B.A.. Many of my Argentine friends raved in advance about Puerto Madero, telling me how great it was etc. When I finally got there I must say I was a bit disappointed and underwhelmed.Puerto Madero is an old shipping dock neighborhood that has been revamped into a modern causeway several blocks long on either side of the canal, lined with very over priced restaurants, pubs, hotels etc.This is nothing you can't see on a much grander scale in cities like Toronto or Vancouver.I think the people of Buenos Aires 'think' visitors want to see a modern part of their city... yet in reality most people come to Buenos Aires to see the older, more unique barrios like Recoleta, San Telmo and La Boca.I didn't have the heart to tell them otherwise and just played along with it, nodding my head in agreement as they continually told me how fabulous Puerto Madero was.Just to give you an idea how over priced and touristy this part of town is... me and a friend stopped at one of countless restaurant/pubs along the canal and had a simple order of Picada (*1 order to share between us), Calamari (*1 order to share between us) and a couple beer.The bill was roughly $100 USD!!!For some simple pub food and a couple beer!!!Puerto Madero is something you must go see quickly once I suppose if you visit B.A... but I wouldn't spend any more than an hour there walking the causeway.Then get out of there unless you are rich and feel like paying top dollar for average food and drink.
Most Vibrant Part of Buenos Aires. I enjoyed the vibrant culture that part of the city exudes. I didn't feel 100% safe carrying an expensive camera around!
Nice safe part of town at night. Plenty of restaurants and bars. There are also three Starbucks here.
Lovely area. Numerous super restaurants on the waterside overlooking The Majer Bridge

good Saturday night. We went there for spending Saturday night. lots of bars and restaurants.So you can can find something great.Most of the bars and restaurants have a good view and easily and safe you can walk and enjoy the view of waterfront and lights.
Puerto Madero. approx 3 miles of restaurants and not much else but probably the nicer part of Buenos Aires
small waterfront area. The bridge is beautiful to visit especially at dusk. Lots of restaurant options along the waterfront and street side but not much else to see.
Terrible. Please, go to another because this is more Vegas than Buenos Aires. Horrible in everything. I went in Senor Tango and Esquina Carlos Gardel, Piazzola, are exclent.

a sunny day on the docks. As part of our exploration of Buenos Aires, we spent part of day in the Puerto Madero district, enjoying the sun, the proximity to the water, and a choice of many cafes and restaurants. There is not much to do, other than walk the banks of the canals and take in the atmosphere of an upscale urban oasis.
New meets Old. Great street food and deli markets. Interesting redevelopment and well worth a tour of the area.
Good location for a choice of modern restaurants. Most restaurants have an outside river view covered patio as will as inside dinning. There are many choices.
Fun trendy place to visit for dinner. Puerto Madero has numerous restaurant choices along the river front with excellent views and fine dining. Definitely worth a visit.

Pleasant. This hi tech, modern area of the city is interesting mainly in it's contradictions with the old city areas. Fancy restaurants with high prices line the "waterfront". Interesting modern architectural features provide some interest. But the real heart of the city lies elsewhere- eg, san telmo, boca and even Palermo and north.
Beautiful. Beautiful water way, the female bridge, restaurant, can't miss in if visiting Buenos Aires
Great for a stroll. this place is great for a stroll and alfressco dining. Parts of the waterfront are still under development but it will be great once everything is done

Lovely. The modern architecture is breathtaking. Across the woman's bridge (a sight in itself) is a good museum of modern art that contains an original Warhol. The place is full of high-end restaurants, and is great for an afternoon stroll.

Great restaurants and the safest place in Buenos Aires. You should always visit this placeif you're in Buenos Aires. The best restaurants in town are there and believe me, the prices are not bad... An evening walk is always recommended. Loved it!
Newest neighbourhood in Buenos Aires.. See the new skyline near the river, with top restaurants and hotels in the city. It´s very nice to have lunch or dinner, or just walk and take photos.
Beautiful neighborhood. Build relatively recently mostly new buildings (reminded me a little of Miami) deffinetly worth visiting on the nice day and hop few cafes and bars

The Port. Great to walk along both sides and marvel at the old sail training ships that are now permanently moored alongside. A great mixture of moderately expensive restaurants also make this an eaters paradise.

Varied sightseeing and eating. Pleasant walk through the recently renovated old port facilities of Buenos Aires (the River Plate is a muddy brown color because it drains a large area of Southern Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay and northern Argentina). A wide variety of upper range restaurants offering very good beef. But be prepared to pay top dollar. Birdwatchers might like to walk towards the river past Puerto Madero (away from the city) till you get to "Costanera Sur" where you will find an older promenade with large trees facing a landfill that has been left to go wild. Be wary of pickpockets though. This area is popular for the inhabitants of Buenos Aires and tends to get crowded on weekends and holidays.

Things I would do in Puerto Madero. I was visiting my sister who lives in the Puerto Madero neighborhood in early March and would suggest the following highlights:1. Go eat at La Cabaña along the water. They had the best steak I had on my entire trip and yummy empanadas for your starter (included in the cubiertos charge). 2. Visit the nature reserve which is an area with extensive paths along the water to walk or bike along. Nice way to get out in nature while in a big city. Rent a bike from the orange juice guy by the entrance and also get an OJ after- very refreshing!
Restaurants and side walk. Beautiful place to go, justa walk around and stop by one of the restaurants for a great meal...
A really nice area of the city. A great area of the city, really modern and full of nice restaurants and shops. You can have a nice promenade across the port and take some beautiful pictures.
Fun night time walk. Pleasant walk in the evening. Lots of restaurants. Many filled with tourists but definitely some gems. We found a Peruvian fusion restaurant that was fantastic.
nice and quiet. it's the safest zone in buenos aires, it has lots of restaurants( you can recognise them by the red bricks) and shopping places.

For a nice stroll and dinner with a river view. Puerto Madero is billed as Buenos Aires' upcoming barrio and it is. Newly refurbrished warehouses now house a good selection of restaurants with a river view. It is a lovely place to stroll when you are not in a hurry. It is within walking distance of Centro area.

Nice area, but neighborhoods are more interesting. Somewhat sterile and relatively expensive formerly industrial area of BA. This is a commercial redevelopment that has no real soul to it. The Palermo/SoHo and Recoleta/centro areas are more interesting to walk around in. Due to it's position on the immense River Plate, wind is a constant factor. Lots of outdoor dining, but much better food for the money can be found in more charming areas. There is an interesting bridge, an historic yacht, and the area is generally nice and attractive but more interesting areas await.

Excellent restaurant and shops for thick wallets. This is a very quiet neighborhood, with great restaurants and shops. The area is very pricey for Argentina. You''ll pay for a steak the same or more compared to the US. If you go to downtown or other areas of Buenos Aires, the steaks and other meals are as good for a quarter of the price. Off course, you can't beat the location and the 5 star service. A must, if you visit Buenos Aires. I wouldn't stay in a hotel there since is very hard to access by taxi due to heavy traffic during business hours. No access problems in the evenings.

Light and modern, a breath of fresh air in Buenos Aires. Tons of riverfront restaurants in converted warehouses line one side of the river while modern hotels, restaurants and other commercial and residential buildings line the opposite bank. Can walk on unbroken and clean sidewalks (unlike in the rest of Buenos Aires) and sit in the sun to watch the world go by. I would stay there if I ever went back.

Great food. We were recommended to go there by the Concierge at our hotel and it was a 15 minute walk which was most pleasant , We were lucky with the weather ...no rain so it was lovely to walk the waterfront and there were of locals around enjoying the breeze and views. We had dinner in one of the many restaurants there which was very good though a little expensive. We also saw the tango show at the Madero and it was super.Five couples in the show nd they were suberb!

nice place for restaurants. This area is the new and modern area of the city. It is nice, however it lacks the charm of the old part. In puerto madero you can find a lot of good restaurant, but most of them not cheap.

Dockside delight. Big modern buildings, wide open spaces and nice places to eat and drink. That's Puerto Madero in a nutshell. It's a respite from the hurly burly of BAs clogged streets - and the gateway to the delightful reserva nautral which leads down to the river. Another great area for a day of wondering around.
Modern and Expensive area.. Puerto Madero is a new area. I was impressed but it has no soul. Good restaurants around to go dinner (night is beatiful walking) . Try to go with someone is so romantic!
Evenings only. We went both during the day and evening. Mainly restaurant row with nice views of the river. Much prettier at night particularly the puente de Los mujeres.
Excellent view and delicious food!. Going to Puerto Madero is a unforgettable tour, after you taste that meat you will go one and another!!! Don´t miss this walk if you go to Buenos Aires!!
Peace & quiet. a nice change away from the hustle and bustle of BA traffic. Great restaurants
If you're into urban planning, visit this. Ultra modern development. Remarkable make over of a former industrial area
great food, lovely area. very scenic, reasonable prices, good food, good service, security abounds

Nice for a brief stroll, but it could be anywhere. You could be in Miami. You could be at the Baltimore inner harbor. This is the old port, that's been gentrified to the extreme over the past 15 years. It's made up by sterile, corporate apartment buildings and offices, and exorbitantly priced restaurants. It's not the 'real BA'. But not a bad place to go for an afternoon stroll.

Really nice and quite place, great open air space. You can see Calatrava bridge, walk in pedant area, visit national park by bicycle, and get great food in many restaurants in the old docks of the harbor. You can really spent a great day.

great, old and modern. We loved the area. It has very nice restaurant. All seems clean and modern, but still in an old way. They area is open. The old buildings are still used and combined with new modern building. On a sunny day, when you do have enough of the city a great please to relaxe.

Take a stroll through Puerto Madero to breath Buenos Aires. Puerto Madero is a very nice walk, as there are shops, great restaurants, the ships that serve as museums, the beautiful young ladies that work nearby in the corporate offices...

Lots of great restaurants, great place to run, or just people watch. There are many, many restaurants around this area, many of which have outdoor seating available. Perfect place for people watching. Nice wide open walkways, great for going for a run,
Beautiful. Very nice place to walk around, eat and visit some very fancy places.
Looks like a US suburban greenbelt. Nice place for a stroll or bike ride, but doesn't have the feel of the rest of Buenos Aires. Just okay

Great riverfront location to watch the passing scene.. I love sitting outdoors in PM along the river, watching the couples (of all ages) slowly stroll by, with teenage boys on their skateboards adding a bit of visual excitement. Some of the captal's best restaurants are located here in this ultra-modern setting, but the historic center of BA is just across the pedestrian bridges.
Beautiful place, at night!. Waloking on the riverside, with lots of pricy and luxurious restaurants, lights and breeze is perfect, we really enjoyed it!

The Fisherman's Wharf of BA. Modern, touristy. LOADS of restaurants - two of the best in BA. Definitely a place to visit, but do beware of pickpockets - didn't happen to us but we met people who had their wallents taken

Great place for a walk and some fine meal. Puerto madero is very famous, and it was a nice place to go for a walk, seeing the renovation that was done to the old port of the city. It is a beautiful place, and there are lots of good restaurants to eat. We went to Cabaña Las Lillas. Expensive but worth it.
Nice place to have dinner. Nice place to have dinner and walk along the river.

Safest place at night, excellent restaurants.. If you're coming to my city, of course there are many areas you can visit: downtown, Belgrano, Recoleta, Palermo, and so on. But, if you want to go outside at night, downtown becomes a desert area -don't forget downtown is just banking and business buildings-, and the aforementioned neighborhoods are somewhat far away from the usual hotel areas. Until 1990, Puerto Madero was an abandoned area of the Port, since then it has been fully refurbished and it has become the place where you can find the newest, most modern buildings and condos in Buenos Aires. Most Movie & TV personalities, millionaires and well known singers and artists are now living (or have properties) in this area. Security is tight here, not just due to camera surveillance or private security people, but because it is a special area of the city, since it is separated from the coast and built on lands gained to the river, the security depends on the "Prefectura Naval" (Navy Police) which is very strict regarding security matters.Here, you can walk freely without worrying about thieves or the like, and if you go the the Alicia Moreau de Justo Avenue, you'll find lots of bars & restaurants, with many options, from cheap to extremely luxury. You can access to some comments on restaurants from my profile. Even if it is just for a walk, you can have good views of the De La Plata River; on a full moon night, it's something worth to see.
Great Restaurants. Good food...lots of good restaurants to choose from...great night life

The best place at night. As downtown is dangerous and Recoleta and Palermo are too distant of everything, Puerto Madero is for sure the best place to walk at the end of the day, and them, sit in a restaurant to take a good glass of wine. The lights are beautiful, mainly in Fragata Sarmiento and in the Women Bridge. The restaurants are very nice, music shows are everywhere. Very romantic place. Different from other ports of Argentina... maybe the unique charmy port of South America.
New place in Buenos Aires and beautiful place. It's a very nice neighborhood to walk around, eat and enjoy the river.

Worth visitng. An interesting and ultra modern area of BA. It is nice being by the water and there are some pleasant restaurants. It is worth seeing the drawbridge (which pivots) open -- we saw it at 4 pm.

Beautiful neighborhood for a walk. Puerto Madero is one of Buenos Aires´ most recent and fast developing areas. Characterized by its parks, open areas and new buildings, Puerto Madero is great to experience a different side of the city, its most modern one.

Modernized old docs with many restaurants. Puerto Madero has a nice view of the river and is good for strolling around on a nice day, even it one does not want to eat in one of the many restaurants, but have an ice cream. Cabana Las Lilas is the most famous restaurant of Puerto Madero and although it is quite expensive is worth a visit. The main dish is of course barbacue
Good for Argentine standards, but not if compared worldwide. Good place to strall, and learn Argentinean snobish.
puerto madero. Loved being near the water. It is easy to walk around the city from that area.

clean and nice. the "newest neighborhood" in Buenos Aires, supposedly. Lots of expensive, high-end restaurants, some cool architecture, but it lacks the charm of Palermo or Recoleta, as it's kind of isolated from the rest of the city. Definitely a great place to stroll around during the day, though!

Waterfront property transformed into tourist attraction. The old port has been transformed like other cities into living space, restaurants and sightseeing attractions. We visited here on a Sunday afternoon and found it packed with families, couples and rollerbladers enjoying the atmosphere. Good way to spend a leisurely Sunday.
Great restaurant area. Puerto Madero offers a wide variety of restaurant options. Lunch at the newly opened Nautica Rosa was wonderful. Great food, service and ambience.
Great. Good restaurants... enjoyed Campo de Asadores, pleasant evening walk.
Good food and nice ambience. It is a great place during the day or night ,The best restaurants and some places not so expensive , Nice place to see people .
Calm, peaceful new area in BA. Good for a nice stroll in the most modern part of BA: right at the port with a range of excellent resto's to try out. Good for some relaxing!

Many restaurants, nice walk. In Puerto Madero you can choose from a variety of nice restaurants, from different style and prices, or just take a walk by the river. Nice place for a sunset time. Oh, yes, if you take a walk, take a Freddo ice cream (helado) "dulce de leche" with you -- it is just there, close to the restaurants.
Nice at night!. In february summer is wonderful by night! Although was the second time I ate in a not very nice restaurant... Watch out!!

Charming. Charming place in the town!
But, don´t go to FRODDO icecream. TERRIBLE service.

MUST SEE AND EXPLORE. should you wish to experience contemporary BA - this is the place to go. Stunning modern architecture, great restaurants and bars, facinating sights. It is amazing how a smart developer can turn old docs in the most fashionable and trendy area of the city.The restaurant are pricy but some of them are worth every penny of it. Sit on the terraces of any one of them and watch both local people and visitors take a leisurely walk . Strongly recommended.
nice place to stoll. Loved the view. Nice place to stroll or just walk and see the people passing by!
Great Area to Take a Stroll. A great place to walk along the rivers edge. There are many great restaurants including an ice cream store.
Out for dinner. Great place for dinner. Walking to the tango bridge is a must if you like architecture. Not great for relaxing outside with a glass of wine. Puerto Madero is best for dining.

A new city within the city. Puerto Madero is the result of the refurbishing of the old port area in Buenos Aires. It has been turned into a Modern City overlooking La Plata River. Lots of places to walk to, old ships and docks. Restaurants, movie theatres and even a floating Casino.

Relaxing and luxurious new area. Good use of old warehouses meanly as restaurants on one side and very modern area with promenade on the other side of the water. Nice yachtharbour. Pretty atmosphere to relax and escape from the city heat.
A great place to walk around. Sitting by the port and sipping a glass of vino in the sun is a great experience whilst people watching
Great place to walk around. Safe spot to walk day and night. There's lots of restaurants (but none is cheap).
nice walk by the river. It is the perfect place to go for a walk in the afternoon.

Fantastic marina area. The choice of restaurants is great, many of a very high quality.
Tasted my best steak since I was in Argentina last in 2006!
Very safe area, discreet security throughout.

Urban renewal at its most interesting. This area of renovated warehouses along the water way is a very nice place to walk and eat. See/go on, for example, the two beautiful old sailing ships (one the Argentine Navy's training ship) tied up on the quay. There are a number of upscale restaurants with ample outdoor seating. Go to Cabana las Lilas and have great wine, a huge, perfectly cooked steak and watch the passing parade.
Nice thing to do. Lots of restaurant options. We tried Las Lilas. Great food, rather pricey.
A nice place, good for eat, running.... Go there and veryngood places to eat and dancing at night, or run and jogging.
nicest place in BA. in very busy, crowded BA this is a place where you can have a nice walk and admire interesting modern architecture
Just to walk and take the city vibe!. It's a good place to walk, take the vibe and look for a good place to eat! You have to visit the "Ponte de la Mujer" - a nice architecture sample!

A great palce to run, walk or peoplewatch. We went for a run and then on a sort of pub crawl - stopping for a cool drink at one spot and then continuing to another for dinner. it was cool on a very hot day and not so many toursits as other parts of the city

New and goog neigborhood. It´s the newest neighborhook in Buenos Aires. By the river, You can have nice views of the river. There are very good restaurants. There you will find Fortabat Museum with very important paintings.

Nice though a little insipid. Very nice, clean and safe. also a little bit boring unless you're planning to have dinner around there in which case the first 3 descriptions are probably helpful. Nice restaurants abound though many are geared to the tourist industry. Great place to stay though as near to the city without the hassle.
Great views but the restaurants are overpriced.. This is a great place for a stole but the restaurants are overpriced. They are good but expensive for what you get.
You find everything you need. From restaurants, bars, nightclubs, coffee shops and pharmacies. Its one of the safest places in Buenos Aires

Restaurant Row. We enjoyed a delicious two hour lunch at Cabana Las Lilas, less expensive than going there for dinner and with the added pleasure of watching joggers, strollers, and kayakers along the waterfront.

Interesting buildings and good restaurants. Puerto Madero is built on the old wharfs of Buenos Aires - some ot the buildings are reformed warehouses. It is now the most expensive neighbourhood and has more than 100 restaurants to choose from. Some highrises are signed by world known architects - and you have the Rio de la Plata as your backdrop

Beautiful. This is a very beautiful place to go. There's a nice bridge (puente de la mujer) where you can take beautiful photos and there are different types of great (and most of times expensive) restaurants and bars.

Nice stroll by the river - good restaurants. There are two very distinctive sides of the river... the most "touristy" one and the other for locals. for a true argentine atmosphere, go across the Puente de la Mujer Bridge and walk around in the newer part. Take care of restaurants that are too expensive, considering taking money to tourists. check the menu before getting in!

Very pretty at night!. This is the up market part of Capital (Buenos Aires). It is so gorgeous to go out for dinner and walking around the whole area along the water. The restaurants are high quality meals with big price tags attached. It is a touristy area and they charge accordingly. It is a fancy pricey place, but beautiful even if you just want to walk around and have a look- a must do place to see if passing through Buenos Aires!

Perfect. I love this place, so peaceful and quiet it almost seems as if it's far away from downtown (when actually it's a 10 minute walk). Great restaurants (maybe a bit expensive, maybe average for tourists) and great place to walk and take nice photos.

Modern Buenos Aires. This is as modern as Buenos Aires gets. Lovely (expensive) bars and restaurant next to the water. If you have some money to spend, I would recomend a breakfast by the water! Don't go if its raining, it gets greyish!

good for a walk...not much else. Puerto Madero is very modern with a lot of restaurants along the water on Alicia Moreau de Justo. It's not very Argentinian, and very similar to Canary Wharf in London or the Embarcadero in San Francisco.

The perfect place for a relaxing visit in buzzling Buenos Aires. Puerto Madero used to be the original cargo and passengers´ port of Buenos Aires. The port ceased operations in the 1959s and for almost 4 decades it sat quiely and just used to storage. In 1998, the governments of Argentina and the City of Buenos Aires created the Corporation of Puerto Madero as a means to spur redevelopment of this blighthed area, and new economic development. The place is today an amazing attraction and one of the most expensive neighborhoods of Buenos Aires. The perfect place to be outdoors, surrounded by the port´s heritage and amazing architecture. A must see. Perfect for lunch and dinner, if you can afford it. Most Americans/Europeans will find the prices to be acceptable as
Nice to walk. Great restaurants. Business area as well as tourist. Do not forget to walk over "puente de la mujer" bridge

rushed, poor planning and ego gone wild. Puerto Madero is a good idea on paper but in reality is barely works. Who plans a modern urban area without transportation and work flow? it's apparent this rush job of a location does.The tall buildings could be apparent considering there is no one actually walking around them and some of the smaller buildings look vacant on closer inspection. i love the idea of this place but it is a bust at this time. The best thing about Puerto Madero is Avenida Hernan on the weekend. The parilla's and the street fair really liven the place up. It is a shame no cares to help throw garbage awey though. The litter is out of control.Should you walk the nature reserve just try and keep a positive outlook. Remember that this use to be a wasteland, mother nature is trying to beat back the porteno's lack of cleaning up after themselves and someday these people shall pass.The beaches are a sad sad sight. I would recommend coming hear to walk the trails and enjoy some quiet time in BA, just avoid the beach areas should litter bother you.

I really cant explain. this neighborhood is nice , clean , calm and yes , kind of beautiful , too. But I really wasnt excited about it. Felt like nothing happens , everything was SO quiet I got bored , in five minutes I think. I would choose another place to saty in BAs , like Recoleta or Palermo.

Upmarket but Characterless II. I love this title from a prior review, and I think it sums up the neighborhood perfectly. It could be anywhere, and there is nothing of particular note that I came across. Find the most non-descript part of the city, and you've got the idea. I stayed in this neighborhood because of convenience and access to downtown, but that doesn't make it a sight in its own right.

Quiet, clean, cool. A quiet spot away from the crowds with nice, upmarket restaurants overlooking deserted docks. Not much character and the only people will be you, other ambling tourists, scattered lunchtime joggers and the people who work here. Can safely be skipped if you have limited time in the city as there's little to distinguish it from hundreds of other dockland redevelopments around the world.

Nice place to eating. A very beautiful neighborhood with a lot of cafes and restaurants. From here you can see a lot of ships, including one floating casino. You can only take a walk or stop and get a wonderful coffee or a fantastic meal.
The most famous restaurant is "Siga La Vaca".

Upmarket but characterless. Very pleasant modern environment but could be in any big city. Worth visiting the sail training ship Presidente Sarmiento - permanently moored near the bridge. We had an excellent meal (salmon rather than beef!) in a restaurant called Fresh Market. This is a high class deli during the day. We had no problems with currency exchange but if you are unlucky you can get scammed by cab drivers if you pay in US dollars or offer 100 peso note. If you buy in a decent shop or restaurant US dollars should be fine.

Nice place for a stroll. We had an evening stroll along the lengths of docks 3 and 4 and enjoyed the lively atmosphere of the area. The western side is still full of rather touristy restaurants and a few cafes. The eastern side is also now well developed. We felt fairly safe and when you've had enough of walking, you can take the tram (running parallel to the docks) back to where you started for 1 peso each (coins only).

great to take children. We took our children (12, 11 and 7) and walked watching the river, we entered the museum boat (Fragata Sarmiento) and they had a great time. We had a very good lunch, in a fancy restaurant for a good price. There are also coffee shops, ice creams and "churros"We went also another day at night for dinner. It is very nice at night too, and safe.

I Love Tango!. There is a wonderful Resturant/Tango Club in Puerto Madero where you a see a lovely Tango show of 2 hrs.with 1 15 min.Interval very well done allot of fun!My only complaint & just say no is that they try to take your picture for money or sell u a DVD for money.But aside from that it's all good & a must see.For the entire dinner with a bottle of wine desert & show $50.00 PP.

A fun place to walk around. While nothing exceptional, Puerto Madero is a nice place to walk along the water and there are ample benches all around if you want to just sit and relax and enjoy the nice day (and an occasional breeze). There are many restaurants in Puerto Madero which cater to tourists - menus printed in English, outdoor seating, and higher prices. The food that we had at the restaurants there was fine, but no better than the food we found for considerably less in other neighborhoods. The outdoor seating is nice and the atmosphere is enjoyable. You can also see the famous "Woman" bridge and tour a few old Argentine naval ships for a minimal cost (2 pesos per person), which are interesting but require only about 20 minutes of time. All the information on the ships is provided solely in Spanish, so if you don't know Spanish you're basically just looking at various artifacts. My suggestion would be to spend a few hours walking around Puerto Madero to see it (maybe early morning or in the evening), and then go on to other parts of the city. If possible, visit when you want nothing more than helado (ice cream) as a snack, because there are better places in Buenos Aires to eat.

Cooler by the water. I first visited in March 2006, when a taxi driver took me to Cabana Las Lilas, a restaurant I thoroughly enjoyed, although it is touristy and pricey by comparison. Still Puerto Madero is a great place to visit, and it is nice on hot days to sit on one the many verandas along the waterside to partake of a cool beverage. I met some very nice local people at the Spell Cafe, and returned there a few times for more reasonably priced food and drink. The Calatrava or Women's Bridge is an architectural work of art. I spent much more time in the area when I rented an apartment in BA for a month in 2007, and got to really check things out. Cabana Las Lilas is great, but noisy inside when busy; sit outside in the back if you can. I think that applies to all the places along the canal. I've eaten there about six times. Never disappointed. Great service. My fine steak dinners there averaged about 50 American dollars, but I was extravagant, having at least one bottle of good wine, appetizers, dessert, and espresso. My more favored restaurant is La Baita in Palermo, but that's for another review.

Nice concept, but touristy. Nicely redone port area for tourists. Many restaurants, but some are chains from other places.Bice (the original in Milan, Italy is great). This one was not very good and expensive. If you live in NY, Houston or Dallas you can try it there. We ate mostly at local and loved the food.
Lovely Place. Great place for photo opportunities. It feels a little romantic, but then again, what doesn't in Buenos Aires?

Madiocre...At best. Puerto Madero is nothing but a canal with boats and super expensive restaurants designed for tourists...The restauranst are extremely expensive...Not worth it...And other than the restaurants, there's not much to do...There are two old ships docked by the canal...They are beautiful, and entrance is free...but that can be done in 30 minutes...Ohter than that, please don't get scammed in those ridiculously priced restuarants...

Must visit this place. I felt compelled to write a review because the other ones are too old. I stayed in Buenos Aires with my wife and children during August 19-26 / 2007. Puerto Madero is one of the places that you must visit in Buenos Aires. I understood that it was the old Buenos Aires' port and was a ruin until a few years ago when the city began urban renewal of all the place. In one side you will see new and modern buildings and on the other the old port depots converted to beatiful buildings with restaurants, stores and apartments. You will find two interesting ships from the 1890 and 1920s that are museums. Even the old cranes have been painted and restored and are now an original decoration of what once was the main port of Buenos Aires.The place is perfect to visit at any time, and it is huge. You have to like to walk. Near dike 1 you will find Cabaña Las Lilas. Superb food, wine and service. It is expensive for Argentinian standards, but I am sure you will find it not as expensive as many similar restaurants in other countries that don't get even closer to Las Lilas quality. In the other extreme (dike 4, you have to walk a lot) you will find Siga La Vaca restaurant. An All you can Eat restaurant, inexpensive and excellent. Don't expect gourmet wine or service, but we don't have any complaint. You pay per each person that take a chair and the included beverage can be a bottle of wine (per person!!). My wife wasn't feeling well, we think due to some virus, and the waitress was kind enough as to offer not to charge her if she didn't feel good to eat. At the end my wife ate because everything was so good.I don't have any problem with pickpockets or strange people. There are policemen everywhere and the place is clean, open, full of students of a nearby university, people that work in the office builidings and other tourists. Between dike 1 and dike 4 you will find a lot of other restaurants. They looked nice but I didn't eat at them, so can't say anything about their quality. On the other hand, one thing difficult to find during our visit to B.A. was a place with bad food. We didn't get into anyone.Regarding taxis, remises and radio taxis. Radio taxis require a telephone number before sending you a taxi. So have at hand your hotel or rented apartment phone number. They don't accept cell phones if the number is from other country. We used this service mainly to get from our apartment to other place. Once in the street, we used to stop taxis and didn't have any bad experience. But we are latinamericans and our first language is Spanish. Our accent revealed we are foreigners but even the worst faced taxi driver that we met, was at the end much nicer that any other similar taxi drivers we had met in other countries. Use common sense and be modest. I found the porteños (Buenos Aires people) are the most educated and friendly people. They will help you and make you feel at ease.

A must in Bs As. We went dining twice to Puerto Madero during our week long stay in Buenos Aires. Together with Las Cañitas, in Palermo, I'd say this is one of the finest dining districts in the city, with plenty of high quality, excellent value restaurants to choose from."Cabaña las Lilas" is supposed to be the best parilla in BsAs. However, it's far more expensive than most steak houses... and the steak is definitely not worth it, although the place and service are wonderful (especially the table "cover", which includes mozzarella, salmon, pepperonatta and a delicious freshly baked bread). Table "cover", nonetheless, adds $10 to the bill which are not specified anywhere, so be warned. I think a better choice would be "La Chacra", a wonderful parrilla at Cordoba Av., near 9 de Julio.Our second (and far better) dining experience was at "Marcelo", a restaurant owned by Buenos Aires' renowned chef Marcelo Piegari (who also owns "Piegari", the city's best restaurant as stated everywhere). Pasta and risottos are made for sharing, and the fresh pasta (made at the restaurant) is absolutely amazing! Try the spinach-ricotta filled ravioli with pomodoro sauce, it's truly an epicurean experience. Desserts are wonderful, too. The meal for two was $30.All in all, I'd highly reccomend Puerto Madero to anyone in Buenos Aires.

Caution in this tourist area. Be careful when getting picked up at night even from a radio taxis for the counterfeit currency exchange when visiting this touristy area. I find most of the scam problems or pick-pocketing takes place in areas frequented by tourists and Puerto Madero is one of them. It is by itself and outside of the real downtown district and developed only recently with more of an international standard of development. The best meat restaurant Cabanas Las Lilas is there so you will want to go there, but just be very cautious about currency switch scams. Check you bill and your change at the restaurant and be sure to keep your eyes on the money you hand over to the cab driver. And get very suspicious if all the sudden all he claims you are giving him are counterfiet bills.Ask him to take you to the main police station on Lavalle 400, only a few blocks away and get the currency sorted out.

fine shopping at Puerto Madero. Puerto Madero is a great shopping and dining district in buenos aires. the outdoor mall is right on the river which is very scenic at night. During the day we went shopping and had some very pleasant meals. There is plenty of security so we felt safe. On frommers we read about a restaurant named Cabana las lillas which is supposedly the best "parilla" in buenos aires. With such a great article about this restaurant we decided to make this place a definite stop. The restaurant I must say is beautiful, it is right on the river and it is very upscale. The "parilla" grill is enclosed in glass allowing the guests to see the food being prepared. The service was also great. Now...the food. Our party had seven guests, not one of the main courses was even decent. The steak was so hard and veiny that I had to end up leaving half of it! (and I am talking about the filet mignon). The meal for seven was only $175 dollars (incl. wine, beer, dessert) other than the ambiance I would have had more quality food at Burger King!
